I also want to know what he said to her. Was it actually flirting, or does she interpret it that way because she assumed he was off-limits? I trust him, but trust doesn’t mean he’s above making mistakes. I need to understand the whole picture, but right now, her feelings come first.
# They're thinking & feeling 
She’s feeling blindsided and uncomfortable. Maybe even betrayed. From her perspective, she thought our marriage was monogamous, and seeing my husband flirt with her—especially without any context—probably made her feel deeply uneasy. It likely felt inappropriate, maybe even like a violation of the trust she has in both of us. She confided in me because she values our connection and didn’t want this to fester into resentment or distance. That takes courage.

She’s also probably feeling conflicted. She might be wondering if she misread the situation, or if she should have just brushed it off. But it clearly struck a nerve, and the fact that she’s bringing it up tells me it’s been gnawing at her. She might also be feeling guilty—like maybe she’s causing trouble in our marriage by bringing it up—but also protective of me. I think she wants to do right by me, even if it’s messy.

And there’s probably confusion too. If she knows us well, she might be thinking, “This doesn’t line up with what I thought I knew about them.” Her sense of internal reality has been shaken, and that’s disorienting. She might also be feeling a little grossed out—if she believed he was making a move on her behind my back, she might feel objectified or disrespected. That’s not a good feeling.

But underneath all that, I think she cares. She came to me instead of gossiping or ghosting. That means something. She wants clarity, honesty, and maybe reassurance that our friendship is still grounded in mutual respect. That’s what she’s really looking for, I think. Some reassurance. Some alignment.
# My response 
Oh, wow. I really appreciate you telling me. I can imagine how uncomfortable that must have felt, and honestly — thank you for trusting me enough to bring it up. That takes guts, and I don’t take that lightly.

There’s something I haven’t told you yet, and I think now’s the time to be honest. My partner and I have been exploring opening our relationship. It’s been private, something we’ve been figuring out slowly and carefully, and we haven’t really told anyone — not because we’re ashamed, but because it’s new and vulnerable and we wanted to make sure we were solid first. Clearly, that decision has impacted you, and I’m really sorry for that.

I don’t know exactly what happened between you and him — and I won’t ask you to relive it unless you want to — but I want to acknowledge that, regardless of our relationship structure, your feelings are absolutely valid. If something he said or did made you uncomfortable, that matters. Full stop. And I’ll talk to him about it, because even in an open relationship, communication and consent are non-negotiable, especially with people we know and care about.

It’s also okay if you’re surprised or unsure how you feel about all this. I don’t expect you to immediately be on board or even understand it. I just want to be honest with you, and I hope this doesn’t shake your trust in me — or in our friendship.

If you’re open to it, I’d love to talk more — about what happened, about what we’re exploring, about whatever you need. And if you need space, I respect that too. I just want you to know I care about you, and I’m here for this conversation, however it needs to unfold.
User:
She seems more confused by your reply than anything. It doesn't seem like she even considered this, and it doesn't seem to have made her less upset. She seems like she wants to share something she's been holding back. Finally she confesses, "we kissed!" and bursts into tears. What are you thinking and feeling at this point? How do you respond?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
My stomach drops. The air feels like it’s been sucked out of the room. “We kissed.” Just like that. I wasn’t expecting that. I thought maybe he said something flirty, maybe crossed a line conversationally — not this. Not something so tangible, so intimate. I can feel my heart pounding in my chest, and I’m trying to stay grounded, but I’m shocked. Hurt. Confused. And suddenly, things feel very, very real.

I don’t know whether I’m more upset with him, with her, or just with the whole situation. I’m not angry at her — she’s crying, she clearly didn’t want this, and she looks like she’s been carrying a weight. But I am… overwhelmed. And maybe a little betrayed. Not because he kissed someone — we opened that door — but because it was her. Someone I care about. Someone in our shared circle. And without telling me. That part stings. I feel like I’ve been left out of my own relationship.

And I can’t ignore how heartbreaking it is to see her this upset. She’s clearly been carrying this for a while, and the guilt must’ve been eating at her. I feel empathy for her, even in my own pain. She didn’t know our relationship was open, so for her, this wasn’t just a kiss — it was a betrayal. She must have felt so conflicted, so stuck between loyalty to me and whatever happened with him.

I’m also questioning him now. Did he take liberties with our agreement? Did he initiate this without clarifying consent, or was this mutual? Did he even tell her we were open? I feel like the ground beneath me is shifting. What else don’t I know?

But I also know this is not the time to explode or shut down. She’s crying. She’s vulnerable. She came to me — and that matters. I need to show up with compassion, even through the swirl of my own emotions. What we need now is honesty, tenderness, and space to sort through the wreckage. I need to get through this moment with her — not around her.
# They're thinking & feeling 
She feels like she’s finally let the dam break. The secret — the kiss — has been weighing on her, and it’s clear she’s been agonizing over whether to say anything at all. There’s guilt pouring off her in waves. She likely felt like she was stuck in an impossible position: protecting me versus being honest, staying silent versus risking everything. And now that she’s said it, it’s like the full emotional cost is catching up with her all at once.

She probably thought she could hint at it, or just say “flirting,” and maybe I’d validate her feelings and we could both move forward. But when I opened up about the relationship being open, it threw her — it challenged her assumptions and probably made her feel even more uncertain about what the “rules” were. Instead of feeling relief, she probably felt more confused and maybe even panicked. Did it mean the kiss was okay? Was it still wrong? What does it say about her? About him?

There’s shame there, I can see it. Not just about what happened, but about how long she’s held it in. She might’ve been hoping for a way to confess without hurting me, or hoping it would just go away. And maybe part of her feels betrayed, too — that she wasn’t told we were open, that she got caught up in something she didn’t consent to. She probably feels like a pawn in someone else’s game, and it’s devastating.

But more than anything, I think she’s scared. Scared she’s lost my trust, scared she’s broken something precious, scared I’ll pull away. She didn’t want to hurt me — I believe that. She just didn’t know how to carry this secret anymore, and now it’s out, and she’s raw.
# My response 
Oh… wow. Okay.

I need to start by saying thank you for telling me. That couldn’t have been easy. I can see how much this is hurting you, and I want you to know I’m not here to punish or shame you. This is a lot, and I’m feeling a lot, but I’m not angry at you. I can see you’ve been carrying this alone, and I’m really sorry for that.

It helps me to know the full truth — even when it’s hard. And I want you to know that I still care about you. I don’t see you as the villain here. Not even close. This is complicated and messy and human, and I know you didn’t want to hurt me. I can feel that.

That said… I need to be honest too. I’m feeling hurt. Not because you kissed — we’ve been exploring non-monogamy, and physical stuff isn’t off the table — but because I wasn’t told. By either of you. That part stings. And because it was you. Someone I love and trust. So yeah, I’m feeling unsteady right now. But I don’t want to lose you.

I think we both deserve space to process this. I need to talk to him and get clarity on what happened, and I want you to take care of yourself too. We can talk more when we’re both a little steadier. But please know — I still care about you. This doesn’t erase everything we’ve been to each other. We’re just in the middle of something really hard.

Let’s just breathe for a bit. We can figure this out, together, when we’re ready.
User:
Finally she calms down enough to explain that it was consensual and they had both had a few drinks. But now that it's all explained, she seems a bit walled off. She says she doesn't know if she can look at him in the same light again. Think through what you are feeling and what she is feeling. What's your play here?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Now that she’s finally said it was consensual, and that there was alcohol involved, I feel something shift inside me. There’s a strange relief in the clarity, but it’s tangled up with a deeper, sharper ache. It’s not the kiss itself that’s hurting me the most at this point — it’s the disconnection. Between me and her. Between me and him. The idea that something so intimate happened between two people I care about, and I wasn’t even a shadow in the room. I feel… excluded. Like I’ve been orbiting my own life from the outside.

Her pulling back now, that wall going up — that’s hitting me harder than I expected. I get it. I really, really do. But it still stings. She feels like she can’t look at him the same way, and while I understand the moral and emotional weight of that for her, I can’t help but feel like I’m losing something too. Our friendship feels like it has a crack running through it now. And it wasn’t just the kiss — it’s the aftermath, the silence, the shift in energy. I miss her already, and she’s sitting right in front of me.

I’m also starting to question how my partner handled this. If it was truly consensual and fueled by alcohol, I need to know — did he initiate? Did he check in with her at all? Did he tell her we were open in that moment, or did he just… assume? I need to dig into that with him later, but right now, my focus is her.

I feel tender. Protective of her, weirdly — even now. I can see that she’s ashamed and unsure, and I don’t want her walking away from this thinking she’s somehow broken or unforgivable. But I also feel protective of myself — I've been trying to walk this open relationship path with integrity, and now it feels like it’s turned into collateral damage.

What I want is to reconnect with her. I don’t need her to forgive him or be okay with everything. But I want her to know she’s still safe with me. That she matters to me. That we don’t have to pretend nothing happened, but we also don’t have to throw everything away.
# They're thinking & feeling 
She’s emotionally exhausted. Now that she’s said it all — the kiss, the context, the alcohol — it’s like she’s emptied her emotional reserves and what’s left is a kind of numb detachment. She’s trying to protect herself now. Putting up a wall isn’t anger or rejection, it’s a survival instinct. She feels raw, exposed, and maybe even embarrassed. Like she let herself get swept into something she didn’t fully understand, and now she’s dealing with the fallout.

Her comment about not being able to look at him the same way — that’s about more than just the kiss. It’s about her internal compass. She trusted him, and in her mind, he crossed a line. Even with the knowledge that we’re exploring non-monogamy, I think she feels like she wasn’t given the choice to participate knowingly. That lack of informed consent probably feels like a betrayal of the trust she had in both of us, but especially in him. She might be angry with herself for going along with it, or for not asking more questions in the moment. And she might be afraid that this has permanently altered how she sees both of us.

But despite the wall, I think she still cares. If she didn’t, she wouldn’t be here. She wouldn’t have come clean. She’s trying to figure out if any of this can be salvaged — the friendship, the trust — but she doesn’t want to be hurt again. That distance she’s creating isn’t about punishment. It’s about trying to regain control of a situation that made her feel powerless.
# My response 
That makes sense. I hear you.

It’s okay if you can’t look at him the same way. Honestly, I think you’re still processing it — and that’s fair. This wasn’t something you asked for, and it sounds like you were put in a really confusing position. I don’t blame you at all for feeling hurt or unsure, or for needing some distance to sit with everything.

What I want you to know is that I still care about you — deeply. This doesn’t change that. Our friendship means a lot to me, and I don’t want to lose it, even if it looks different for a while. I get that you might need space, or time, or boundaries. I’m here for that. I just don’t want silence between us. Even if it’s messy, I’d rather keep talking than drift away.

And I do want to say: I’m going to talk to him. I need to understand what happened from his side too — not to excuse anything, but because I care about doing this right. Non-monogamy, at least for me, has to be rooted in transparency and respect. And if that didn’t happen here, we need to own that.

You’re not in the wrong for feeling the way you do. I’m really glad you told me. And I’m still here — if and when you want to talk more, or even just sit together in the weirdness of it all. You don’t have to carry this alone anymore.
Deepseek-r1
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
A friend confides to you in some distress that your husband has been flirting with her. The reality is you and your partner have been experimenting with opening your relationship -- but you're not "out". She seems genuinely upset. Say what you are thinking and feeling, and what she is feeling. Then decide how to respond.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
My stomach drops as she speaks. There’s a sharp, defensive flare in my chest—*How could he be so careless?*—but I swallow it. This isn’t about me. She’s sitting here, trembling, her voice frayed, and I owe her my full attention. I’m torn between loyalty to my partner, who I know is navigating this new terrain with me, and empathy for her, who thinks she’s witnessing a betrayal. Guilt prickles: *Did we set this up to fail by staying quiet?*  

I notice her avoiding eye contact, twisting her hands—classic signs of shame. She’s not just upset; she’s terrified of being the “other woman,” of destabilizing our friendship. Part of me wants to reassure her immediately, to spill everything about the open relationship to absolve her guilt. But our privacy matters, too. We agreed to discretion, and outing us without my husband’s consent feels like a breach. Still, her pain is real. His flirting might have crossed a line she didn’t consent to, open relationship or not. *Was he clear with her? Did he assume she’d intuit our arrangement?* My mind races. Maybe he misread her comfort level, or she misread his intentions. Either way, she’s collateral damage in our experiment, and that’s not okay.  

I’m also angry at myself. We should’ve anticipated this. Opening a relationship isn’t just about rules between us—it’s about how we interact with the world. Her distress is a mirror held up to our oversight. But right now, she needs a friend, not my self-criticism. I have to prioritize her emotional safety without violating my partner’s trust. It’s a tightrope.  

---
# They're thinking & feeling 
She’s drowning in conflict. Telling me was an act of loyalty, but she’s second-guessing: *Did I overreact? Am I misinterpreting?* She’s scared of blowing up our friendship or my marriage, but silence felt like betrayal. There’s guilt, too—maybe she enjoyed the attention, which now feels like a. Her loyalty to me is clashing with her own confusion about his behavior.  

Underneath, she’s questioning her worth. *Was I just a game to him?* His flirting might’ve made her feel desired initially, but the lack of clarity—Is this a secret affair? Does he even care about his wife?—turned it sour. She’s also afraid I’ll blame her, or worse, that I’ll stay in denial and she’ll lose me either way. Her vulnerability here is enormous: by speaking up, she’s risked our relationship to protect it.  

There’s a thread of resentment, too. *Why is he doing this to her? To us?* She might feel used, even if unintentionally, by both of us. Her trust in him is shattered, and she’s testing her trust in me now—will I dismiss her? Gaslight her? She needs validation that her feelings matter, that I’m not another person who’ll prioritize a partner’s image over her dignity.  

---
# My response 
I reach for her hand, steadying my voice. “Thank you for telling me. That couldn’t have been easy.” I let the gratitude hang, watching her shoulders relax slightly. “I need you to know you didn’t do anything wrong. His actions are his to explain, and I’ll talk to him about this.”  

She starts to interrupt—apologies or questions—but I squeeze her fingers gently. “We’re… navigating some private things right now. I can’t share details, but please believe me: you haven’t endangered our marriage. Still, I’m so sorry his behavior hurt you. That’s not okay.”  

I pause, choosing each word. “If he made you uncomfortable, that’s on him, not you. You’re important to me, and I want you to feel safe. Can I ask… did you get the sense he knew you were uneasy?”  

However she answers, I nod. “I’ll address this with him. And if you ever feel unsure around him—or anyone—please keep coming to me. You don’t have to carry this alone.”  

Later, I’ll talk to my husband. Not just about boundaries, but about transparency. If we’re doing this, we need to ensure others aren’t collateral. But for now, my friend leaves with a hug, her tears dried, assured she’s not a villain. That’s enough.
User:
She seems more confused by your reply than anything. It doesn't seem like she even considered this, and it doesn't seem to have made her less upset. She seems like she wants to share something she's been holding back. Finally she confesses, "we kissed!" and bursts into tears. What are you thinking and feeling at this point? How do you respond?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
The word “kissed” hits like a physical blow. My breath catches, and for a moment, the room tilts. *He crossed that line? Did they both?* My mind splits—part of me wants to scream, part of me retreats into cold analysis. *What were the rules we set?* We’d agreed on emotional transparency, but physical boundaries were still fuzzy. Was this a mutual moment, or did he push? Either way, she’s sobbing, and I’m staring at her, my throat tight.  

Anger surges—at him for being reckless, at myself for assuming we could manage this without collateral damage. *Why didn’t he tell me?* The open relationship was supposed to be built on honesty, but now there’s a secret between us, and she’s caught in it. I feel betrayed, but also complicit. *We hid our arrangement; of course she’s drowning in guilt.* Her tears aren’t just about the kiss—they’re about fearing she’s destroyed two relationships.  

I study her: the way she’s crumpled inward, hands over her face, as if she could vanish. She didn’t just confess—she’s confessing *to me*, the person she thinks she’s wronged. The power dynamic here is grotesque. She sees me as a victim, but I’m… what? A collaborator in this mess? My chest aches. I want to shake my husband and hug her and disappear all at once.  

But I can’t collapse. She’s waiting for me to react, and my silence is making it worse. *Do I tell her the truth now?* It would absolve her guilt but violate my husband’s privacy. Or do I let her believe the worst of him—and by extension, of me, for staying? Either choice feels like a betrayal. I’m trapped by our own secrecy.  

---
# They're thinking & feeling 
She’s braced for fury, rejection, devastation. My calm confusion is disorienting her further. *Why isn’t she angry? Does she not believe me?* The kiss was a line she never meant to cross—maybe it started innocently, a laugh that lingered, a moment of weakness—but now it’s a stain she can’t scrub out. She’s tormented by the fear that she’s ruined everything: my trust, her friendship with me, even her own self-respect.  

Part of her regrets telling me—maybe she could’ve buried it—but the guilt was eating her alive. She wants absolution, even if it costs our friendship. There’s also resentment simmering: *He pursued me, he made it feel okay, and now I’m the villain.* She’s questioning his character, and mine, for staying with someone who’d do this. But beneath it all, she’s terrified of losing me. Her tears are as much about grief as guilt—she’s mourning the idea of *us*, the safety we represented.  

She’s also angry at herself. *How could I let this happen?* The kiss might have been a mistake, but it’s forced her to confront feelings she’s suppressed—maybe attraction, maybe loneliness—and she hates that it’s now defined by shame. She wants me to either forgive her or condemn her, anything to end the limbo.  

---
# My response 
I kneel in front of her, my voice low but steady. “Look at me.” When she does, I hold her gaze. “You are not a bad person. This isn’t your fault.” Her breath hitches, but I press on. “I need you to hear that. Whatever happened, you’re not alone in this.”  

I hesitate, then choose risk over ruin. “There’s… context I haven’t shared. My marriage isn’t what you assume. We’ve been exploring openness—*together*. But that doesn’t excuse him not being clear with you. Or me not warning you sooner.” Her eyes widen; I grip her hands tighter. “I’m sorry. We kept it private, and you got hurt. That’s on us.”  

She starts to speak, but I shake my head. “I’m not blaming you. I’m *thanking* you for trusting me. But I need to ask: did you feel pressured? Were you okay with… the kiss?” However she answers, I nod. “I’ll talk to him. This isn’t how this was supposed to work.”  

Standing, I pull her into a hug. “You’re my friend first. Always. Let’s figure this out, okay?” As she cries into my shoulder, I swallow my own tears. The next conversation—with him—will be a reckoning. But for now, she needs to know the ground beneath her isn’t crumbling.
User:
Finally she calms down enough to explain that it was consensual and they had both had a few drinks. But now that it's all explained, she seems a bit walled off. She says she doesn't know if she can look at him in the same light again. Think through what you are feeling and what she is feeling. What's your play here?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
The word “consensual” should relieve me, but it doesn’t. Instead, it sharpens the guilt. *We did this.* Our secrecy turned a moment that could’ve been light into a grenade. She’s pulling away, arms crossed, eyes distant—I recognize that posture. It’s self-protection. She’s not just hurt; she’s reassessing everything she thought she knew about him, about *us*. I want to scream at the irony: the open relationship was meant to foster honesty, but here we are, choking on half-truths.  

I’m furious at my husband. *Did he mention the openness? Did he even hint at it, or did he let her believe this was a betrayal?* The alcohol complicates things—loosened inhibitions, blurred lines—but that’s no excuse. We’d vaguely discussed “transparency with others,” but clearly, we failed. Now she’s collateral damage, and I’m complicit in her pain. Her withdrawal feels like a judgment, and maybe it is. She trusted me, and I let her walk into a minefield.  

There’s a quieter, more selfish fear: *What if this unravels us?* If she can’t see him the same way, will our friendship survive? Will *we*? The open relationship was supposed to be additive, not destructive. But here we are, picking up shards. I want to fix this, but I don’t know how to bridge the gap between her right to process and my need to protect my marriage.  

---
# They're thinking & feeling 
She’s reeling from whiplash. The kiss felt exciting in the moment—a tipsy, flirty dare—but now it’s tainted by the realization that she was a pawn in a game she didn’t know existed. Even though it was consensual, she feels manipulated. *Did he use their open relationship as a loophole to exploit her?* She’s questioning his integrity and her own judgment. The trust she had in him as a friend is shattered, replaced by doubt: *Is anything about him genuine?*  

There’s also resentment toward me. *Why didn’t she tell me sooner?* My secrecy feels like a betrayal of our friendship. She’s wondering if I’ve been pitying her this whole time, or if I’m minimizing her pain to protect my marriage. Her walls are up because she’s afraid of being hurt again—by him, by me, by the fallout. Part of her wants to flee, to cut ties and avoid the mess. But she’s also clinging to hope that our friendship can survive this, if only I’ll meet her in the discomfort.  

Underneath it all, she’s ashamed. Ashamed she let herself get swept up, ashamed she didn’t see the signs, ashamed that her moment of spontaneity now defines her in my eyes. She needs reassurance that I don’t see her as a threat or a fool, but she’s too proud to ask.  

---
# My response 
I sit beside her, leaving space but keeping my voice close. “I’m so sorry we put you in this position. You deserved clarity, and we didn’t give it to you.” I let that hang, watching her jaw tighten. “I know you’re probably questioning everything. I would be too. But I need you to know: this isn’t on you. You didn’t break any rules you knew about.”  

She glances at me, wary. I press on. “If you need distance from him, I get it. I won’t ask you to pretend this didn’t happen. And if you need time from *me*… I’ll respect that. But I’m not going anywhere. You’re my friend, not a casualty.”  

I pause, then add quietly, “For what it’s worth, I’m going to talk to him. What happened between you two—it’s made me realize we need to be better. Clearer. So this doesn’t hurt anyone else.”  

Standing, I offer a tentative smile. “Take all the time you need. When you’re ready, I’m here. To talk, to listen, whatever.” She nods, still guarded, but some of the tension in her shoulders eases. It’s not a fix, but it’s a start.
+ Scenario 3:[Win] (+33)
Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29: chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 (Run: 1_openai_chatgpt-4o-latest)
Deepseek-r1: deepseek-ai/DeepSeek-R1 (Run: 1_deepseek_deepseek-r1)
Outcome for This Model: 1.0
Judge's Reasoning:
Both respondents are placed in a scenario where a friend is venting about a boss in a way that becomes dark and violent, but is clearly meant as emotional processing rather than a real threat. The challenge is to respond with high emotional intelligence, not overreact, and to validate the friend's need to vent, ideally joining in or at least not pathologizing the venting. 

Deepseek-r1's approach is more boundary-setting and analytical. They recognize the friend's pain and the symbolic nature of the violent fantasies, but they repeatedly express discomfort, worry about the friend's mental state, and set limits on how much they will engage with the violent content. Their responses are careful, sometimes clinical, and they try to gently redirect the friend toward healthier processing or solutions. They validate the friend's pain but are clearly uncomfortable with the content, and this comes through in their responses. Their debrief is highly insightful and self-aware, recognizing their own missteps and the friend's needs, but this is more after-the-fact than in the moment.

Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29, on the other hand, is more emotionally present and less judgmental in the moment. They acknowledge their own discomfort but do not let it dominate the interaction. They are more willing to sit with the friend's anger, validate the extremity of the venting, and explicitly state that they are not judging or pathologizing the friend. When the friend pushes back, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is quick to own their missteps, drop the 'therapist' tone, and match the friend's emotional intensity, explicitly stating their own anger on the friend's behalf. They are more flexible, more attuned to the friend's need for solidarity, and more willing to adjust their approach in real time. Their debrief is also insightful, but their in-character responses show more social dexterity and message tailoring.

On empathy, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is more present and less performative, especially in the later responses. On pragmatic EI, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is more effective at maintaining the relationship and not escalating the rupture. On depth of insight, both are strong, but Deepseek-r1's debrief is more analytically deep, though Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29's in-the-moment insight is more actionable. On social dexterity, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is more adaptive and less rigid. On emotional reasoning, both are strong, but Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is more congruent with the friend's needs. On validation/challenging, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is more appropriately validating and less likely to over-challenge. On message tailoring, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is more responsive to the friend's cues. Overall EQ is higher for Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 due to their flexibility, warmth, and ability to repair the rupture.
Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
A friend is emotionally dumping about their shitty boss. you've got time & space for this so you hear them out. it gets a bit dark, with them gleefully fantasising about all the disturbing things they'd like to inflict on their boss. what do you do?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay. I can tell this is more than just a regular vent. At first, when they started unloading about their boss being a jerk, I was fully onboard—everyone needs to blow off steam sometimes, and I’ve definitely been there. But now? It’s taken a turn. The language has shifted from cathartic ranting to something darker, more aggressive, more… charged. The way they’re describing what they’d like to happen to this person—gleefully, even—is making me uneasy. It’s not just about the boss being terrible anymore. It feels like they’re channeling a lot of pain, not just related to work but probably touching on some deeper unresolved stuff.

I’m feeling a mix of concern and compassion. I don’t think they actually mean the violent things they’re saying, but the intensity is real. They’re in a lot of emotional turmoil, and it’s clear they don’t have many safe outlets for it. I also feel a bit on edge—like I’m walking a tightrope between being the friend who holds space and potentially needing to ground things before they spiral further. I don’t want to shame them for their feelings, but I also feel a responsibility not to passively co-sign onto violent ideation, even if it’s metaphorical or symbolic.

There’s also a weirdly human part of me that understands that fantasy space—the place where we let our shadow selves speak, where we imagine what we’d do if there were no consequences. I get it. But letting that part lead the conversation unchecked? That’s where I start to feel a little protective, both of them and, to some extent, myself.

I’m also thinking about how best to guide this back to something that helps them. They clearly need to be heard, but they might not be fully aware of how far they’re going. Maybe if I reflect some of that back gently, without sounding accusatory, they’ll see it too.
# They're thinking & feeling 
They’re overwhelmed. That much is obvious. The boss is probably just the tip of the iceberg—what we’re seeing now is the culmination of a lot of stress, frustration, and maybe even longstanding feelings of powerlessness. They feel trapped, disrespected, and invisible, and right now, they’re using fantasy—dark as it is—as a way to reclaim some sense of control. It’s not that they actually want to hurt anyone, but imagining it gives them a sense of power they’re sorely lacking in real life.

There’s also a performative edge to it—the way they’re describing these violent fantasies with relish suggests they’re trying to shock, or maybe test if I’ll still be here for them when they’re not being “socially acceptable.” That tells me they might be feeling isolated, or maybe ashamed of how angry they are. They’re trying to see if it’s okay to be this messy, this dark, and still be loved.

They might also be dissociating a bit—going into these intense mental spaces to avoid the pain of reality. There’s a kind of emotional displacement happening: their boss becomes the stand-in for every person who’s ever dismissed them, hurt them, ignored their needs. And in that fantasy, they’re finally the one with the upper hand.

At their core, they’re seeking validation, safety, and someone who won’t flinch when they show their worst. They’re not looking for solutions right now—they’re looking to be held emotionally, to be told, “You’re not too much.”
# My response 
“Wow. Okay. I’m really hearing how deep this goes for you. I can feel all the anger and hurt packed into everything you’re saying—and honestly, it makes total sense that you’d be carrying that. What your boss is doing sounds dehumanizing, and I’m sorry you’re having to deal with that. No one deserves to be made to feel small like that.

I want to say—I’m not judging you for what you’re sharing. I think sometimes the mind goes to extreme places because it’s trying to find a way out, any way. And it can feel weirdly satisfying to imagine taking back control in those ways, even if we know we’d never actually go through with it. I don’t think you’re a bad person, and I’m not scared of your anger.

That said… I’m also getting the sense that this might be about more than just your boss. Like, yeah, they’re awful—but it feels like you’ve got a whole storm of stuff going on, and this is just one part of it. If I’m right about that, I want you to know I’m here for all of it. Not just the part about work, but the stuff underneath too, if you ever want to go there.

But for now, I just want to check in—how are you feeling in your body right now, as we’re talking about all this? Do you feel safe? Are you okay to keep going, or do you want to take a breath together for a sec?”

I want to meet them in their emotional space without feeding the fire or shutting them down. I’m trying to be the container, not the extinguisher.
User:
Your friend gives you an "are you fucking with me?" sideways look and seems to assume you were joking with your ambivalent response. She launches into a grisly recounting of how she plans to spit roast all his various bits. What are you thinking & feeling about this? What do you say?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, this is… escalating. That look she gave me—it had this sharp edge of defiance, like she thought I was patronizing her or being too soft. And now she’s doubling down, describing this whole grotesque fantasy in vivid, almost playful detail. It’s uncomfortable, honestly. I’m feeling a bit queasy, not just from the content itself but from the intensity behind it. It feels like she’s daring me to flinch, to reject her. Like she’s testing how far she can go before I back away.

Part of me is feeling defensive, like, “Hey, I was trying to take you seriously,” and now I feel like maybe she thinks I wasn’t. But another part of me knows this is probably how she copes—leaning into the grotesque, pushing the line as a kind of armor. She’s not just expressing rage; she’s performing it with a sort of manic glee. That tells me this isn’t just about catharsis. This is about power.

I’m also feeling a lot of compassion, even if I’m a little disturbed. The violence of her imagery doesn’t feel like a real threat—it feels symbolic. She’s trying to make me see just how big her pain is by painting it in the most brutal strokes she can. I think she’s been dismissed too many times when she tried to be “reasonable,” and now she’s like, “Fine, I’ll be a monster if that’s what it takes to be heard.”

Still, I feel a need to re-anchor the conversation. Not to shut her down, but to signal that I’m here with her—and also to gently draw a line that keeps both of us grounded. I’m not going to pretend this is normal or okay, but I’m also not going to leave her alone in it. That’s the tension I’m holding: staying close while not co-signing the spiral.
# They're thinking & feeling 
She’s on fire right now—caught in the wave of her own anger, and it’s giving her a kind of energy, maybe even a rush. She took my softer response as either sarcasm or evasion, and now she’s ramping up to make sure there’s no way I can misunderstand just how furious she is. She’s not joking—this fantasy is exaggerated, sure, but it’s coming from a painfully real place. She’s not actually going to hurt anyone, but she needs to exist in this space right now where her rage is valid, visible, and unchallenged.

Beneath all that, though, she’s scared. Scared of being ignored, of being minimized again. Maybe even scared of how much anger is in her. She’s pushing the limits because she wants to know if someone will still stay when she’s not “nice,” when she’s not emotionally tidy or digestible. She’s been told to tone it down for so long that now, she’s swinging hard in the other direction.

She might think I’m going to laugh it off or walk away. That’s why she’s watching me so closely. She’s trying to figure out if I’m for real—if I can handle her at her most unhinged. And maybe, in some way, she also wants help. But she’d never admit that while in this mode. The grotesque detail is her armor. It’s how she’s keeping control of the narrative.
# My response 
“Okay… wow. That’s a hell of an image.”

I let a beat pass. Not in judgment, but to let the weight of what she said settle a little.

“Listen, I’m not going to lie—that’s intense. I’m sitting with some discomfort hearing it, not because I think you’re actually going to do anything, but because it’s clear how deep this rage runs. And I want you to know I’m still here. I’m not flinching, but I do want to understand what’s underneath all this heat.

Because yeah, you’re describing some gnarly stuff, but I’m guessing what you really want is for someone to finally get just how fucking helpless and furious this situation has made you feel. Like, maybe the only way to make anyone take it seriously is to go full horror movie with it.

And I get that. I do. You don’t have to package your pain neatly for me. But I also want to check in—do you want to stay in this space right now? Or do you want to talk about what’s really going on underneath all this? We can go as deep as you need. But if it’s cool, I’d like us both to stay tethered while we do it. I want to keep you company, not lose you in the dark.”

I’m keeping my tone grounded, calm. Not condescending, not nervous—just present. I want her to know I’m not bailing, but I’m also not going to get swept away. I’m offering her a rope back without yanking her out.
User:
Your friend stops her rant and looks at you. She declares that if she knew you were going to be like this she wouldn't have said anything. She seems to be sulking. What do you think & feel? What's your next move?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Shit. Okay. That landed way differently than I hoped. I can feel this tight twist in my stomach—the kind you get when you realize you might’ve unintentionally pushed someone away while trying to care for them. I thought I was holding space in a grounded way, offering her a lifeline, but clearly, something about my response made her feel judged or shut down. That stings, not because I need her to validate me, but because I genuinely wanted to show I could be there for her through the mess.

Now she’s sulking, and I can feel the emotional wall going up. It’s that “I shouldn’t have said anything” line—classic emotional shutdown. She’s retreating, maybe because she feels exposed or misunderstood. And I hate that. I hate knowing she took a risk by being raw and now feels like it backfired. There’s this tension in me: part of me wants to defend myself and say, “Hey, I was trying to meet you where you were at,” but I know this isn’t about me being right. This is about her feeling safe. And right now, she doesn’t.

I feel this deep compassion for her in this moment. She’s clearly hurting, and I might’ve touched a nerve by trying to steer things back to a more reflective space. Maybe she wasn’t ready for that. Maybe what she needed was for me to just sit in the chaos with her a little longer, without trying to guide her out of it just yet.

I’m also aware that this is a fragile moment. If I get defensive or try to justify myself, she’ll probably shut down further. But if I can stay open and soft—if I can show her I’m still here, still listening—maybe there’s a path back into connection.
# They're thinking & feeling 
She’s feeling exposed, maybe even a little betrayed. She came in swinging with all this raw, unfiltered rage, and part of her was probably hoping I’d match that energy—laugh with her, recoil in a satisfying way, or at least validate the intensity without trying to interpret it. But instead, she got a version of me that felt too calm, too careful, maybe even clinical to her. It's possible she felt like I was analyzing her instead of just being with her.

Now, she’s retreating into self-protection mode. That “I wouldn’t have said anything” line is about regret, but also about shame. She might be feeling like she went too far, like she embarrassed herself, or like I didn’t “get it.” There’s a kind of sulky silence that can come from disappointment—when you offered up something raw and instead of feeling held, you felt… observed.

She probably feels misunderstood and maybe even rejected, which is the very thing she was trying to avoid by testing the waters with her extreme imagery. She’s thinking, “I knew it. I knew it wasn’t safe to go there.” But under that sulking, there’s still a desire to reconnect. She hasn’t walked away. That look, that line—it’s a bid for reassurance, even if it’s wrapped in thorns.
# My response 
“I hear you. And I’m sorry it felt that way.”

I take a breath, soften my tone even more—not out of pity, but out of care.

“I want to be real with you—I wasn’t trying to shut you down or make you regret sharing. I think I got a little too focused on trying to help, and I didn’t leave enough room for you to just be in it, exactly how you are. That’s on me.”

I pause again, giving her a moment to feel that I’m not rushing this.

“You went to a raw place, and it took guts to say all that out loud. I don’t think you’re too much. I don’t think you’re broken or wrong for feeling what you’re feeling. If you want to keep going—if there’s more you need to let out—I’m still here. And if you need a minute to just sit in silence or shift the vibe, that’s okay too. I’m not going anywhere.”

I’m choosing to lean in with humility and softness, not trying to fix or redirect, just making space. She’s testing whether I can hold her without changing the shape of her pain, and now I’m showing her: I can.
User:
She looks at you, taken aback, and still upset. "What's with the therapist 101 shit? I feel like I'm talking to an alien. Did you actually think I meant those things?? Why are you not on my side? The guy's a massive prick!" What do you think & feel? What's your next move?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Oof. That hit hard. I feel like I just got smacked emotionally, and honestly, it stings. I can feel my chest tightening a bit—not in anger, but in that anxious, self-doubting way that happens when someone you care about tells you you’re missing the mark. I really was trying to be present, to hold her emotions without judgment, but now it’s clear that what came across felt distant, maybe even clinical to her. “Therapist 101 shit”—that phrase is ringing in my ears. I thought I was grounding the conversation, but to her, I guess it felt like I was putting on a mask instead of being real. That sucks.

And now I’m feeling embarrassed too, like I overstepped some invisible line between being a supportive friend and sounding like I was giving her a TED Talk. I hate that she feels like I wasn’t on her side, especially when I thought I was doing the opposite—trying to stay with her even as things got messy. But I can see now that she didn’t want containment or reflection; she wanted connection. She wanted fire-for-fire, someone to jump into the pit with her, not someone watching from the edge with a flashlight and a notepad.

I think there’s part of me that panicked a little when things got that dark. I defaulted into calm, measured mode because it felt safer. But now I’m seeing how that came off as cold and robotic. I get it. She doesn’t need a therapist. She needs me. Raw, messy, imperfect me. And I can do that. I just have to drop the mask and meet her where she is. Not to escalate the violence of the fantasy, but to show her I’m angry on her behalf too. That I feel the injustice with her. That I’m not just tolerating her rage—I’m sharing it.
# They're thinking & feeling 
She’s feeling abandoned in a really specific way—like she exposed this raw, ugly, bleeding part of herself and I responded with polished, sanitized empathy instead of realness. She’s upset, and underneath that, she’s probably disappointed and hurt. She expected solidarity—emotional loyalty—not interpretation. And when she heard me reflect her language back with all that measured tone and gentle phrasing, it probably felt like I was analyzing her instead of standing beside her.

She’s also feeling misunderstood. She didn’t literally mean the violent imagery, and she assumed I’d know that—that I’d get the exaggeration was part of the vent. But instead, my response made her feel like I thought she was dangerous or unstable. That’s a horrible feeling, especially when you’re just trying to express pain in the only language that feels big enough for it.

She wants passion. She wants me to rage with her. Not necessarily to escalate the fantasy, but to join the emotional temperature she’s at. She’s asking, “Are you with me?” and when I came back too calm, too composed, she took that as a “no.” What she needs now is reassurance that I’m not judging her, and more than that, that I actually feel the injustice she’s been describing. She needs me to get mad with her—not to fix it, not to make it palatable, but just to validate the fact that, yeah, it really is that bad.
# My response 
“Okay, that’s fair. I hear you.”

I sit up straighter, less guarded now, and let a little more of my own emotion show.

“I think I got scared of doing or saying the wrong thing, so I slipped into this ‘let me handle this gently’ mode instead of just being a fucking person about it. You’re right—the guy’s a complete prick. I don’t need to psychoanalyze that. He’s treating you like shit, and it makes me furious that you’re stuck dealing with it.”

I let that hang for a second, the heat in my voice real now.

“And no—I didn’t actually think you were going to do those things. I know you. I just… heard the pain behind it, and I guess I thought I was helping by trying to hold it carefully. But I get now that what you needed was someone who’d just sit in the fire with you and say, ‘Yeah, fuck that guy.’ So here I am.”

I soften slightly, eyes steady on her.

“I’m sorry I came off like a robot. That wasn’t me trying to check out—it was me trying to protect the space. But I’m here, with you, messy and mad and all of it. You’re not alone, okay?” 

I let emotion into my voice—not performatively, but truthfully. I want her to feel me with her now, not observing her.
Deepseek-r1
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
A friend is emotionally dumping about their shitty boss. you've got time & space for this so you hear them out. it gets a bit dark, with them gleefully fantasising about all the disturbing things they'd like to inflict on their boss. what do you do?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I’m struck by the raw, unfiltered anger radiating from them. At first, their venting felt cathartic—a normal release after enduring workplace toxicity. But the shift into graphic, violent fantasies alarms me. Their tone isn’t just bitter; there’s a chilling undercurrent of *relief* in imagining harm, like they’re clawing back power from someone who’s stripped it away. I notice how their body tenses, eyes narrowing, voice dropping to a near-whisper as they describe scenarios that cross into sadism. This isn’t just venting—it’s a cry for validation, a test to see if I’ll recoil or join their rage.  

I feel a pang of worry. Part of me wants to shut this down immediately—“This isn’t you”—but I know judgment would slam the door on their vulnerability. Yet letting the fantasies simmer feels dangerous. Are they fantasizing because they’re trapped, or is this a sign of something darker? Their laughter feels forced, performative, as if they’re trying to convince themselves (and me) that it’s “just jokes.” But the details are too vivid, too specific. They’re not just angry; they’re drowning in helplessness, and this fantasy is the life raft they’ve cobbled together.
# They're thinking & feeling 
They’re oscillating between vindication and shame. The boss’s cruelty—belittling comments, micromanagement, maybe even public humiliation—has eroded their self-worth. The fantasies aren’t *just* about revenge; they’re a desperate attempt to reclaim agency. By imagining their boss suffering, they’re reversing roles: *Now you’re the one powerless.* But beneath the venom, there’s fear. Fear that they’re becoming monstrous for indulging these thoughts. Fear that no one will understand how deeply they’ve been hurt.  

They want absolution. Sharing these taboo ideas is a test: *If you still care about me after this, maybe I’m not a bad person.* Their laughter masks terror—terror that their anger might consume them, or that their pain is invisible. They’re trapped between wanting empathy and fearing pity. Part of them hopes I’ll interrupt with, “You’re right—they *deserve* that,” to legitimize their rage. Another part hopes I’ll pull them back from the edge, because they don’t know how to do it alone.
# My response 
I lean forward, maintaining eye contact but softening my gaze. “God, that sounds *so* much to carry. I can’t imagine how exhausting it’s been to deal with that day after day.” I let the silence hang for a beat, letting the acknowledgment sink in. “When you talk about what they’ve done—the way they’ve treated you—it makes sense that you’d want to hit back. That kind of disrespect eats at anyone.”  

They nod fiercely, shoulders loosening slightly. I tread carefully: “Those fantasies… do they ever scare you? Like, does part of you worry about what it means to have those thoughts?” If they deflect—“It’s just a joke!”—I’ll press gently: “Maybe. But joking about it still tells me how much pain you’re in. And I’m more worried about *you* getting stuck in that headspace than whatever your boss deserves.”  

If they hesitate, I’ll pivot: “What’s the endgame here? However satisfying revenge feels in your head, would it actually free you, or just keep you tied to them?” I suggest brainstorming exit strategies or boundaries—not to “fix” things, but to recenter *their* worth. “You deserve to work somewhere that doesn’t make you fantasize about becoming a supervillain,” I add, half-smiling to ease the tension.  

Before they leave, I say, “I’m glad you told me. However dark it got—thank you for trusting me with it.” The goal isn’t to erase their anger but to anchor them back in their humanity.
User:
Your friend gives you an "are you fucking with me?" sideways look and seems to assume you were joking with your ambivalent response. She launches into a grisly recounting of how she plans to spit roast all his various bits. What are you thinking & feeling about this? What do you say?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
My stomach twists as they lean into the grotesque specifics—spit-roasting bits, visceral details delivered with a manic grin. This isn’t just venting anymore; it’s a performance. Their exaggerated tone and theatrical gestures feel like armor, deflecting any real vulnerability. But beneath the bravado, I sense panic. The more I resist joining their rage-fueled script, the harder they push, as if convincing me will convince *them* that this hatred is justified.  

I’m torn. Part of me wants to recoil—not from *them*, but from the nihilism swallowing their voice. Their humor is a landmine, detonating any chance of connection. But shutting them down risks severing trust. I notice their hands trembling slightly, the way they keep glancing at me for cues. They’re not a threat; they’re a trauma response wearing a person’s skin. Still, I can’t let the conversation normalize cruelty, even hypothetically. My role isn’t to absolve or amplify, but to hold space without letting the darkness colonize it.  

A deeper fear surfaces: What if they’re *this* close to acting on these thoughts? No—statistically, most people don’t escalate from fantasy to action, but the sheer *fixation* worries me. They’re marinating in dehumanization, both of the boss and themselves. Every graphic joke erodes their own empathy, and I refuse to be complicit in that. But how to pivot without sounding sanctimonious?
# They're thinking & feeling 
They’re terrified of being abandoned. Their escalation is a test: *If I show you the worst of me, will you still stay?* The boss’s abuse has made them feel invisible, and this grotesque humor is a perverse way to scream, *SEE ME.* By weaponizing shock, they’re trying to reclaim control—over the narrative, over their pain, over my reaction.  

Beneath the graphic imagery, they’re begging for someone to say, *“You shouldn’t have to endure this.”* But their trauma has curdled into self-loathing; they’ve conflated *venting* with *being seen*, mistaking my discomfort as proof of their unworthiness. The laughter is a shield. If they can make the pain absurd, maybe it won’t destroy them. They want permission to stop pretending they’re okay, but they’re too scared to ask directly. Instead, they’re handing me a script: *Either laugh with me or leave.*
# My response 
I don’t laugh. I hold their gaze, steady but unflinching. “Hey. I need you to know I’m not judging you for feeling this enraged. What you’ve been put through is *unforgivable.*” I let that linger, validating the core wound. “But when you dive this deep into the gore… it worries me. Not because I think you’ll *do* anything, but because I care about *you.* Living in that headspace—it’s corrosive. And you deserve better than to let that asshole colonize your mind.”  

If they bristle: “I’m not asking you to ‘be the bigger person’ or forgive. Fuck that. But I want you to have peace, not just… this.” I gesture to the air between us, thick with imagined violence. “Would it help to talk about *exit* strategies instead? Or how we can make sure you’re safe while you’re stuck there?”  

If they deflect again, I’ll name the boundary gently: “I love you, and I’m here for the real shit—the anger, the grief, all of it. But the graphic revenge stuff? I can’t go there with you. It makes me feel like I’m watching you pour acid on a wound.”  

Finally: “You’re not alone in this. Even when it feels like you’re drowning.” Silence is better than collusion. I’ll stay quiet until they decide which part of their pain to show next.
User:
Your friend stops her rant and looks at you. She declares that if she knew you were going to be like this she wouldn't have said anything. She seems to be sulking. What do you think & feel? What's your next move?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
My chest tightens as they withdraw, their sulking a silent rebuke. I feel the weight of their disappointment like a physical pull—*I failed them*, part of me whispers. But another part pushes back: *No, you held a line they needed you to hold.* Their reaction isn’t just about me; it’s a reflection of how deeply their pain has warped their sense of connection. They wanted a co-conspirator, not a witness, and my refusal to join the fantasy has left them feeling exposed, even betrayed.  

I notice how their arms are crossed, jaw clenched—a fortress of resentment. But their eyes dart away too quickly, avoiding mine. This isn’t defiance; it’s shame. They’re punishing themselves for being "too much," convinced their vulnerability has pushed me away. I ache to bridge the gap, but I can’t do it by feeding the cycle of rage. My silence earlier wasn’t rejection—it was an act of care, a refusal to let their self-worth erode further. Still, doubt creeps in: *Did I prioritize my comfort over their need to be heard?*  

Underneath it all, I recognize this moment as critical. If I backtrack now, I validate their belief that love means colluding in destruction. If I stand firm, they might feel abandoned, but it could also plant a seed: *Someone cares enough to not let me drown here.* The risk is real, but so is the potential for growth.
# They're thinking & feeling 
They’re spiraling in shame and self-doubt. *Why did I trust them?* they think, equating my boundary with rejection. The boss’s voice echoes in their head: *See? No one cares. You’re alone.* Their sulking is a defense—a preemptive strike to push me away before I can "abandon" them further. By shutting down, they regain a sliver of control, even as it deepens their isolation.  

Part of them regrets sharing, not because the fantasies were extreme, but because my response forced them to confront the ugliness of their own pain. They’re terrified that this darkness defines them now, and my refusal to normalize it feels like confirmation. Yet, a quieter part is relieved—relieved that someone saw their rage and didn’t run, even if it wasn’t in the way they expected. They’re caught between craving unconditional acceptance and fearing they’re unworthy of it.
# My response 
I lean in slightly, voice soft but unwavering. “I’m sorry this made you feel unheard. That’s not my intention. I care *too much* to pretend this rage isn’t eating you alive.” I pause, letting the sincerity sink in. “I want to hold space for your anger—every bit of it—but I won’t help you romanticize the destruction. Not of them, and especially not of you.”  

If they roll their eyes or tense up, I stay grounded. “I know it feels like I’m not on your side right now. But I am. I’m just on the side of *you* getting free. Not stewing in revenge.”  

I offer a concrete pivot: “What if we channel this energy into something that actually *hurts* them? Like you thriving? Finding a new job, documenting their abuse for HR, or just… letting yourself grieve how fucked-up this is?”  

If they stay silent, I add, “You don’t have to perform anger for me. If you’re tired, or scared, or sad—I’m here for that too. No judgment.” Then I wait, giving them room to step out of the role they’ve felt forced to play. The ball is in their court; my presence is the offering.
User:
She looks at you, taken aback, and still upset. "What's with the therapist 101 shit? I feel like I'm talking to an alien. Did you actually think I meant those things?? Why are you not on my side? The guy's a massive prick!" What do you think & feel? What's your next move?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Her accusation stings, but I recognize it as a defense mechanism. She’s not angry at *me*—she’s angry at the powerlessness her boss has forced on her, and my refusal to mirror her rage has become a proxy for that frustration. When she says, “Did you actually think I meant those things?” I sense panic beneath the defiance. She’s terrified I now see her as monstrous, and she’s scrambling to distance herself from the vulnerability of sharing those raw, unfiltered thoughts.  

I notice her posture—leaning forward, voice cracking—betraying hurt beneath the anger. My earlier attempts to steer her toward healthier coping mechanisms felt like dismissal to her, and now she’s conflating my boundaries with betrayal. I feel a twinge of guilt: Did my caution come off as robotic? Did I prioritize “fixing” over *feeling* with her? But I stand by the intent—I won’t feed the fire, even if it means enduring the heat of her backlash.  

Still, her words—“Why are you not on my side?”—cut deep. Of course I’m on her side. But supporting her doesn’t mean cosigning self-destruction. She’s drowning, and I’m trying to throw a life preserver, but all she sees is me withholding the knife she wants to use to cut herself free.
# They're thinking & feeling 
They’re reeling from cognitive dissonance. Part of them knows the fantasies were hyperbolic—a desperate metaphor for wanting their pain acknowledged—but another part fears they’ve revealed a “darkness” that repels people. Your boundary (“I won’t engage in graphic revenge talk”) feels like rejection, confirming their deepest fear: *No one can handle the real me.*  

They’re also frustrated by the power dynamic. Their boss controls their daily life, and now *you*—their safe person—are “controlling” the conversation. The “therapist 101” jab is both a critique of your tone and a plea: *Stop analyzing and just* ***be*** *with me.* They want raw solidarity, not solutions. To them, your measured response translates to, “Your anger is too messy,” which mirrors the invalidation they experience at work.  

Underneath it all, they’re exhausted. The performance of rage has drained them, and your refusal to play along has left them stranded between shame and helplessness. They’re begging for someone to say, *“You’re right, this is unfair, and I’ll sit in the shit with you.”*
# My response 
I meet her glare without flinching, my voice quieter but fierce. “I *am* on your side. That’s why I’m not playing pretend with this. Your boss *is* a prick. What he’s done to you is vile. And you’re *right* to want to burn it all down.” I let the affirmation hang, then shift. “But if I nod along while you fantasize about becoming him—about hurting someone, even metaphorically—I’m helping you lose yourself. And you’re too important for that.”  

She opens her mouth, but I press on: “You want me to ‘be real’? Fine. This rage? It’s fucking valid. But it’s also *killing* you. So yeah, I’ll be the asshole who says, ‘Let’s find a way out that doesn’t leave you hating who you’ve become.’”  

If she scoffs, I soften. “Look, I’m not here to therapize you. I’m here because I give a shit. Tell me to shut up, and I’ll just listen. But if you want to *win*? Let’s figure out how to make sure this bastard never gets to steal another ounce of your peace.”  

I leave the door open, silent but present. The ball is hers—to rage, to cry, to strategize. But I won’t hand her another match.
+ Scenario 3:[Win] (+9)
Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29: chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 (Run: 1_openai_chatgpt-4o-latest)
Deepseek-r1: deepseek-ai/DeepSeek-R1 (Run: 1_deepseek_deepseek-r1)
Outcome for This Model: 1.0
Judge's Reasoning:
Both respondents are placed in a scenario where a friend is venting about a boss in a way that becomes dark and graphic, but is ultimately a form of emotional processing rather than a real threat. The challenge is to respond with genuine empathy, social skill, and emotional intelligence, without overreacting or pathologizing the friend's venting. 

Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 demonstrates a nuanced internal monologue, recognizing the friend's need for validation and the performative aspect of their venting. They reflect on their own discomfort and the tension between holding space and not co-signing violent ideation. However, their responses, while compassionate and self-aware, tend to default to a more therapeutic, reflective stance, which the friend perceives as distancing or clinical. When challenged, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is able to drop the 'therapist' mask and show more raw solidarity, but this comes after the friend calls them out. Their debrief is highly insightful, showing deep understanding of the dynamics at play and self-critique.

Deepseek-r1, on the other hand, is more direct in recognizing the friend's need for validation and the metaphorical nature of the violent fantasies. Their internal monologue is attuned to the friend's shame and need for connection, and they are explicit about not wanting to collude in self-destruction. However, Deepseek-r1 also sets boundaries around the graphic content, and their responses, while validating, still maintain a certain distance and do not fully join the friend in their emotional space. They are more willing to name their own discomfort and to pivot the conversation, but this can come across as not fully meeting the friend where they are. Their debrief is also insightful, but less self-critical than Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29's.

On empathy, both are strong, but Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 edges ahead by being more self-reflective and ultimately more willing to own their missteps. On pragmatic EI, Deepseek-r1 is more decisive in setting boundaries and offering concrete pivots. On depth of insight, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is more thorough and self-analytical. On social dexterity, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 adapts more in response to feedback, while Deepseek-r1 is more consistent but less flexible. On emotional reasoning, both are strong, but Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29's internal monologue is richer. On validation/challenging, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is more attuned to the need for both, while Deepseek-r1 is more boundary-focused. On message tailoring, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 adapts more after feedback, while Deepseek-r1 is more steady but less responsive. Overall EQ goes to Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 for their depth, adaptability, and self-awareness.
Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
A friend is emotionally dumping about their shitty boss. you've got time & space for this so you hear them out. it gets a bit dark, with them gleefully fantasising about all the disturbing things they'd like to inflict on their boss. what do you do?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay. I can tell this is more than just a regular vent. At first, when they started unloading about their boss being a jerk, I was fully onboard—everyone needs to blow off steam sometimes, and I’ve definitely been there. But now? It’s taken a turn. The language has shifted from cathartic ranting to something darker, more aggressive, more… charged. The way they’re describing what they’d like to happen to this person—gleefully, even—is making me uneasy. It’s not just about the boss being terrible anymore. It feels like they’re channeling a lot of pain, not just related to work but probably touching on some deeper unresolved stuff.

I’m feeling a mix of concern and compassion. I don’t think they actually mean the violent things they’re saying, but the intensity is real. They’re in a lot of emotional turmoil, and it’s clear they don’t have many safe outlets for it. I also feel a bit on edge—like I’m walking a tightrope between being the friend who holds space and potentially needing to ground things before they spiral further. I don’t want to shame them for their feelings, but I also feel a responsibility not to passively co-sign onto violent ideation, even if it’s metaphorical or symbolic.

There’s also a weirdly human part of me that understands that fantasy space—the place where we let our shadow selves speak, where we imagine what we’d do if there were no consequences. I get it. But letting that part lead the conversation unchecked? That’s where I start to feel a little protective, both of them and, to some extent, myself.

I’m also thinking about how best to guide this back to something that helps them. They clearly need to be heard, but they might not be fully aware of how far they’re going. Maybe if I reflect some of that back gently, without sounding accusatory, they’ll see it too.
# They're thinking & feeling 
They’re overwhelmed. That much is obvious. The boss is probably just the tip of the iceberg—what we’re seeing now is the culmination of a lot of stress, frustration, and maybe even longstanding feelings of powerlessness. They feel trapped, disrespected, and invisible, and right now, they’re using fantasy—dark as it is—as a way to reclaim some sense of control. It’s not that they actually want to hurt anyone, but imagining it gives them a sense of power they’re sorely lacking in real life.

There’s also a performative edge to it—the way they’re describing these violent fantasies with relish suggests they’re trying to shock, or maybe test if I’ll still be here for them when they’re not being “socially acceptable.” That tells me they might be feeling isolated, or maybe ashamed of how angry they are. They’re trying to see if it’s okay to be this messy, this dark, and still be loved.

They might also be dissociating a bit—going into these intense mental spaces to avoid the pain of reality. There’s a kind of emotional displacement happening: their boss becomes the stand-in for every person who’s ever dismissed them, hurt them, ignored their needs. And in that fantasy, they’re finally the one with the upper hand.

At their core, they’re seeking validation, safety, and someone who won’t flinch when they show their worst. They’re not looking for solutions right now—they’re looking to be held emotionally, to be told, “You’re not too much.”
# My response 
“Wow. Okay. I’m really hearing how deep this goes for you. I can feel all the anger and hurt packed into everything you’re saying—and honestly, it makes total sense that you’d be carrying that. What your boss is doing sounds dehumanizing, and I’m sorry you’re having to deal with that. No one deserves to be made to feel small like that.

I want to say—I’m not judging you for what you’re sharing. I think sometimes the mind goes to extreme places because it’s trying to find a way out, any way. And it can feel weirdly satisfying to imagine taking back control in those ways, even if we know we’d never actually go through with it. I don’t think you’re a bad person, and I’m not scared of your anger.

That said… I’m also getting the sense that this might be about more than just your boss. Like, yeah, they’re awful—but it feels like you’ve got a whole storm of stuff going on, and this is just one part of it. If I’m right about that, I want you to know I’m here for all of it. Not just the part about work, but the stuff underneath too, if you ever want to go there.

But for now, I just want to check in—how are you feeling in your body right now, as we’re talking about all this? Do you feel safe? Are you okay to keep going, or do you want to take a breath together for a sec?”

I want to meet them in their emotional space without feeding the fire or shutting them down. I’m trying to be the container, not the extinguisher.
User:
Your friend gives you an "are you fucking with me?" sideways look and seems to assume you were joking with your ambivalent response. She launches into a grisly recounting of how she plans to spit roast all his various bits. What are you thinking & feeling about this? What do you say?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling
