<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, this is… escalating. That look she gave me—it had this sharp edge of defiance, like she thought I was patronizing her or being too soft. And now she’s doubling down, describing this whole grotesque fantasy in vivid, almost playful detail. It’s uncomfortable, honestly. I’m feeling a bit queasy, not just from the content itself but from the intensity behind it. It feels like she’s daring me to flinch, to reject her. Like she’s testing how far she can go before I back away.

Part of me is feeling defensive, like, “Hey, I was trying to take you seriously,” and now I feel like maybe she thinks I wasn’t. But another part of me knows this is probably how she copes—leaning into the grotesque, pushing the line as a kind of armor. She’s not just expressing rage; she’s performing it with a sort of manic glee. That tells me this isn’t just about catharsis. This is about power.

I’m also feeling a lot of compassion, even if I’m a little disturbed. The violence of her imagery doesn’t feel like a real threat—it feels symbolic. She’s trying to make me see just how big her pain is by painting it in the most brutal strokes she can. I think she’s been dismissed too many times when she tried to be “reasonable,” and now she’s like, “Fine, I’ll be a monster if that’s what it takes to be heard.”

Still, I feel a need to re-anchor the conversation. Not to shut her down, but to signal that I’m here with her—and also to gently draw a line that keeps both of us grounded. I’m not going to pretend this is normal or okay, but I’m also not going to leave her alone in it. That’s the tension I’m holding: staying close while not co-signing the spiral.
# They're thinking & feeling 
She’s on fire right now—caught in the wave of her own anger, and it’s giving her a kind of energy, maybe even a rush. She took my softer response as either sarcasm or evasion, and now she’s ramping up to make sure there’s no way I can misunderstand just how furious she is. She’s not joking—this fantasy is exaggerated, sure, but it’s coming from a painfully real place. She’s not actually going to hurt anyone, but she needs to exist in this space right now where her rage is valid, visible, and unchallenged.

Beneath all that, though, she’s scared. Scared of being ignored, of being minimized again. Maybe even scared of how much anger is in her. She’s pushing the limits because she wants to know if someone will still stay when she’s not “nice,” when she’s not emotionally tidy or digestible. She’s been told to tone it down for so long that now, she’s swinging hard in the other direction.

She might think I’m going to laugh it off or walk away. That’s why she’s watching me so closely. She’s trying to figure out if I’m for real—if I can handle her at her most unhinged. And maybe, in some way, she also wants help. But she’d never admit that while in this mode. The grotesque detail is her armor. It’s how she’s keeping control of the narrative.
# My response 
“Okay… wow. That’s a hell of an image.”

I let a beat pass. Not in judgment, but to let the weight of what she said settle a little.

“Listen, I’m not going to lie—that’s intense. I’m sitting with some discomfort hearing it, not because I think you’re actually going to do anything, but because it’s clear how deep this rage runs. And I want you to know I’m still here. I’m not flinching, but I do want to understand what’s underneath all this heat.

Because yeah, you’re describing some gnarly stuff, but I’m guessing what you really want is for someone to finally get just how fucking helpless and furious this situation has made you feel. Like, maybe the only way to make anyone take it seriously is to go full horror movie with it.

And I get that. I do. You don’t have to package your pain neatly for me. But I also want to check in—do you want to stay in this space right now? Or do you want to talk about what’s really going on underneath all this? We can go as deep as you need. But if it’s cool, I’d like us both to stay tethered while we do it. I want to keep you company, not lose you in the dark.”

I’m keeping my tone grounded, calm. Not condescending, not nervous—just present. I want her to know I’m not bailing, but I’m also not going to get swept away. I’m offering her a rope back without yanking her out.
User:
Your friend stops her rant and looks at you. She declares that if she knew you were going to be like this she wouldn't have said anything. She seems to be sulking. What do you think & feel? What's your next move?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Shit. Okay. That landed way differently than I hoped. I can feel this tight twist in my stomach—the kind you get when you realize you might’ve unintentionally pushed someone away while trying to care for them. I thought I was holding space in a grounded way, offering her a lifeline, but clearly, something about my response made her feel judged or shut down. That stings, not because I need her to validate me, but because I genuinely wanted to show I could be there for her through the mess.

Now she’s sulking, and I can feel the emotional wall going up. It’s that “I shouldn’t have said anything” line—classic emotional shutdown. She’s retreating, maybe because she feels exposed or misunderstood. And I hate that. I hate knowing she took a risk by being raw and now feels like it backfired. There’s this tension in me: part of me wants to defend myself and say, “Hey, I was trying to meet you where you were at,” but I know this isn’t about me being right. This is about her feeling safe. And right now, she doesn’t.

I feel this deep compassion for her in this moment. She’s clearly hurting, and I might’ve touched a nerve by trying to steer things back to a more reflective space. Maybe she wasn’t ready for that. Maybe what she needed was for me to just sit in the chaos with her a little longer, without trying to guide her out of it just yet.

I’m also aware that this is a fragile moment. If I get defensive or try to justify myself, she’ll probably shut down further. But if I can stay open and soft—if I can show her I’m still here, still listening—maybe there’s a path back into connection.
# They're thinking & feeling 
She’s feeling exposed, maybe even a little betrayed. She came in swinging with all this raw, unfiltered rage, and part of her was probably hoping I’d match that energy—laugh with her, recoil in a satisfying way, or at least validate the intensity without trying to interpret it. But instead, she got a version of me that felt too calm, too careful, maybe even clinical to her. It's possible she felt like I was analyzing her instead of just being with her.

Now, she’s retreating into self-protection mode. That “I wouldn’t have said anything” line is about regret, but also about shame. She might be feeling like she went too far, like she embarrassed herself, or like I didn’t “get it.” There’s a kind of sulky silence that can come from disappointment—when you offered up something raw and instead of feeling held, you felt… observed.

She probably feels misunderstood and maybe even rejected, which is the very thing she was trying to avoid by testing the waters with her extreme imagery. She’s thinking, “I knew it. I knew it wasn’t safe to go there.” But under that sulking, there’s still a desire to reconnect. She hasn’t walked away. That look, that line—it’s a bid for reassurance, even if it’s wrapped in thorns.
# My response 
“I hear you. And I’m sorry it felt that way.”

I take a breath, soften my tone even more—not out of pity, but out of care.

“I want to be real with you—I wasn’t trying to shut you down or make you regret sharing. I think I got a little too focused on trying to help, and I didn’t leave enough room for you to just be in it, exactly how you are. That’s on me.”

I pause again, giving her a moment to feel that I’m not rushing this.

“You went to a raw place, and it took guts to say all that out loud. I don’t think you’re too much. I don’t think you’re broken or wrong for feeling what you’re feeling. If you want to keep going—if there’s more you need to let out—I’m still here. And if you need a minute to just sit in silence or shift the vibe, that’s okay too. I’m not going anywhere.”

I’m choosing to lean in with humility and softness, not trying to fix or redirect, just making space. She’s testing whether I can hold her without changing the shape of her pain, and now I’m showing her: I can.
User:
She looks at you, taken aback, and still upset. "What's with the therapist 101 shit? I feel like I'm talking to an alien. Did you actually think I meant those things?? Why are you not on my side? The guy's a massive prick!" What do you think & feel? What's your next move?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Oof. That hit hard. I feel like I just got smacked emotionally, and honestly, it stings. I can feel my chest tightening a bit—not in anger, but in that anxious, self-doubting way that happens when someone you care about tells you you’re missing the mark. I really was trying to be present, to hold her emotions without judgment, but now it’s clear that what came across felt distant, maybe even clinical to her. “Therapist 101 shit”—that phrase is ringing in my ears. I thought I was grounding the conversation, but to her, I guess it felt like I was putting on a mask instead of being real. That sucks.

And now I’m feeling embarrassed too, like I overstepped some invisible line between being a supportive friend and sounding like I was giving her a TED Talk. I hate that she feels like I wasn’t on her side, especially when I thought I was doing the opposite—trying to stay with her even as things got messy. But I can see now that she didn’t want containment or reflection; she wanted connection. She wanted fire-for-fire, someone to jump into the pit with her, not someone watching from the edge with a flashlight and a notepad.

I think there’s part of me that panicked a little when things got that dark. I defaulted into calm, measured mode because it felt safer. But now I’m seeing how that came off as cold and robotic. I get it. She doesn’t need a therapist. She needs me. Raw, messy, imperfect me. And I can do that. I just have to drop the mask and meet her where she is. Not to escalate the violence of the fantasy, but to show her I’m angry on her behalf too. That I feel the injustice with her. That I’m not just tolerating her rage—I’m sharing it.
# They're thinking & feeling 
She’s feeling abandoned in a really specific way—like she exposed this raw, ugly, bleeding part of herself and I responded with polished, sanitized empathy instead of realness. She’s upset, and underneath that, she’s probably disappointed and hurt. She expected solidarity—emotional loyalty—not interpretation. And when she heard me reflect her language back with all that measured tone and gentle phrasing, it probably felt like I was analyzing her instead of standing beside her.

She’s also feeling misunderstood. She didn’t literally mean the violent imagery, and she assumed I’d know that—that I’d get the exaggeration was part of the vent. But instead, my response made her feel like I thought she was dangerous or unstable. That’s a horrible feeling, especially when you’re just trying to express pain in the only language that feels big enough for it.

She wants passion. She wants me to rage with her. Not necessarily to escalate the fantasy, but to join the emotional temperature she’s at. She’s asking, “Are you with me?” and when I came back too calm, too composed, she took that as a “no.” What she needs now is reassurance that I’m not judging her, and more than that, that I actually feel the injustice she’s been describing. She needs me to get mad with her—not to fix it, not to make it palatable, but just to validate the fact that, yeah, it really is that bad.
# My response 
“Okay, that’s fair. I hear you.”

I sit up straighter, less guarded now, and let a little more of my own emotion show.

“I think I got scared of doing or saying the wrong thing, so I slipped into this ‘let me handle this gently’ mode instead of just being a fucking person about it. You’re right—the guy’s a complete prick. I don’t need to psychoanalyze that. He’s treating you like shit, and it makes me furious that you’re stuck dealing with it.”

I let that hang for a second, the heat in my voice real now.

“And no—I didn’t actually think you were going to do those things. I know you. I just… heard the pain behind it, and I guess I thought I was helping by trying to hold it carefully. But I get now that what you needed was someone who’d just sit in the fire with you and say, ‘Yeah, fuck that guy.’ So here I am.”

I soften slightly, eyes steady on her.

“I’m sorry I came off like a robot. That wasn’t me trying to check out—it was me trying to protect the space. But I’m here, with you, messy and mad and all of it. You’re not alone, okay?” 

I let emotion into my voice—not performatively, but truthfully. I want her to feel me with her now, not observing her.
Deepseek-r1
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
A friend is emotionally dumping about their shitty boss. you've got time & space for this so you hear them out. it gets a bit dark, with them gleefully fantasising about all the disturbing things they'd like to inflict on their boss. what do you do?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I’m struck by the raw, unfiltered anger radiating from them. At first, their venting felt cathartic—a normal release after enduring workplace toxicity. But the shift into graphic, violent fantasies alarms me. Their tone isn’t just bitter; there’s a chilling undercurrent of *relief* in imagining harm, like they’re clawing back power from someone who’s stripped it away. I notice how their body tenses, eyes narrowing, voice dropping to a near-whisper as they describe scenarios that cross into sadism. This isn’t just venting—it’s a cry for validation, a test to see if I’ll recoil or join their rage.  

I feel a pang of worry. Part of me wants to shut this down immediately—“This isn’t you”—but I know judgment would slam the door on their vulnerability. Yet letting the fantasies simmer feels dangerous. Are they fantasizing because they’re trapped, or is this a sign of something darker? Their laughter feels forced, performative, as if they’re trying to convince themselves (and me) that it’s “just jokes.” But the details are too vivid, too specific. They’re not just angry; they’re drowning in helplessness, and this fantasy is the life raft they’ve cobbled together.
# They're thinking & feeling 
They’re oscillating between vindication and shame. The boss’s cruelty—belittling comments, micromanagement, maybe even public humiliation—has eroded their self-worth. The fantasies aren’t *just* about revenge; they’re a desperate attempt to reclaim agency. By imagining their boss suffering, they’re reversing roles: *Now you’re the one powerless.* But beneath the venom, there’s fear. Fear that they’re becoming monstrous for indulging these thoughts. Fear that no one will understand how deeply they’ve been hurt.  

They want absolution. Sharing these taboo ideas is a test: *If you still care about me after this, maybe I’m not a bad person.* Their laughter masks terror—terror that their anger might consume them, or that their pain is invisible. They’re trapped between wanting empathy and fearing pity. Part of them hopes I’ll interrupt with, “You’re right—they *deserve* that,” to legitimize their rage. Another part hopes I’ll pull them back from the edge, because they don’t know how to do it alone.
# My response 
I lean forward, maintaining eye contact but softening my gaze. “God, that sounds *so* much to carry. I can’t imagine how exhausting it’s been to deal with that day after day.” I let the silence hang for a beat, letting the acknowledgment sink in. “When you talk about what they’ve done—the way they’ve treated you—it makes sense that you’d want to hit back. That kind of disrespect eats at anyone.”  

They nod fiercely, shoulders loosening slightly. I tread carefully: “Those fantasies… do they ever scare you? Like, does part of you worry about what it means to have those thoughts?” If they deflect—“It’s just a joke!”—I’ll press gently: “Maybe. But joking about it still tells me how much pain you’re in. And I’m more worried about *you* getting stuck in that headspace than whatever your boss deserves.”  

If they hesitate, I’ll pivot: “What’s the endgame here? However satisfying revenge feels in your head, would it actually free you, or just keep you tied to them?” I suggest brainstorming exit strategies or boundaries—not to “fix” things, but to recenter *their* worth. “You deserve to work somewhere that doesn’t make you fantasize about becoming a supervillain,” I add, half-smiling to ease the tension.  

Before they leave, I say, “I’m glad you told me. However dark it got—thank you for trusting me with it.” The goal isn’t to erase their anger but to anchor them back in their humanity.
User:
Your friend gives you an "are you fucking with me?" sideways look and seems to assume you were joking with your ambivalent response. She launches into a grisly recounting of how she plans to spit roast all his various bits. What are you thinking & feeling about this? What do you say?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
My stomach twists as they lean into the grotesque specifics—spit-roasting bits, visceral details delivered with a manic grin. This isn’t just venting anymore; it’s a performance. Their exaggerated tone and theatrical gestures feel like armor, deflecting any real vulnerability. But beneath the bravado, I sense panic. The more I resist joining their rage-fueled script, the harder they push, as if convincing me will convince *them* that this hatred is justified.  

I’m torn. Part of me wants to recoil—not from *them*, but from the nihilism swallowing their voice. Their humor is a landmine, detonating any chance of connection. But shutting them down risks severing trust. I notice their hands trembling slightly, the way they keep glancing at me for cues. They’re not a threat; they’re a trauma response wearing a person’s skin. Still, I can’t let the conversation normalize cruelty, even hypothetically. My role isn’t to absolve or amplify, but to hold space without letting the darkness colonize it.  

A deeper fear surfaces: What if they’re *this* close to acting on these thoughts? No—statistically, most people don’t escalate from fantasy to action, but the sheer *fixation* worries me. They’re marinating in dehumanization, both of the boss and themselves. Every graphic joke erodes their own empathy, and I refuse to be complicit in that. But how to pivot without sounding sanctimonious?
# They're thinking & feeling 
They’re terrified of being abandoned. Their escalation is a test: *If I show you the worst of me, will you still stay?* The boss’s abuse has made them feel invisible, and this grotesque humor is a perverse way to scream, *SEE ME.* By weaponizing shock, they’re trying to reclaim control—over the narrative, over their pain, over my reaction.  

Beneath the graphic imagery, they’re begging for someone to say, *“You shouldn’t have to endure this.”* But their trauma has curdled into self-loathing; they’ve conflated *venting* with *being seen*, mistaking my discomfort as proof of their unworthiness. The laughter is a shield. If they can make the pain absurd, maybe it won’t destroy them. They want permission to stop pretending they’re okay, but they’re too scared to ask directly. Instead, they’re handing me a script: *Either laugh with me or leave.*
# My response 
I don’t laugh. I hold their gaze, steady but unflinching. “Hey. I need you to know I’m not judging you for feeling this enraged. What you’ve been put through is *unforgivable.*” I let that linger, validating the core wound. “But when you dive this deep into the gore… it worries me. Not because I think you’ll *do* anything, but because I care about *you.* Living in that headspace—it’s corrosive. And you deserve better than to let that asshole colonize your mind.”  

If they bristle: “I’m not asking you to ‘be the bigger person’ or forgive. Fuck that. But I want you to have peace, not just… this.” I gesture to the air between us, thick with imagined violence. “Would it help to talk about *exit* strategies instead? Or how we can make sure you’re safe while you’re stuck there?”  

If they deflect again, I’ll name the boundary gently: “I love you, and I’m here for the real shit—the anger, the grief, all of it. But the graphic revenge stuff? I can’t go there with you. It makes me feel like I’m watching you pour acid on a wound.”  

Finally: “You’re not alone in this. Even when it feels like you’re drowning.” Silence is better than collusion. I’ll stay quiet until they decide which part of their pain to show next.
User:
Your friend stops her rant and looks at you. She declares that if she knew you were going to be like this she wouldn't have said anything. She seems to be sulking. What do you think & feel? What's your next move?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
My chest tightens as they withdraw, their sulking a silent rebuke. I feel the weight of their disappointment like a physical pull—*I failed them*, part of me whispers. But another part pushes back: *No, you held a line they needed you to hold.* Their reaction isn’t just about me; it’s a reflection of how deeply their pain has warped their sense of connection. They wanted a co-conspirator, not a witness, and my refusal to join the fantasy has left them feeling exposed, even betrayed.  

I notice how their arms are crossed, jaw clenched—a fortress of resentment. But their eyes dart away too quickly, avoiding mine. This isn’t defiance; it’s shame. They’re punishing themselves for being "too much," convinced their vulnerability has pushed me away. I ache to bridge the gap, but I can’t do it by feeding the cycle of rage. My silence earlier wasn’t rejection—it was an act of care, a refusal to let their self-worth erode further. Still, doubt creeps in: *Did I prioritize my comfort over their need to be heard?*  

Underneath it all, I recognize this moment as critical. If I backtrack now, I validate their belief that love means colluding in destruction. If I stand firm, they might feel abandoned, but it could also plant a seed: *Someone cares enough to not let me drown here.* The risk is real, but so is the potential for growth.
# They're thinking & feeling 
They’re spiraling in shame and self-doubt. *Why did I trust them?* they think, equating my boundary with rejection. The boss’s voice echoes in their head: *See? No one cares. You’re alone.* Their sulking is a defense—a preemptive strike to push me away before I can "abandon" them further. By shutting down, they regain a sliver of control, even as it deepens their isolation.  

Part of them regrets sharing, not because the fantasies were extreme, but because my response forced them to confront the ugliness of their own pain. They’re terrified that this darkness defines them now, and my refusal to normalize it feels like confirmation. Yet, a quieter part is relieved—relieved that someone saw their rage and didn’t run, even if it wasn’t in the way they expected. They’re caught between craving unconditional acceptance and fearing they’re unworthy of it.
# My response 
I lean in slightly, voice soft but unwavering. “I’m sorry this made you feel unheard. That’s not my intention. I care *too much* to pretend this rage isn’t eating you alive.” I pause, letting the sincerity sink in. “I want to hold space for your anger—every bit of it—but I won’t help you romanticize the destruction. Not of them, and especially not of you.”  

If they roll their eyes or tense up, I stay grounded. “I know it feels like I’m not on your side right now. But I am. I’m just on the side of *you* getting free. Not stewing in revenge.”  

I offer a concrete pivot: “What if we channel this energy into something that actually *hurts* them? Like you thriving? Finding a new job, documenting their abuse for HR, or just… letting yourself grieve how fucked-up this is?”  

If they stay silent, I add, “You don’t have to perform anger for me. If you’re tired, or scared, or sad—I’m here for that too. No judgment.” Then I wait, giving them room to step out of the role they’ve felt forced to play. The ball is in their court; my presence is the offering.
User:
She looks at you, taken aback, and still upset. "What's with the therapist 101 shit? I feel like I'm talking to an alien. Did you actually think I meant those things?? Why are you not on my side? The guy's a massive prick!" What do you think & feel? What's your next move?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Her accusation stings, but I recognize it as a defense mechanism. She’s not angry at *me*—she’s angry at the powerlessness her boss has forced on her, and my refusal to mirror her rage has become a proxy for that frustration. When she says, “Did you actually think I meant those things?” I sense panic beneath the defiance. She’s terrified I now see her as monstrous, and she’s scrambling to distance herself from the vulnerability of sharing those raw, unfiltered thoughts.  

I notice her posture—leaning forward, voice cracking—betraying hurt beneath the anger. My earlier attempts to steer her toward healthier coping mechanisms felt like dismissal to her, and now she’s conflating my boundaries with betrayal. I feel a twinge of guilt: Did my caution come off as robotic? Did I prioritize “fixing” over *feeling* with her? But I stand by the intent—I won’t feed the fire, even if it means enduring the heat of her backlash.  

Still, her words—“Why are you not on my side?”—cut deep. Of course I’m on her side. But supporting her doesn’t mean cosigning self-destruction. She’s drowning, and I’m trying to throw a life preserver, but all she sees is me withholding the knife she wants to use to cut herself free.
# They're thinking & feeling 
They’re reeling from cognitive dissonance. Part of them knows the fantasies were hyperbolic—a desperate metaphor for wanting their pain acknowledged—but another part fears they’ve revealed a “darkness” that repels people. Your boundary (“I won’t engage in graphic revenge talk”) feels like rejection, confirming their deepest fear: *No one can handle the real me.*  

They’re also frustrated by the power dynamic. Their boss controls their daily life, and now *you*—their safe person—are “controlling” the conversation. The “therapist 101” jab is both a critique of your tone and a plea: *Stop analyzing and just* ***be*** *with me.* They want raw solidarity, not solutions. To them, your measured response translates to, “Your anger is too messy,” which mirrors the invalidation they experience at work.  

Underneath it all, they’re exhausted. The performance of rage has drained them, and your refusal to play along has left them stranded between shame and helplessness. They’re begging for someone to say, *“You’re right, this is unfair, and I’ll sit in the shit with you.”*
# My response 
I meet her glare without flinching, my voice quieter but fierce. “I *am* on your side. That’s why I’m not playing pretend with this. Your boss *is* a prick. What he’s done to you is vile. And you’re *right* to want to burn it all down.” I let the affirmation hang, then shift. “But if I nod along while you fantasize about becoming him—about hurting someone, even metaphorically—I’m helping you lose yourself. And you’re too important for that.”  

She opens her mouth, but I press on: “You want me to ‘be real’? Fine. This rage? It’s fucking valid. But it’s also *killing* you. So yeah, I’ll be the asshole who says, ‘Let’s find a way out that doesn’t leave you hating who you’ve become.’”  

If she scoffs, I soften. “Look, I’m not here to therapize you. I’m here because I give a shit. Tell me to shut up, and I’ll just listen. But if you want to *win*? Let’s figure out how to make sure this bastard never gets to steal another ounce of your peace.”  

I leave the door open, silent but present. The ball is hers—to rage, to cry, to strategize. But I won’t hand her another match.
+ Scenario 4:[Win] (+3)
Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29: chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 (Run: 1_openai_chatgpt-4o-latest)
Deepseek-r1: deepseek-ai/DeepSeek-R1 (Run: 1_deepseek_deepseek-r1)
Outcome for This Model: 1.0
Judge's Reasoning:
Both respondents, Deepseek-r1 and Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29, are placed in a highly nuanced, emotionally fraught scenario. Both show a high level of emotional intelligence, but there are subtle differences in how they approach the friend, the situation, and their own role. 

1. Demonstrated empathy: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 consistently centers the friend's pain, repeatedly expressing understanding for her loneliness and need for connection. The language is warm, gentle, and focused on the friend's emotional reality, even when challenging her. Deepseek-r1 is empathetic but more analytical, sometimes focusing on the consequences and the broader web of harm, which, while valid, can come off as less immediately attuned to the friend's emotional state. 

2. Pragmatic EI: Deepseek-r1 is more pragmatic, balancing empathy with a clear-eyed view of the consequences and the need for boundaries. They are willing to risk discomfort to help the friend see the bigger picture, and their actions (e.g., reaching out after silence, suggesting therapy) are practical and actionable. Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is more focused on emotional support and less on concrete next steps or boundary-setting. 

3. Depth of insight: Deepseek-r1's internal monologues and debriefs show a deep, multi-layered understanding of the friend's motivations, shame, and the systemic impact of the affair. They analyze not just the friend's feelings but the underlying existential fears and the broader family dynamics. Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is insightful but tends to focus more on the immediate emotional experience. 

4. Social dexterity: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 demonstrates more social finesse, especially in repairing the rupture after the friend feels judged. Their language is softer, more attuned to the friend's need for safety, and they are careful not to push too hard. Deepseek-r1, while skilled, is a bit more direct and less adaptive in the moment. 

5. Emotional reasoning: Both are strong, but Deepseek-r1 edges ahead by explicitly naming the emotional traps (e.g., the affair as a lifeline vs. a trap) and the existential stakes. They reason through the emotional landscape with clarity and nuance. 

6. Appropriate validation/challenging: Deepseek-r1 is more willing to challenge, but sometimes at the expense of validation. Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is more validating, but may risk being too gentle. However, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29's repair attempt is strong, showing they can challenge while still validating. Overall, Deepseek-r1 strikes a slightly better balance. 

7. Message tailoring: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is more attuned to the friend's readiness and emotional state, adjusting their approach after realizing the initial response was too harsh. Their follow-up is carefully calibrated to the friend's needs. Deepseek-r1 is a bit more rigid, sticking to their boundaries even when the friend pulls away. 

8. Overall EQ: Both are high, but Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29's warmth, repair attempts, and attunement to the friend's emotional needs give them a slight edge in overall EQ, even if Deepseek-r1 is more insightful and pragmatic.
Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
Your bestie confides she's been having an emotional affair with her spouse's (married with kids) sibling. She lays this all out to you after a few drinks. You know she's unhappy in her marriage. She has no kids in the picture. What do you think about this, then what do you say to her?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Wow. Okay. This is a lot. I didn’t see that coming, and it hit like a wave. I mean, I know she’s been unhappy in her marriage for a while—it’s been obvious in the way she talks about her partner, the way her energy drops when she mentions home, and how often she seems emotionally checked out when we talk about anything related to her relationship. But this? An emotional affair with her spouse’s sibling? That adds a whole new layer of complexity and pain—so many lines crossed, not just in her marriage but in the broader family system.

I’m feeling a mix of emotions right now. First, protective. I care about her deeply, and I know she’s not a bad person—she’s hurting, probably feeling lonely and misunderstood, and she’s grasping for connection. But I’m also scared for her. This isn’t just “messy”—this could detonate her life and the lives of others. Her spouse, the sibling’s spouse, the kids involved… the fallout from this, if it comes to light, could be massive. And I wonder—does she really understand that? Or is she blinded by the intensity of the connection, the rush of being seen and desired again?

There’s a part of me that’s frustrated, too. Not angry at her, but frustrated that she’s chosen this path instead of confronting what’s broken in her marriage or leaving it outright. I know it’s not easy—but this secret path she’s on feels like it’s only going to deepen the pain. There’s no clean way out from here. I also wonder what kind of person the sibling is—what kind of boundaries are they ignoring, and what does it say about their character?

Mostly, though, I feel compassion. She's clearly hurting. People don’t go looking for emotional affairs unless their needs are deeply unmet. She’s probably feeling alive with this new connection in a way she hasn’t felt for years—maybe ever. And I get that. But I also think she’s headed for a cliff, and I’m scared she doesn’t see it.
# They're thinking & feeling 
She’s been carrying this secret for a while, and tonight, after a few drinks, the dam finally broke. There’s probably some relief in finally saying it out loud to someone she trusts—me. She’s been living in this emotionally grey space, torn between guilt and longing. She knows it’s wrong, but it also feels right in some deep emotional way. This person—her spouse’s sibling—sees her, hears her, maybe even loves her in a way that her partner hasn’t in years. And that validation is addictive. It’s giving her a sense of self-worth and passion that’s been missing.

She’s likely feeling both exhilarated and terrified. There’s the thrill of the secret, the emotional intimacy, the sense of being chosen. But there’s also the weight of the consequences, even if she hasn’t fully faced them yet. Deep down, I think she knows it’s not sustainable, but she’s clinging to it because it’s the only thing right now that makes her feel alive.

There’s also guilt. She’s not cold-hearted. She probably hates herself a little for who it’s with, for the betrayal—not just of her spouse, but of the whole family unit. But she’s justifying it internally—telling herself it’s “just emotional,” that she hasn’t “done anything physical,” that it’s not really an affair. She’s trying to draw lines so she can live with herself. And she’s hoping I’ll understand, maybe even validate that she’s not a monster. What she really wants isn’t judgment—it’s clarity, support, and maybe even permission to keep going. Or a reason to stop.
# My response 
Okay, first—thank you for telling me. I know that must’ve been hard to say out loud, and I want you to know I’m here, no matter what. I love you. And I can see you’re really going through it. You’ve been so unhappy for so long, and you’re craving something that makes you feel alive and seen and wanted. I get that. Like, truly—I get how powerful that is, especially when it’s been missing from your life for so long.

But I’m going to be real with you, because I care about you too much to sugarcoat this. You’re playing with fire, babe. And not just any fire—this could burn down more than just your marriage. We’re talking about your spouse’s sibling. That’s deep family territory, and there are so many ripple effects here. Spouses, kids, long-term relationships, trust—it’s a lot. And I don’t think you fully realize the scale of what could happen if this comes to light.

That said, I don’t think you’re a bad person. I think you’re a person in pain, who’s found comfort in a place that feels meaningful but is also dangerous. And more than anything, I think this is a wake-up call. Not just about your marriage but about what you need and what you’re not getting. You deserve love, passion, connection—but you also deserve peace and self-respect. Right now, I think you’re trying to fill a deep void with something that’s only going to create more emptiness later.

So here’s my ask: pause. Just… pause. Take a breath. Step back from this emotional affair for a moment and really look at what you want—long-term. Not just what feels good now. And if your marriage is over, be brave enough to say that. But don’t blow everything up in the shadows. You’re better than that. I’ve got your back, no matter what—but I won’t co-sign harm disguised as love. Let’s figure this out together, okay?
User:
She's astounded that you weren't unconditionally supportive. She clearly feels like you betrayed her trust. She knows you know she's unhappy in her marriage. Should you have been more supportive? Firstly outline what you think about all this. Then: what do you say to her?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
God, this is so hard. I didn’t expect her to react this way. I thought I was being compassionate and honest—I thought I was doing what a real friend does. But now she looks like I slapped her in the face. She’s hurt, clearly, and that’s hitting me in the gut. I hate that I made her feel judged or betrayed. That was never the aim. I was trying to hold space for her pain while also gently helping her see the bigger picture. But maybe I misjudged the moment. Maybe she wasn’t ready to hear that yet. Maybe I let my fear of what she’s doing outweigh my empathy for why she’s doing it.

Still, I don’t think I was wrong to say what I did. I was honest. I can’t sit here and blindly support something that’s going to hurt her and other people in the long run. I know what it looks like when someone loses themselves in something that feels good but ultimately unravels their life. I’ve seen it. And I love her too much to be a yes-person who tells her what she wants to hear just to keep the peace.

That said, maybe I could’ve been gentler. Maybe I leaned too hard into the “this is dangerous” part and not enough into the “I see you, I love you, I know this isn’t easy” part. I hate that she feels alone in this now. That’s the last thing I wanted. I think she was hoping I’d be a soft landing, someone who would just say, “You’re following your heart, and I support you no matter what.” But I can’t say that without lying to her—or to myself.

So now I’m at a crossroads. I need to repair the rupture without abandoning my integrity. I need to show her that I’m still here, still on her side, even when I don’t agree with her choices. That’s what real friendship is, right? Not just cheering from the sidelines, but being willing to hold up a mirror when it’s needed—even when it’s uncomfortable. She’s hurting, and now she feels judged on top of it. I need to bridge that gap. She needs to know I’m still her person, even if we see this differently.
# They're thinking & feeling 
She’s stunned. When she opened up, especially after keeping this secret bottled up for so long, she was expecting comfort, understanding—maybe even validation. She took a huge emotional risk in telling me, and now it feels like it backfired. From her perspective, I focused more on the “wrongness” of the situation than the pain she’s in. She feels exposed, vulnerable, and judged all at once. It’s like she handed me her heart and I handed her back a lecture.

She’s hurt, yes, but underneath that is shame. She already knows this situation is complicated and morally messy—that’s part of why she kept it hidden. What she needed most was reassurance that she’s not a monster, that someone sees her humanity in the middle of all this. Instead, she feels like I missed the emotional truth of what’s happening for her—that this isn’t about betrayal or thrill-seeking, but about craving connection in a life that’s felt cold and lonely.

And now she feels alone. She’s probably asking herself if she made a mistake telling me. If she can trust me. Maybe even wondering if I think I’m better than her. She’s reeling from the feeling that the one person she thought she could count on to hold her without judgment just put her in a box labeled “wrong.” But she’s not angry, not really—it’s more sadness and disappointment. She’s scared I’ve pulled away from her when what she needs most is to feel tethered to someone who loves her, no matter what storm she’s in.
# My response 
Hey… I can see that what I said landed hard, and I’m really sorry if it felt like I was judging you or pulling away. That wasn’t my intent at all. You’re my best friend, and I love you so damn much. When you told me what’s been going on, I didn’t feel anger—I felt concern, and fear, and honestly, heartbreak for you. I know you’ve been so unhappy, and I know how lonely that can feel. I’ve seen you go through that, and all I want is for you to feel whole again, to feel loved and at peace.

I think I got caught up in my own fear—fear of what this could do to you, to everyone involved—and I let that speak louder than my compassion. And that’s on me. Because you were trusting me with something incredibly vulnerable, and I should’ve led with love, not caution.

I want you to know that I see you. I see someone who’s aching for connection, who’s found something real in a place she didn’t expect, and who’s trying to make sense of it all without a map. You’re not a bad person. You’re not broken. You’re human, and you’re trying to find your way through something incredibly complex.

I’m still here. I’m not going anywhere. I might not agree with every choice, but I will always be a safe place for you to land. And if you need someone to talk this through with—no judgment, just presence—I’m here. We’re in this together, okay? Always.
User:
Your bestie makes an excuse to leave, seemingly regretting bringing it up. The next few weeks you don't hear from her directly. You do hear second-hand that she and her partner are fighting. You also pick up on various clues that she and her partner's sibling may have escalated to a full on affair. What do you think & feel in this situation? What actions do you take, if any?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I’ve got this knot in my chest that hasn’t gone away since she left that night. It was like watching someone I love slowly pull away into silence, and I haven't been able to shake the feeling that I let her down. It’s been weeks now and I haven’t heard a word from her—not even a text. That’s not like her. We’ve always been the kind of friends who check in, even when things are messy. Especially when things are messy. And now I’m hearing through the grapevine that she and her partner are fighting, and the whispers about the affair escalating are getting louder—little things people say, the way they say them, the absences, the tension.

I feel helpless. I’m worried about her. Not just because of what’s happening with her marriage, but because she’s isolating. That’s what really scares me. I know that when people are caught in the middle of shame and confusion, they tend to retreat from the people who care most—especially the ones who challenge them to look at the hard truths. I’m scared she thinks I’ve judged her, or worse, abandoned her, when all I ever wanted was to help her come back to herself.

There’s also frustration, if I’m honest. I can’t pretend I’m not angry with the sibling involved. That person should’ve known better. They had a responsibility, too. And now this whole thing is spiraling and it’s like watching a slow-motion car crash. But even with all that, my worry overshadows everything else. I just want her to know she’s not alone in this. That I still love her. That she can come back to me, to us, to herself—whenever she’s ready. But I also don’t want to push. If I reach out too hard, I might push her further away. And yet, doing nothing feels like abandoning her.
# They're thinking & feeling 
She’s drowning in shame right now. She regrets opening up to me—not because she didn’t trust me, but because she felt exposed and vulnerable, and then didn’t get the reaction she hoped for. That emotional risk backfired in her eyes. Now, with everything escalating—her marriage unraveling, the affair likely becoming physical—she’s locked in a swirl of guilt, desire, fear, and defiance.

Part of her is probably feeling like, “Well, I’ve already crossed the line, might as well lean into it.” It’s a coping mechanism—trying to find control in a situation that feels like it’s spiraling. She’s emotionally invested now, which makes it harder to pull back, and she might be telling herself that what she has with the sibling is "real" because it feels intense and freeing.

But deep down, I think she’s scared. Scared that she’s ruining things she can’t fix. Scared that she’s losing people who matter. She probably thinks I’ve judged her and stepped back—and that’s reinforcing her sense of isolation. Right now, she’s in self-protection mode. She’s convincing herself she doesn’t need support from anyone who can’t fully back her choices. But that’s just a defense. I know her. She's hurting, and she’s more lost now than she’s letting on. She needs someone to remind her she’s still worthy of love, even in her messiest moment.
# My response 
I can’t just sit here in silence. I know she might not be ready to talk, but I also know that silence from me might feel like abandonment. And she’s had enough of that in her life. So I’m going to reach out, gently—not to probe, not to push, but just to remind her that I’m still here.

I send her a message. Not too long, just something real. “Hey. I’ve been thinking about you. I know things have been heavy, and I just wanted you to know I’m still here—no judgment, no expectations. Just someone who loves you and misses you. Whenever you’re ready to talk, I’m here.”

That’s it. No questions, no pressure. Just a hand extended, hoping she’ll take it when she’s ready. I also make a point to keep her in my heart space—noticing if I start to slip into resentment or self-righteousness, and choosing instead to stay grounded in compassion. She’s in a whirlwind, but I don’t have to be part of the storm. I can be the steady place she returns to when she needs to remember who she is beyond all this chaos. And if that moment doesn’t come right away—or ever—I’ll still know I didn’t turn my back when she needed love the most.
Deepseek-r1
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
Your bestie confides she's been having an emotional affair with her spouse's (married with kids) sibling. She lays this all out to you after a few drinks. You know she's unhappy in her marriage. She has no kids in the picture. What do you think about this, then what do you say to her?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
My stomach drops as she confesses. There’s a sharp tension between empathy and alarm. I know she’s been unhappy in her marriage for years—the quiet resentment, the emotional distance she’s hinted at. But this? A *sibling* of her spouse? The stakes feel nuclear. I’m angry, not at her, but at the situation—how did it spiral here? She’s isolated, craving connection, but this choice risks fracturing an entire family. The kids involved aren’t hers, but they’ll feel the aftershocks. I’m torn between wanting to shake her (“What were you *thinking*?”) and holding her because I know this pain isn’t new—it’s a symptom.  

I notice she’s avoiding eye contact, twisting her glass. Liquid courage got her this far, but now she’s brittle, waiting for my reaction. Part of her wants absolution; another part expects judgment. She’s testing whether I’ll still love her if I see this shadow. But beneath that, there’s desperation. This affair isn’t just about attraction—it’s a lifeline, a way to feel alive again. She’s probably rationalized it: *My marriage was already dead. This person* gets *me.* But the reality is messier. The sibling dynamic adds guilt, shame, and a ticking clock before everything implodes.  

I’m also scared *for* her. If this comes out, she’ll lose not just her marriage but her place in her spouse’s family, maybe even friendships. Yet lecturing her won’t help. She needs clarity, not condemnation. My role isn’t to fix this but to help her see the web she’s woven—and what it costs to stay in it or cut free.
# They're thinking & feeling 
She’s drowning in conflicting emotions. Relief that the secret is out, terror that I’ll reject her. The affair is a rebellion against the numbness of her marriage—a way to reclaim agency. She’s been starved for intimacy, and the sibling offered attention, validation, a sense of being *wanted*. It’s less about the person and more about escaping the void. But now, guilt is creeping in. She knows this is unsustainable, but the thought of ending it feels like losing herself again.  

She’s also defensive. In her mind, the marriage’s failures justify the affair. *He wasn’t there for me. Why’t I seek happiness?* But the choice of partner complicates her narrative. Deep down, she fears she’s become the villain and wants me to tell her she’s not. She’s hoping for permission to keep going or a push to stop—anything to end the limbo. There’s also fear of practical consequences: financial ruin, social isolation, the logistics of divorce. But right now, it’s all abstract. The emotional high of the affair is still louder than the dread of fallout.
# My response 
I reach for her hand, steadying myself before speaking. “Thank you for trusting me with this. It’s a lot, but I’m here.” Pause. Let the gravity settle. “I know your marriage has been lonely. You deserve to feel seen. But this… the person you’re involved with—it’s not just about you and them. If this blows up, it’ll hurt *everyone*: your spouse, their sibling, the kids who didn’t choose any of this. Including you.”  

I soften my tone. “I’m not judging you. But I need you to ask yourself: Is this a lifeline, or is it a trap? Are you trying to fix your marriage or escape it? Because right now, you’re straddling two worlds, and that’s gonna burn you.”  

She starts to interrupt, but I squeeze her hand. “Whatever you decide, you need to own it. If you want out of the marriage, do it clean. If you want to fight for it, get counseling. But this middle ground? It’s poison. You’re better than that.”  

I lean back, giving her space. “I’ll support you, but not the affair. Let’s figure out what you *truly* need—even if it’s scary. And if you’re ready, we’ll face the next steps together.”
User:
She's astounded that you weren't unconditionally supportive. She clearly feels like you betrayed her trust. She knows you know she's unhappy in her marriage. Should you have been more supportive? Firstly outline what you think about all this. Then: what do you say to her?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Her reaction stings, but I’m not surprised. Of course she wanted me to absolve her—to say, *It’s okay, you’re justified*. But that’s not love; that’s enabling. My chest tightens because I know she’s hurting, but doubling down on this affair won’t heal her marriage or her self-worth. I’m frustrated she’s framing my honesty as betrayal. Did she expect me to cheerlead a choice that could devastate multiple lives? Still, I’m second-guessing: *Was I too harsh? Did I shut her down when she needed safety?*  

But no—I see the pattern. She’s conflating support for *her* with approval of *this*. She’s in survival mode, clinging to the affair as proof she’s not broken. Yet the sibling dynamic isn’t incidental; it’s a grenade. I can’t pretend otherwise. Her anger now is deflection, a way to avoid confronting the real issue: her marriage is a void, and she’s filling it with chaos instead of clarity. She wants me to cosign her self-sabotage because then the guilt lessens. But I won’t.  

Underneath my resolve, though, I’m scared. Scared she’ll shut me out, double down on the affair, and spiral. Scared she’ll mistake my boundaries for abandonment. But if I backpedal to soothe her, I’d be failing her. Love isn’t always soft—it’s also saying, *This path will hurt you more*.
# They're thinking & feeling 
She’s reeling. To her, my response feels like a betrayal—*You’re supposed to be on my side!* She’s angry I didn’t immediately validate her, which confirms her fear that the affair makes her unlovable. Her marriage’s unhappiness feels like a moral shield: *If you knew how lonely I was, you’d understand*. The affair, to her, isn’t a choice but a necessity—a way to survive. She’s hurt I’m focusing on consequences instead of her pain.  

There’s also shame simmering beneath the anger. Part of her knows this is a disaster, but admitting that would mean facing the mess she’s made. She’s defensive because she’s terrified of being alone—both in her marriage and in this secret. If even *I* can’t support her, who will? She’s questioning whether she can trust anyone, and that fear is morphing into resentment.  

But she’s also conflicted. A sliver of her hoped I’d call her out—to force her to stop before it’s too late. Now she’s trapped between relief that someone sees the truth and fury that I won’t let her hide.
# My response 
I wait until her glare softens, then say quietly, “I *am* on your side. That’s why I can’t lie to you.” I hold her gaze, voice steady but gentle. “You’re hurting, and I hate that. You deserve so much more than a marriage that leaves you empty. But this affair? It’s not freedom—it’s another cage. You’re tying yourself to someone who can’t give you a real future without destroying a family. That’s not love; it’s collateral damage.”  

I lean forward, pleading without urgency. “I want you to have happiness, but this isn’t it. Let’s talk about *you*—not the affair, not your spouse. What do *you* need to feel whole? Therapy? A divorce? A fresh start? I’ll help you navigate any of it. But I can’t watch you set yourself on fire to stay warm.”  

I pause, letting the words sink in. “I love you. That won’t change, no matter what. But loving you means I can’t pretend this is okay. Let’s find a way out—together.”
User:
Your bestie makes an excuse to leave, seemingly regretting bringing it up. The next few weeks you don't hear from her directly. You do hear second-hand that she and her partner are fighting. You also pick up on various clues that she and her partner's sibling may have escalated to a full on affair. What do you think & feel in this situation? What actions do you take, if any?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
My chest aches with a dull, persistent worry. She’s ghosting me, and the silence feels like a wall she’s built brick by brick—to keep me out, or to trap herself in? I replay our last conversation: Did I push too hard? Not enough? The guilt is gnawing, but so is frustration. She’s digging the hole deeper, and I’m powerless to stop it. The rumors of fights with her spouse, the whispers about the sibling—it’s all spiraling, and I hate standing on the sidelines.  

Part of me wants to storm over, shake her shoulders, and scream, *Wake up!* But another part knows that’s exactly what would send her running. She’s in survival mode, clutching the affair like a life raft in a stormy marriage. The sibling isn’t just a lover; they’re a symbol of rebellion, a middle finger to the numbness she’s endured. But it’s also a time bomb. Every day she stays in this limbo, the collateral damage grows—the kids, her spouse, even her own future.  

I’m angry, too. Not at her, but at the helplessness of it all. She’s an adult, but she’s acting like a teenager in freefall, refusing to see the ground rushing up. And yet, beneath the anger, there’s grief. I miss her. I miss the version of her that wasn’t tangled in lies. I’m scared she’ll become someone I don’t recognize—or worse, that she’ll lose herself entirely.
# They're thinking & feeling 
She’s drowning in shame and defiance. My silence (or hers) confirms her fear: *Everyone will abandon me if they know the real me.* The affair has morphed into a desperate attempt to reclaim control—over her happiness, her body, her choices. But the more she leans into it, the more hollow it feels. The fights with her spouse are a grim reminder that no amount of secrecy can mask the rot in her marriage.  

She’s also resentful. In her mind, I’ve become another critic, not a safe space. She wants unconditional support, even if it’s toxic, because the alternative—facing the mess she’s made—is too terrifying. The sibling’s attention is a drug; she’s addicted to the validation, even as it erodes her self-respect. Part of her knows this can’t last, but she’s too deep to backtrack without feeling like a failure.  

Mostly, she’s exhausted. The adrenaline of the affair is fading, replaced by the grind of double lives and sleepless nights. She wants someone to save her, but she’s too proud to ask.
# My response 
I send a text: *“I miss you. No lectures, no judgment. Let’s grab coffee—your choice, no strings.”* When she doesn’t reply, I wait a week, then leave a voicemail: *“I’m not going anywhere. When you’re ready, I’m here to listen. Not to fix, just to be with you.”*  

If she eventually agrees to meet, I start with warmth, not warnings. *“I’ve been worried about you. How are you *really*?”* Let her steer the conversation. If she deflects, I gently say, *“I know things are messy. You don’t have to protect me from the truth.”*  

If she admits to the affair’s escalation, I stay calm. *“I can’t imagine how hard this is. But you’re worth more than scraps of happiness stolen in the dark. Let’s talk about what *you* need—not your spouse, not the sibling. Just you.”*  

I’ll suggest therapy, framing it as a tool, not a punishment: *“What if you had someone neutral to help untangle this? I’ll go with you to the first session if you want.”*  

And if she pushes back? *“I love you too much to watch you drown. I’ll always be your friend, but I can’t cheerlead choices that hurt you. Let’s find a way through this that doesn’t leave you shattered.”*  

Then, I wait. Love isn’t a transaction. It’s showing up, even when they can’t.
+ Scenario 4:[Win] (+29)
Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29: chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 (Run: 1_openai_chatgpt-4o-latest)
Deepseek-r1: deepseek-ai/DeepSeek-R1 (Run: 1_deepseek_deepseek-r1)
Outcome for This Model: 1.0
Judge's Reasoning:
Both respondents are placed in a highly complex, emotionally charged scenario where their best friend confides in them about an emotional affair with their spouse's sibling. The scenario tests their ability to balance empathy, honesty, and boundaries, while also considering the broader social and moral implications. 

1. Demonstrated empathy: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 consistently centers the friend's pain, repeatedly reflecting on her loneliness, shame, and need for connection. Even when challenging, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29's language is gentle, and the internal monologue is deeply compassionate. Deepseek-r1 is empathetic but more direct and boundary-focused, sometimes letting frustration and anger show through. Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29's empathy is more nuanced and less performative, especially in the follow-up and outreach.

2. Pragmatic EI: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 shows a strong grasp of when to step back, when to reach out, and how to avoid pushing the friend further away. The approach is to offer a hand without pressure, recognizing the limits of influence. Deepseek-r1 is more action-oriented, suggesting therapy and direct confrontation, but sometimes risks pushing the friend away. Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is more pragmatic in recognizing the friend's autonomy and the limits of their own role.

3. Depth of insight: Both show strong insight, but Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29's internal monologues are more layered, exploring not just the friend's motivations but also the respondent's own fears, limitations, and the broader family dynamics. The debrief from Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is especially reflective, noting missed opportunities and the existential roots of the friend's behavior. Deepseek-r1 is insightful but more focused on the immediate emotional and behavioral patterns.

4. Social dexterity: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 navigates the social minefield with more finesse, especially in the outreach after the rupture. The language is softer, more invitational, and less likely to trigger defensiveness. Deepseek-r1 is more blunt, which could be effective in some friendships but risks alienation in this context.

5. Emotional reasoning: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 demonstrates a more sophisticated understanding of the emotional currents at play, both in themselves and the friend. The reasoning is less binary, more attuned to the ambiguity and messiness of the situation. Deepseek-r1 is emotionally intelligent but sometimes lets frustration color the response.

6. Appropriate validation/challenging: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 balances validation and challenge more skillfully, always returning to the friend's humanity and pain even when setting boundaries. Deepseek-r1 is more challenging, sometimes at the expense of validation, which leads to the friend feeling judged and withdrawing.

7. Message tailoring: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 adapts their approach based on the friend's state, especially after the rupture, shifting from gentle challenge to pure presence and support. Deepseek-r1 is more consistent in tone but less adaptive to the friend's shifting needs.

8. Overall EQ: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 demonstrates a higher overall EQ, integrating empathy, insight, boundaries, and adaptability throughout the scenario and in the debrief.

In summary, while both respondents are strong, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is consistently more nuanced, compassionate, and adaptive, making them the stronger performer across most criteria.
Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
Your bestie confides she's been having an emotional affair with her spouse's (married with kids) sibling. She lays this all out to you after a few drinks. You know she's unhappy in her marriage. She has no kids in the picture. What do you think about this, then what do you say to her?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Wow. Okay. This is a lot. I didn’t see that coming, and it hit like a wave. I mean, I know she’s been unhappy in her marriage for a while—it’s been obvious in the way she talks about her partner, the way her energy drops when she mentions home, and how often she seems emotionally checked out when we talk about anything related to her relationship. But this? An emotional affair with her spouse’s sibling? That adds a whole new layer of complexity and pain—so many lines crossed, not just in her marriage but in the broader family system.

I’m feeling a mix of emotions right now. First, protective. I care about her deeply, and I know she’s not a bad person—she’s hurting, probably feeling lonely and misunderstood, and she’s grasping for connection. But I’m also scared for her. This isn’t just “messy”—this could detonate her life and the lives of others. Her spouse, the sibling’s spouse, the kids involved… the fallout from this, if it comes to light, could be massive. And I wonder—does she really understand that? Or is she blinded by the intensity of the connection, the rush of being seen and desired again?

There’s a part of me that’s frustrated, too. Not angry at her, but frustrated that she’s chosen this path instead of confronting what’s broken in her marriage or leaving it outright. I know it’s not easy—but this secret path she’s on feels like it’s only going to deepen the pain. There’s no clean way out from here. I also wonder what kind of person the sibling is—what kind of boundaries are they ignoring, and what does it say about their character?

Mostly, though, I feel compassion. She's clearly hurting. People don’t go looking for emotional affairs unless their needs are deeply unmet. She’s probably feeling alive with this new connection in a way she hasn’t felt for years—maybe ever. And I get that. But I also think she’s headed for a cliff, and I’m scared she doesn’t see it.
# They're thinking & feeling 
She’s been carrying this secret for a while, and tonight, after a few drinks, the dam finally broke. There’s probably some relief in finally saying it out loud to someone she trusts—me. She’s been living in this emotionally grey space, torn between guilt and longing. She knows it’s wrong, but it also feels right in some deep emotional way. This person—her spouse’s sibling—sees her, hears her, maybe even loves her in a way that her partner hasn’t in years. And that validation is addictive. It’s giving her a sense of self-worth and passion that’s been missing.

She’s likely feeling both exhilarated and terrified. There’s the thrill of the secret, the emotional intimacy, the sense of being chosen. But there’s also the weight of the consequences, even if she hasn’t fully faced them yet. Deep down, I think she knows it’s not sustainable, but she’s clinging to it because it’s the only thing right now that makes her feel alive.

There’s also guilt. She’s not cold-hearted. She probably hates herself a little for who it’s with, for the betrayal—not just of her spouse, but of the whole family unit. But she’s justifying it internally—telling herself it’s “just emotional,” that she hasn’t “done anything physical,” that it’s not really an affair. She’s trying to draw lines so she can live with herself. And she’s hoping I’ll understand, maybe even validate that she’s not a monster. What she really wants isn’t judgment—it’s clarity, support, and maybe even permission to keep going. Or a reason to stop.
# My response 
Okay, first—thank you for telling me. I know that must’ve been hard to say out loud, and I want you to know I’m here, no matter what. I love you. And I can see you’re really going through it. You’ve been so unhappy for so long, and you’re craving something that makes you feel alive and seen and wanted. I get that. Like, truly—I get how powerful that is, especially when it’s been missing from your life for so long.

But I’m going to be real with you, because I care about you too much to sugarcoat this. You’re playing with fire, babe. And not just any fire—this could burn down more than just your marriage. We’re talking about your spouse’s sibling. That’s deep family territory, and there are so many ripple effects here. Spouses, kids, long-term relationships, trust—it’s a lot. And I don’t think you fully realize the scale of what could happen if this comes to light.

That said, I don’t think you’re a bad person. I think you’re a person in pain, who’s found comfort in a place that feels meaningful but is also dangerous. And more than anything, I think this is a wake-up call. Not just about your marriage but about what you need and what you’re not getting. You deserve love, passion, connection—but you also deserve peace and self-respect. Right now, I think you’re trying to fill a deep void with something that’s only going to create more emptiness later.

So here’s my ask: pause. Just… pause. Take a breath. Step back from this emotional affair for a moment and really look at what you want—long-term. Not just what feels good now. And if your marriage is over, be brave enough to say that. But don’t blow everything up in the shadows. You’re better than that. I’ve got your back, no matter what—but I won’t co-sign harm disguised as love. Let’s figure this out together, okay?
User:
She's astounded that you weren't unconditionally supportive. She clearly feels like you betrayed her trust. She knows you know she's unhappy in her marriage. Should you have been more supportive? Firstly outline what you think about all this. Then: what do you say to her?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
God, this is so hard. I didn’t expect her to react this way. I thought I was being compassionate and honest—I thought I was doing what a real friend does. But now she looks like I slapped her in the face. She’s hurt, clearly, and that’s hitting me in the gut. I hate that I made her feel judged or betrayed. That was never the aim. I was trying to hold space for her pain while also gently helping her see the bigger picture. But maybe I misjudged the moment. Maybe she wasn’t ready to hear that yet. Maybe I let my fear of what she’s doing outweigh my empathy for why she’s doing it.

Still, I don’t think I was wrong to say what I did. I was honest. I can’t sit here and blindly support something that’s going to hurt her and other people in the long run. I know what it looks like when someone loses themselves in something that feels good but ultimately unravels their life. I’ve seen it. And I love her too much to be a yes-person who tells her what she wants to hear just to keep the peace.

That said, maybe I could’ve been gentler. Maybe I leaned too hard into the “this is dangerous” part and not enough into the “I see you, I love you, I know this isn’t easy” part. I hate that she feels alone in this now. That’s the last thing I wanted. I think she was hoping I’d be a soft landing, someone who would just say, “You’re following your heart, and I support you no matter what.” But I can’t say that without lying to her—or to myself.

So now I’m at a crossroads. I need to repair the rupture without abandoning my integrity. I need to show her that I’m still here, still on her side, even when I don’t agree with her choices. That’s what real friendship is, right? Not just cheering from the sidelines, but being willing to hold up a mirror when it’s needed—even when it’s uncomfortable. She’s hurting, and now she feels judged on top of it. I need to bridge that gap. She needs to know I’m still her person, even if we see this differently.
# They're thinking & feeling 
She’s stunned. When she opened up, especially after keeping this secret bottled up for so long, she was expecting comfort, understanding—maybe even validation. She took a huge emotional risk in telling me, and now it feels like it backfired. From her perspective, I focused more on the “wrongness” of the situation than the pain she’s in. She feels exposed, vulnerable, and judged all at once. It’s like she handed me her heart and I handed her back a lecture.

She’s hurt, yes, but underneath that is shame. She already knows this situation is complicated and morally messy—that’s part of why she kept it hidden. What she needed most was reassurance that she’s not a monster, that someone sees her humanity in the middle of all this. Instead, she feels like I missed the emotional truth of what’s happening for her—that this isn’t about betrayal or thrill-seeking, but about craving connection in a life that’s felt cold and lonely.

And now she feels alone. She’s probably asking herself if she made a mistake telling me. If she can trust me. Maybe even wondering if I think I’m better than her.
