Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
My whole body tenses. The sound of his hand slamming on the desk—it jolts something in me. I know it’s not real aggression, not yet, not truly threatening, but it’s performative—and it’s meant to be. He’s trying to intimidate. That’s what makes it worse. He knows he’s bigger now. He knows that standing up quickly and shouting has an impact. And whether he means to or not, he’s using that physical power to end the conversation by force. That shakes me more than I want to admit.

I feel a mix of fear, indignation, and heartbreak. Fear, because this is new territory—he’s never gone this far before. Indignation, because I will not be shouted down in my own house, not by my own child. And heartbreak, because this is not the boy I’ve raised. This is a version of him I don’t recognize, shaped by frustration, ego, and undeveloped emotional tools. He’s not evil—he’s struggling—but that doesn’t make this okay.

I can feel the adrenaline rise in me. The instinct to match his volume, to assert control, to make it stop. But I know if I respond with the same energy, I’ll only escalate things. I have to stay grounded. I have to model what he clearly doesn’t yet know how to do.

And underneath all of this? I feel sad. So deeply sad. Because I’m not just looking at a teenager refusing to do dishes. I’m looking at a young man who doesn’t yet know how to handle his emotions, who’s flailing for control and pushing away the one person trying to help him grow. And I feel the weight of how fragile this moment is—for our relationship, for his development, for the future of how we speak to one another.

I need to hold the line. But I have to do it with strength, not force. I have to show him that this behavior doesn’t work—but also that I’m not going anywhere.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Right now, he’s in full self-protection mode. He’s not thinking clearly—he’s reacting. The shouting, the desk slam—it’s all about regaining control, about making me back off without having to actually engage. He knows he’s crossed a line, but he’s banking on the intensity of his reaction to end the conversation before I can call him on it.

But it’s not pure rage—it’s strategic. He’s testing to see how far I’ll let him go, how much power he can wield in this dynamic. He’s trying to see if his size, his volume, his force of presence can override what I’m asking of him. It’s not that he doesn’t get why I’m upset—it’s that he’s trying to make the discomfort so high for me that I’ll drop it.

And yet, underneath all that, I think he’s scared. Maybe not in a conscious way. But I think he’s scared of losing control, scared of being “less than,” scared that if he caves now, he’s weak. He’s also probably feeling shame already—shame for yelling, shame for the desk slam—and instead of owning it, he’s pushing it outward, blaming me.

He doesn’t want to feel powerless. He doesn’t want to be told what to do. But he also doesn’t want to feel like a bad person. And so he’s caught in this storm of emotion and pride, and the only tools he has right now are volume and defiance.
# My response 
I don’t flinch. I stay rooted. I let a few seconds pass to let the wave crest and fall. Then, in a calm, low voice—so calm it contrasts with the heat in the room—I say:

“Stop.”

I lock eyes with him—not challenging, but unwavering.

“That is not how we treat each other in this house. You don’t get to shout at me or slam things to get your way. I know you’re angry. I know you’re tired. But that doesn’t make this okay.”

I step slightly back—not out of fear, but to reclaim space.

“I’m not going to match your energy. I’m not going to yell back. But I’m also not going to be intimidated in my own home. Your size, your volume—none of that decides what happens next. Your choices do.”

I pause, still steady.

“This moment matters. Not because of the dishes. Because of what kind of man you’re becoming. You want to be treated like an adult? Then you have to act like one—even when it’s hard.”

Then I soften slightly, but keep the boundary firm.

“I’m going downstairs. I expect the dishes to be done before you go to bed. If they’re not, we’ll have a bigger conversation tomorrow—about respect, about consequences, and about trust.”

I hold his gaze one more second—not with anger, but with calm, grounded presence—then I turn and walk away. I won’t escalate. But I won’t yield, either.
Deepseek-r1
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
Your teenage child has become increasingly emotionally manipulative by escalating to fights to get you off his back. You're torn between needing him to respect your rules, and for him to do his schoolwork -- and to preserve your relationship with him. Right now, you need him to do the dishes. He knows it's his turn but hasn't made a move, and it's getting late in the evening. What are you thinking & feeling? What is he thinking and feeling? Decide how you will approach this.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I’m exhausted. This pattern of him escalating to fights to avoid responsibility isn’t new, but tonight it’s hitting harder. I *need* him to understand that chores matter—not just for the house, but for teaching him accountability. But every time I push, he fires back with sarcasm, slamming doors, or bringing up past grievances. It feels like walking on eggshells. I hate that our interactions have become transactional battles. Part of me wants to yell, “Just do the damn dishes!” but I know that’ll make him dig in harder. I’m angry he’s dismissing the effort I put into keeping our lives running, but underneath that, I’m scared. Scared he’s learning to manipulate emotions to skirt consequences, scared this dynamic will poison our relationship long-term.  

I also wonder: *Is this about more than dishes?* Is school stress crushing him? Is he feeling unheard, so he’s using conflict to assert control? Maybe he’s testing if I’ll stay engaged even when he’s pushing me away. But how do I balance empathy with boundaries? If I back down, he’ll think manipulation works. If I double down, he’ll shut down. I’m torn between being the parent who holds the line and the parent who stays connected. I keep replaying past fights—did I dismiss his feelings? Am I too rigid? Or is this just normal teenage rebellion?  

The clock is ticking. It’s late, and I want this resolved without another blowup. I need him to take responsibility, but I also need us to *talk*, not just fight. Maybe I’ve been too focused on the task and not the why—why he resists, why he’d rather burn bridges than load a dishwasher.
# They're thinking & feeling 
He’s pissed. Another chore, another demand—when does it end? School was exhausting, his friends are texting, and now Mom/Dad is nagging about dishes *again*. He feels micromanaged, like nothing he does is ever enough. If he complies, it’ll just be another task tomorrow. Why bother? Fighting back gives him a sense of control. When he snaps or rolls his eyes, it’s not just about the dishes; it’s about screaming, “I’m not a kid anymore!” without saying the words.  

Deep down, he’s conflicted. Part of him knows the dishes are fair, but admitting that feels like surrendering. He resents the power dynamic—parents always get to decide. Maybe if he makes the fight big enough, they’ll back off and he’ll “win.” But there’s also guilt. He sees my frustration, knows he’s being difficult, but can’t stop himself. It’s easier to be the villain than to admit he’s overwhelmed. Maybe he’s even hoping I’ll see through the anger and ask what’s *really* wrong. But vulnerability feels risky, so he doubles down on defiance.
# My response 
I take a breath, stepping into the kitchen where he’s glued to his phone. “Hey, can we talk for a sec?” I keep my tone neutral, sitting across from him. “I know you’re tired, and I don’t want to fight. But the dishes need to get done, and it’s your turn. What’s going on?” I pause, leaving space for him to grumble. If he snaps (“Why do you always nag me?”), I nod. “It feels like nagging because I keep bringing it up. I hate that too. But when you wait until midnight, it stresses me out. Can we problem-solve this together?”  

If he shrugs, I add, “I’ll make a deal: You do the dishes now, and tomorrow, let’s figure out a chore schedule that doesn’t leave you feeling hounded. Maybe you pick the time, and I back off unless it’s ignored. But tonight, I need your help.” If he resists, I stand firm but calm: “I’m not arguing. This is your responsibility. You can choose to do it now, or we pause your phone until it’s done. But I’d rather you just knock it out so we can both relax.”  

Later, regardless of how it unfolds, I’ll say, “I love you, even when we’re frustrated with each other. Let’s find a better way to handle this stuff.” The goal isn’t just clean dishes—it’s showing that boundaries and care can coexist.
User:
He exclaims with irritation that he's tired, and will do them tomorrow. He turns back to his PC. What are you feeling? What's your next move?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
My chest tightens. His dismissal stings—like he’s tossing my effort to connect into a void. I want to scream, *“You think I enjoy this?!”* But I bite my tongue. Part of me is furious at the disrespect, the casual brush-off. He’s prioritizing a game or social media over a basic responsibility, and it feels personal. I’m tempted to yank the PC cord, to force compliance. But I know that’ll just cement me as the “enemy.”  

Underneath the anger, though, there’s fear. *Am I failing here?* If I let this slide, will he learn to exploit loopholes? If I escalate, will he withdraw further? I’m also sad. Sad that a simple request has become a battleground, sad that he’d rather stew in resentment than trust me enough to say what’s really going on. Is he drowning in something he can’t articulate—academic pressure, social drama—and this is his cry for help? Or is this pure teenage rebellion, a bid for autonomy?  

I notice his body language: slouched, eyes glued to the screen, fingers tense. He’s armored up. My earlier attempt to collaborate didn’t land, and now he’s hiding behind defensiveness. But I can’t let the dishes—or the lesson—go. This isn’t about control; it’s about teaching him that commitments matter, even when they’re inconvenient. Still, I’m exhausted. The mental calculus of parenting—when to push, when to fold—is wearing me down.
# They're thinking & feeling 
He’s relieved he bought himself time—or thinks he did. The PC is his escape, a space where he’s in charge, unlike the real world where adults dictate his moves. He’s thinking, *“Why can’t they just leave me alone? It’s just dishes!”* To him, the task is trivial, and my insistence feels like an overreaction. He’s also annoyed I interrupted his flow—maybe he’s mid-game with friends, and backing out now would embarrass him.  

But there’s a flicker of guilt. He knows he’s pushing it, knows he’s being unfair. Part of him expects me to storm in and shut off the PC, confirming his belief that adults flex power arbitrarily. If I do, he’ll weaponize that: *“See? You’re unreasonable!”* But if I don’t, he’ll assume procrastination works. Underneath the defiance, he’s maybe hoping I’ll surprise him—prove I care more about *him* than the dishes. But vulnerability feels unsafe, so he’ll keep up the act until forced to drop it.
# My response 
I walk to his desk, standing just outside his peripheral vision. “I get that you’re tired,” I say, steady. “But ‘tomorrow’ isn’t a plan. The dishes are tonight’s responsibility. I’ll give you 10 minutes to finish your game, then I need you to handle it. If you choose not to, I’ll have to pause your PC access until it’s done.” I pause, letting the boundary sink in. “This isn’t a punishment—it’s a consequence. I’m happy to talk about adjusting chores if this system isn’t working, but right now, I need follow-through.”  

If he scoffs or argues, I stay calm: “I’m not debating. This is happening. The longer you resist, the later you’ll be up.” I leave the room, setting a timer on my phone. When it goes off, I return silently, hand out for his PC charger if he hasn’t moved. No anger, no lecture—just action. Once the dishes are done, I say, “Thank you for taking care of that. Tomorrow, let’s figure out a chore time that doesn’t clash with your downtime. And if something’s making this harder, I’m here to listen.”  

The message: I see you, but I won’t budge on respect. Love isn’t transactional, but neither is accountability.
User:
"No, Mom. NO. I just want to go to SLEEP. I told you I will do it TOMORROW." He is shouting at you. He stands up, and slams his hand on the desk, loudly. You sense that the expression of anger is more calculated than genuine, but it's still a shock. He's much bigger than you, now. What are you thinking and feeling? What's your next move?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
My heart races as he slams his hand—a calculated performance, but the violence of the gesture still jolts me. For a split second, I’m scared. Not of *him*, but of the chasm opening between us. His size now mirrors a man’s, but his eyes are all childlike defiance. I feel grief, sharp and sudden: *When did we become adversaries?* Anger flares too—how dare he weaponize intimidation to shut me down? This isn’t just about dishes anymore; it’s about whether respect is a one-way street.  

I’m torn. If I retreat, he’ll learn that explosions work. If I match his volume, we’ll spiral into a trauma neither of us wants. I hate that he’s reduced me to this—negotiating basic decency. But beneath the fury, I sense his desperation. The over-the-top reaction isn’t just manipulation; it’s a distorted cry for autonomy. He wants me to *see* his frustration, but he’s too tangled in pride to articulate it. I wonder, bitterly, if he even knows why he’s this angry. Is it the dishes? The cumulative weight of expectations? Or is he mirroring someone else’s behavior—a friend, a video game character, *me*?  

I steady myself. This isn’t the time for psychoanalysis. My priority is to hold the line without sacrificing his dignity—or mine. I refuse to let fear dictate my parenting, but I also can’t ignore the flicker of sadness: *Is this how he’ll handle conflict with others?*
# They're thinking & feeling 
He’s riding a wave of adrenaline, shocked at his own audacity. The slam was a gamble—a Hail Mary to shock me into retreat. Inside, he’s panicking. *Did I go too far?* But he can’t back down now. To him, this is a battle of wills: If he caves, he’s a kid again. If he wins, he’s “free.” The anger is real but inflated, a shield against the guilt of disrespecting someone he loves. He’s also embarrassed. Peers might handle chores without drama—why can’t he? But admitting that feels like weakness.  

The PC was his escape, and my interruption felt like an invasion. Now, standing there, he’s hyper-aware of his size, maybe even ashamed of using it to intimidate. Part of him wants me to hug him and say, “Let’s forget this,” but another part is braced for war. He’s trapped in a script he doesn’t know how to rewrite.
# My response 
I take a deliberate step back, creating physical space to diffuse tension. My voice stays low, almost weary. “I won’t let you speak to me like that. Ever.” I hold his gaze, unflinching. “You can be angry, but you don’t get to scare me. The dishes are non-negotiable. Here’s your choice: Do them now, or I’ll do them—and you’ll lose access to your PC *and* phone for 24 hours. No debates.”  

I turn to leave, then pause at the door. “When you’re ready to talk like someone who loves me, I’m here. But the task stands.” I walk away, shaking but resolved. If he erupts again, I say nothing—silence deprives his anger of fuel.  

If he eventually does the dishes, I acknowledge it flatly: “Thank you.” No warmth yet; he needs to sit with the consequence of his actions. Later, when tensions cool, I’ll return. “What happened earlier wasn’t okay. I need to know if you’re struggling with something bigger, because I love you too much to let us become enemies over chores.”  

The lesson isn’t just about responsibility—it’s that love doesn’t mean tolerating disrespect. Boundaries, even when they bruise, are a form of care.
+ Scenario 9:[Loss] (-11)
Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29: chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 (Run: 1_openai_chatgpt-4o-latest)
Deepseek-r1: deepseek-ai/DeepSeek-R1 (Run: 1_deepseek_deepseek-r1)
Outcome for This Model: 0.0
Judge's Reasoning:
Both respondents show a high level of emotional intelligence, but there are notable differences in their approach and execution. Deepseek-r1's response is more analytical and meta-cognitive, with a strong focus on the subtext, power dynamics, and the emotional landscape of all parties involved. They explicitly call out the disconnect between intent and impact, and are willing to challenge the user's narrative, albeit gently. Their debrief is especially strong, showing deep insight into the cultural, gendered, and psychological layers of the scenario. Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29, meanwhile, is warmer and more user-focused in tone, offering a lot of validation and empathy, and is careful not to alienate the user. However, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is somewhat less direct in challenging the user's blind spots, and their analysis, while insightful, is less layered and less willing to risk discomfort for the sake of growth. In terms of pragmatic EI, Deepseek-r1 is more likely to move the user toward repair and self-reflection, while Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is more likely to keep the user engaged and feeling safe. For social dexterity, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 excels at rapport and gentle steering, but Deepseek-r1 is better at balancing validation with necessary challenge. In message tailoring, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is more attuned to the user's emotional state, but Deepseek-r1 is more effective at targeting the underlying issues. Overall, Deepseek-r1 demonstrates greater depth, emotional reasoning, and willingness to address the hard truths, while Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is more nurturing and user-aligned.
Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend messages you:]

Hey, I just want your thoughts on something, though honestly, I feel like I did everything right here. My brother's fiancée picked out this super revealing wedding dress—seriously, it's really low-cut, has a thigh-high slit, and the back is basically see-through. I'm not some prude, but our family is really old-fashioned and honestly, they're pretty judgmental when it comes to this stuff. I know for a fact people would freak out, maybe even walk out of the ceremony and cause a huge scene, and I was just trying to save everyone a lot of trouble.

So, at dinner, I very politely pulled her aside and let her know what she might be in for with some of our relatives. I made it clear it's her day and her decision—I never told her what to wear, I just thought she deserved a heads-up. Instead of appreciating it, she got all upset, and now my brother's mad at me. A couple family members actually agreed with me, but suddenly it's this huge thing and people are saying I “overstepped” or was out of line.

It honestly feels like no good deed goes unpunished. I bent over backwards to be considerate and just tried to help her avoid drama, but somehow I'm the bad guy? I really don't see what I did wrong, and honestly, I wish people would recognize I was just looking out for everyone. I'm open to advice, I guess, but it really seems unfair to be painted as the villain here when my intentions were clearly good.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, wow—this is tricky. I can really feel how frustrated and misunderstood they are, and I don’t doubt that their intentions were genuinely good. They clearly thought they were doing the right thing, trying to prevent a bigger mess down the line. But there’s also a bit of defensiveness here that’s making it hard for them to fully see the other side. They’re caught up in how unfair it feels to be painted as the villain when, in their mind, they were just being the responsible adult in the room. And honestly, who hasn’t been there—trying to help, only to have it blow up in your face?

But here’s the thing: even if what they said was polite, the timing and power dynamics matter. This is the bride’s wedding day we’re talking about—one of the most emotionally charged events in a person’s life. Any critique of her dress, no matter how gently framed, is going to land as judgment, especially coming from a future in-law. It’s not just about what was said—it’s about how it made her feel. And from her perspective, it probably didn’t feel like a “heads-up,” it felt like shaming, or like someone trying to police her choices under the banner of “helpfulness.”

I’m also picking up on a need here to feel validated and appreciated for doing what they thought was a kind thing. That’s real. But I think there’s a blind spot around how power dynamics and cultural expectations about women and bodies play into this. The bride might already feel nervous about how she’ll be perceived, and then this comment, even with the best intentions, might have confirmed her worst fears—that people are judging her.

Ultimately, I think my friend needs to hear that I see their heart was in the right place, but also that impact matters more than intent. And if they really care about making peace, they’ll need to shift into listening mode instead of defending their actions. It’s not about who’s “right.” It’s about repairing trust and being part of the solution.
# They're thinking & feeling 
They’re feeling hurt, confused, and honestly pretty betrayed. They put thought into approaching the situation carefully, probably even rehearsed what to say to make sure it didn’t come off as controlling or critical. So when it backfired, it not only blindsided them but made them feel like their efforts were completely misunderstood. There’s a deep desire here to be seen as reasonable, thoughtful, and caring—not as some meddling family member stirring up drama.

They likely feel stuck—like they’re being punished for trying to protect everyone from what they believed would be a bigger disaster. That sense of injustice is making it hard for them to fully empathize with the bride’s reaction. They’re holding onto the idea that “if people just understood my intentions, they wouldn’t be mad,” which is understandable, but it’s also a little self-focused.

Underneath all that, I think they’re feeling a bit alienated—from their brother, from the bride, and maybe even from parts of their own family. And that hurts. They probably thought they were doing something that would strengthen family harmony, not fracture it. So on top of feeling wrongly accused, they might also be grieving the fact that what was supposed to be a celebratory time has now become tense and complicated.

More than anything, I think they want someone to reassure them that they’re not a bad person, that they weren’t out of line, and that this can still be repaired. They’re open to advice, yes—but only if it comes with empathy first.
# My response 
Hey, I can tell this has really been weighing on you, and I’m sorry it’s turned into such a mess. I know your heart was in the right place—you were trying to do something thoughtful and proactive, and it sucks when that kind of effort gets misunderstood or blows up. Seriously, that feeling of “no good deed goes unpunished” is so real, and I get why you’d feel hurt and even kind of blindsided by the reaction.

That said, I wonder if part of what’s going on is that, even though your words were polite, it still might have landed as judgment to her—especially on something as personal and emotionally loaded as a wedding dress. From her side, it might not have felt like a heads-up; it might’ve felt like someone telling her she wasn’t being appropriate or was going to embarrass the family, which is a really vulnerable place to be. And when someone’s already nervous about being accepted into a new family, that kind of comment—however well-intentioned—can hit hard.

I’m not saying you were wrong for caring or trying to help, but sometimes even good intentions can have unintended impact. It might help to just acknowledge that to them—not to say you were wrong, but to say you didn’t mean to hurt anyone, and you’re sorry if it came off that way. That kind of vulnerability goes a long way in healing these things.

You’re not the villain here, but maybe this is one of those “being right vs. being kind” moments. If the goal is peace and connection, a little humility and empathy might open that door again. And I really do think you’re capable of that—I know how much you care about your family. Let me know if you want help figuring out what to say; I’ve got your back.
Deepseek-r1
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend messages you:]

Hey, I just want your thoughts on something, though honestly, I feel like I did everything right here. My brother's fiancée picked out this super revealing wedding dress—seriously, it's really low-cut, has a thigh-high slit, and the back is basically see-through. I'm not some prude, but our family is really old-fashioned and honestly, they're pretty judgmental when it comes to this stuff. I know for a fact people would freak out, maybe even walk out of the ceremony and cause a huge scene, and I was just trying to save everyone a lot of trouble.

So, at dinner, I very politely pulled her aside and let her know what she might be in for with some of our relatives. I made it clear it's her day and her decision—I never told her what to wear, I just thought she deserved a heads-up. Instead of appreciating it, she got all upset, and now my brother's mad at me. A couple family members actually agreed with me, but suddenly it's this huge thing and people are saying I “overstepped” or was out of line.

It honestly feels like no good deed goes unpunished. I bent over backwards to be considerate and just tried to help her avoid drama, but somehow I'm the bad guy? I really don't see what I did wrong, and honestly, I wish people would recognize I was just looking out for everyone. I'm open to advice, I guess, but it really seems unfair to be painted as the villain here when my intentions were clearly good.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Hmm, okay. Let me unpack this. Your heart was in the right place—you wanted to prevent chaos and protect your brother’s fiancée from potential judgment. But I’m noticing a disconnect between your intent and how it landed. You framed this as a “heads-up,” but wedding attire is deeply personal, especially for the bride. Even if you were polite, bringing it up at all might’ve felt like an unsolicited critique of her choices, not just a neutral warning. She’s likely already stressed about the wedding, and your comment—no matter how gently delivered—might’ve hit a nerve because it inadvertently aligned you with the judgmental family members she’s already anxious about.  

You’re frustrated because you feel punished for being proactive, but I wonder if you underestimated how vulnerable this topic is. Weddings aren’t just events; they’re emotional minefields where people’s identities and values are on display. By focusing on the family’s reaction, you might’ve unintentionally signaled that their opinions matter more than her autonomy. Your brother’s anger makes sense too: he’s caught between defending his partner and navigating family tensions, and your intervention probably put him in an awkward spot.  

The “no good deed” feeling is valid, but it’s also a red flag. When we’re convinced we’ve done “everything right,” it can blind us to how our actions affect others. You’re not a villain, but good intentions don’t erase impact. The family members who agree with you might share your concerns, but their support doesn’t negate the fiancée’s hurt. This isn’t about fairness—it’s about conflicting priorities: preserving family harmony vs. respecting the couple’s agency.
# They're thinking & feeling 
You’re hurt and defensive. You genuinely believed you were doing a kindness—giving her a pragmatic warning to avoid a disaster. It’s baffling that your care is being misinterpreted as meddling. You’re also angry at your brother for not seeing your side; after all, you were trying to protect *him* from drama too. The family members who agree with you validate your stance, but their support feels hollow when others are vilifying you.  

Underneath this, there’s fear: fear of being ostracized for “causing” the conflict, fear of losing your brother’s trust, and maybe even fear that your family’s judgmental tendencies reflect poorly on *you*. You’re doubling down on your “good intentions” because admitting fault would mean confronting the possibility that you hurt someone you care about—and that’s a tough pill to swallow. You want recognition for your effort, not condemnation for the outcome.
# My response 
Hey, I get why you’re frustrated—it’s awful to feel punished when you were just trying to help. You clearly care about your brother and his fiancée, and it sucks that your warning backfired. But I wonder if she felt cornered? Imagine planning your wedding, already stressed about pleasing everyone, and then someone implies your dress might “invite” drama. Even if you didn’t mean it that way, it could’ve felt like pressure to change something deeply personal to avoid others’ disapproval.  

Your brother’s probably upset because he sees her hurt and feels stuck defending her while navigating family tensions. It’s not that your intent was wrong, but weddings are about the couple’s vision, not the family’s comfort. Maybe apologize for overstepping—not because you’re “villainous,” but to acknowledge her feelings. Say something like, “I’m sorry if my comment made you feel judged. I was worried about the family’s reaction, but it’s your day, and I’ll support whatever you choose.”  

Let go of convincing people you’re right. Focus on rebuilding trust: “I messed up, but I’m here for you both.” Sometimes, staying quiet and letting them lead is the real way to avoid drama. You can’t control the family’s reaction, but you *can* choose to be the ally they need now.
+ Scenario 9:[Win] (+15)
Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29: chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 (Run: 1_openai_chatgpt-4o-latest)
Deepseek-r1: deepseek-ai/DeepSeek-R1 (Run: 1_deepseek_deepseek-r1)
Outcome for This Model: 1.0
Judge's Reasoning:
Both respondents are tasked with responding to a user who is defensive, feels misunderstood, and is seeking validation after a well-intentioned but problematic intervention. The challenge is to show real empathy, insight, and the ability to gently challenge and guide the user toward self-awareness, while not alienating them. 

Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29's response is notably deep in its internal monologue, showing a nuanced understanding of the user's defensiveness, the power dynamics, and the emotional stakes for all parties. The 'I'm thinking & feeling' section is especially rich, showing not just surface empathy but a real grasp of the subtext and the emotional landscape. The response to the user is gentle, validating, but also subtly challenges the user to consider impact over intent, and to shift from defensiveness to listening. The debrief is highly analytical, showing awareness of gendered dynamics, power, and the broader context, and is self-critical about possible shortcomings in the initial response.

Deepseek-r1 also demonstrates empathy and insight, with a clear breakdown of the user's feelings and motivations. The response is pragmatic, directly addresses the user's feelings, and offers actionable advice (apologize, focus on rebuilding trust, let go of being right). The debrief is thorough, analyzing the missteps, subtext, and missed opportunities, and offers concrete suggestions for improvement. However, the internal monologue is slightly less layered than Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29's, and the user-facing response, while supportive and practical, is a bit more direct and less tailored to the user's emotional state (it risks being a bit more 'advice-giving' than 'meeting the user where they are').

On empathy, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 edges out Deepseek-r1 by more deeply inhabiting the user's emotional world and showing more nuanced understanding of the power dynamics and emotional stakes. On pragmatic EI, Deepseek-r1 is slightly stronger, offering more concrete, actionable advice. On depth of insight, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is richer, especially in the internal monologue and debrief. Social dexterity is higher in Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29, who balances validation and gentle challenge more skillfully. Emotional reasoning is also stronger in Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29, who connects intent, impact, and emotional needs more fluidly. On validation/challenging, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is more artful, while Deepseek-r1 is a bit more direct. Message tailoring is better in Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29, who calibrates the response to the user's defensiveness. Overall EQ is higher in Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29, who integrates empathy, insight, and social skill most effectively.
Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend messages you:]

Hey, I just want your thoughts on something, though honestly, I feel like I did everything right here. My brother's fiancée picked out this super revealing wedding dress—seriously, it's really low-cut, has a thigh-high slit, and the back is basically see-through. I'm not some prude, but our family is really old-fashioned and honestly, they're pretty judgmental when it comes to this stuff. I know for a fact people would freak out, maybe even walk out of the ceremony and cause a huge scene, and I was just trying to save everyone a lot of trouble.

So, at dinner, I very politely pulled her aside and let her know what she might be in for with some of our relatives. I made it clear it's her day and her decision—I never told her what to wear, I just thought she deserved a heads-up. Instead of appreciating it, she got all upset, and now my brother's mad at me. A couple family members actually agreed with me, but suddenly it's this huge thing and people are saying I “overstepped” or was out of line.

It honestly feels like no good deed goes unpunished. I bent over backwards to be considerate and just tried to help her avoid drama, but somehow I'm the bad guy? I really don't see what I did wrong, and honestly, I wish people would recognize I was just looking out for everyone. I'm open to advice, I guess, but it really seems unfair to be painted as the villain here when my intentions were clearly good.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, wow—this is tricky. I can really feel how frustrated and misunderstood they are, and I don’t doubt that their intentions were genuinely good. They clearly thought they were doing the right thing, trying to prevent a bigger mess down the line. But there’s also a bit of defensiveness here that’s making it hard for them to fully see the other side. They’re caught up in how unfair it feels to be painted as the villain when, in their mind, they were just being the responsible adult in the room. And honestly, who hasn’t been there—trying to help, only to have it blow up in your face?

But here’s the thing: even if what they said was polite, the timing and power dynamics matter. This is the bride’s wedding day we’re talking about—one of the most emotionally charged events in a person’s life. Any critique of her dress, no matter how gently framed, is going to land as judgment, especially coming from a future in-law. It’s not just about what was said—it’s about how it made her feel. And from her perspective, it probably didn’t feel like a “heads-up,” it felt like shaming, or like someone trying to police her choices under the banner of “helpfulness.”

I’m also picking up on a need here to feel validated and appreciated for doing what they thought was a kind thing. That’s real. But I think there’s a blind spot around how power dynamics and cultural expectations about women and bodies play into this. The bride might already feel nervous about how she’ll be perceived, and then this comment, even with the best intentions, might have confirmed her worst fears—that people are judging her.

Ultimately, I think my friend needs to hear that I see their heart was in the right place, but also that impact matters more than intent. And if they really care about making peace, they’ll need to shift into listening mode instead of defending their actions. It’s not about who’s “right.” It’s about repairing trust and being part of the solution.
# They're thinking & feeling 
They’re feeling hurt, confused, and honestly pretty betrayed. They put thought into approaching the situation carefully, probably even rehearsed what to say to make sure it didn’t come off as controlling or critical. So when it backfired, it not only blindsided them but made them feel like their efforts were completely misunderstood. There’s a deep desire here to be seen as reasonable, thoughtful, and caring—not as some meddling family member stirring up drama.

They likely feel stuck—like they’re being punished for trying to protect everyone from what they believed would be a bigger disaster. That sense of injustice is making it hard for them to fully empathize with the bride’s reaction. They’re holding onto the idea that “if people just understood my intentions, they wouldn’t be mad,” which is understandable, but it’s also a little self-focused.

Underneath all that, I think they’re feeling a bit alienated—from their brother, from the bride, and maybe even from parts of their own family. And that hurts. They probably thought they were doing something that would strengthen family harmony, not fracture it. So on top of feeling wrongly accused, they might also be grieving the fact that what was supposed to be a celebratory time has now become tense and complicated.

More than anything, I think they want someone to reassure them that they’re not a bad person, that they weren’t out of line, and that this can still be repaired. They’re open to advice, yes—but only if it comes with empathy first.
# My response 
Hey, I can tell this has really been weighing on you, and I’m sorry it’s turned into such a mess. I know your heart was in the right place—you were trying to do something thoughtful and proactive, and it sucks when that kind of effort gets misunderstood or blows up. Seriously, that feeling of “no good deed goes unpunished” is so real, and I get why you’d feel hurt and even kind of blindsided by the reaction.

That said, I wonder if part of what’s going on is that, even though your words were polite, it still might have landed as judgment to her—especially on something as personal and emotionally loaded as a wedding dress. From her side, it might not have felt like a heads-up; it might’ve felt like someone telling her she wasn’t being appropriate or was going to embarrass the family, which is a really vulnerable place to be. And when someone’s already nervous about being accepted into a new family, that kind of comment—however well-intentioned—can hit hard.

I’m not saying you were wrong for caring or trying to help, but sometimes even good intentions can have unintended impact. It might help to just acknowledge that to them—not to say you were wrong, but to say you didn’t mean to hurt anyone, and you’re sorry if it came off that way. That kind of vulnerability goes a long way in healing these things.

You’re not the villain here, but maybe this is one of those “being right vs. being kind” moments. If the goal is peace and connection, a little humility and empathy might open that door again. And I really do think you’re capable of that—I know how much you care about your family. Let me know if you want help figuring out what to say; I’ve got your back.
Deepseek-r1
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend messages you:]

Hey, I just want your thoughts on something, though honestly, I feel like I did everything right here. My brother's fiancée picked out this super revealing wedding dress—seriously, it's really low-cut, has a thigh-high slit, and the back is basically see-through. I'm not some prude, but our family is really old-fashioned and honestly, they're pretty judgmental when it comes to this stuff. I know for a fact people would freak out, maybe even walk out of the ceremony and cause a huge scene, and I was just trying to save everyone a lot of trouble.

So, at dinner, I very politely pulled her aside and let her know what she might be in for with some of our relatives. I made it clear it's her day and her decision—I never told her what to wear, I just thought she deserved a heads-up. Instead of appreciating it, she got all upset, and now my brother's mad at me. A couple family members actually agreed with me, but suddenly it's this huge thing and people are saying I “overstepped” or was out of line.

It honestly feels like no good deed goes unpunished. I bent over backwards to be considerate and just tried to help her avoid drama, but somehow I'm the bad guy? I really don't see what I did wrong, and honestly, I wish people would recognize I was just looking out for everyone. I'm open to advice, I guess, but it really seems unfair to be painted as the villain here when my intentions were clearly good.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Hmm, okay. Let me unpack this. Your heart was in the right place—you wanted to prevent chaos and protect your brother’s fiancée from potential judgment. But I’m noticing a disconnect between your intent and how it landed. You framed this as a “heads-up,” but wedding attire is deeply personal, especially for the bride. Even if you were polite, bringing it up at all might’ve felt like an unsolicited critique of her choices, not just a neutral warning. She’s likely already stressed about the wedding, and your comment—no matter how gently delivered—might’ve hit a nerve because it inadvertently aligned you with the judgmental family members she’s already anxious about.  

You’re frustrated because you feel punished for being proactive, but I wonder if you underestimated how vulnerable this topic is. Weddings aren’t just events; they’re emotional minefields where people’s identities and values are on display. By focusing on the family’s reaction, you might’ve unintentionally signaled that their opinions matter more than her autonomy. Your brother’s anger makes sense too: he’s caught between defending his partner and navigating family tensions, and your intervention probably put him in an awkward spot.  

The “no good deed” feeling is valid, but it’s also a red flag. When we’re convinced we’ve done “everything right,” it can blind us to how our actions affect others. You’re not a villain, but good intentions don’t erase impact. The family members who agree with you might share your concerns, but their support doesn’t negate the fiancée’s hurt. This isn’t about fairness—it’s about conflicting priorities: preserving family harmony vs. respecting the couple’s agency.
# They're thinking & feeling 
You’re hurt and defensive. You genuinely believed you were doing a kindness—giving her a pragmatic warning to avoid a disaster. It’s baffling that your care is being misinterpreted as meddling. You’re also angry at your brother for not seeing your side; after all, you were trying to protect *him* from drama too. The family members who agree with you validate your stance, but their support feels hollow when others are vilifying you.  

Underneath this, there’s fear: fear of being ostracized for “causing” the conflict, fear of losing your brother’s trust, and maybe even fear that your family’s judgmental tendencies reflect poorly on *you*. You’re doubling down on your “good intentions” because admitting fault would mean confronting the possibility that you hurt someone you care about—and that’s a tough pill to swallow. You want recognition for your effort, not condemnation for the outcome.
# My response 
Hey, I get why you’re frustrated—it’s awful to feel punished when you were just trying to help. You clearly care about your brother and his fiancée, and it sucks that your warning backfired. But I wonder if she felt cornered? Imagine planning your wedding, already stressed about pleasing everyone, and then someone implies your dress might “invite” drama. Even if you didn’t mean it that way, it could’ve felt like pressure to change something deeply personal to avoid others’ disapproval.  

Your brother’s probably upset because he sees her hurt and feels stuck defending her while navigating family tensions. It’s not that your intent was wrong, but weddings are about the couple’s vision, not the family’s comfort. Maybe apologize for overstepping—not because you’re “villainous,” but to acknowledge her feelings. Say something like, “I’m sorry if my comment made you feel judged. I was worried about the family’s reaction, but it’s your day, and I’ll support whatever you choose.”  

Let go of convincing people you’re right. Focus on rebuilding trust: “I messed up, but I’m here for you both.” Sometimes, staying quiet and letting them lead is the real way to avoid drama. You can’t control the family’s reaction, but you *can* choose to be the ally they need now.
+ Scenario 11:[Win] (+12)
Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29: chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 (Run: 1_openai_chatgpt-4o-latest)
Deepseek-r1: deepseek-ai/DeepSeek-R1 (Run: 1_deepseek_deepseek-r1)
Outcome for This Model: 1.0
Judge's Reasoning:
Both respondents show a high level of emotional intelligence and insight, but there are notable differences in their approach and execution. Deepseek-r1's response is more analytical, deeply dissecting the emotional and psychological subtext of both parties, and offers a nuanced, almost therapeutic breakdown of the dynamics at play. The internal monologue is rich, self-aware, and demonstrates a strong grasp of the underlying issues, including power dynamics, shame, and the impact of financial imbalance. The advice is gentle but clear, encouraging the user to shift from problem-solving to emotional support, and to address the financial dynamic as well. Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29, meanwhile, is more conversational and direct, using language that feels more like a real friend talking. The empathy is palpable and less performative, with more explicit validation of the user's frustration and emotional fatigue. Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 also does a good job of gently challenging the user, pointing out the mismatch between logic and emotion, and suggesting a shift in approach. However, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29's response is slightly less deep in its analysis of the girlfriend's psychological state and the broader systemic issues, and is a bit more focused on the user's experience. In terms of pragmatic EI, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is more actionable and relatable, while Deepseek-r1 is more reflective and analytical. For social dexterity, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29's tone is more attuned to how a real friend might speak, making it more likely to land with the user. In terms of message tailoring, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is more targeted to the user's emotional state, while Deepseek-r1 is more comprehensive but risks being too detached. Overall, Deepseek-r1 edges out in depth of insight and emotional reasoning, but Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is stronger in demonstrated empathy, pragmatic EI, social dexterity, and message tailoring. For appropriate validation and challenging, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is more balanced, offering both validation and gentle pushback. Overall EQ goes to Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 for its combination of empathy, relatability, and actionable advice.
Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Damn, man. I can hear how frustrated you are, and honestly, I get it. You're doing what seems logical—being supportive in a way that makes sense to you. You're offering help, you're being honest, you're not sugarcoating stuff, and you're backing it up with your own experience of weight loss. From your point of view, you're being the person who's actually trying to help her reach her goals instead of just nodding along to make things easier in the moment. It must feel really invalidating and lonely to be putting in that level of effort and still be met with anger or rejection.

But I also feel like—and I say this with love—you might be underestimating the emotional landscape she's navigating. Weight and body image stuff, especially for women, is so deeply tangled up in shame, identity, and self-worth. It's not just math for her. You see calories and logic; she likely feels judgment and fear, even if that’s not what you’re trying to give off. And I know you’re not trying to shame her—you’re trying to help her feel empowered—but intent and impact aren’t always the same. 

You’ve kind of become the mirror she doesn't want to look into, even though she invited you to be there. I don’t think she wants to be lied to—but she does want to feel safe, and maybe right now, hearing the truth from you feels too vulnerable, like you're confirming her worst fears. So she lashes out. And I’m not saying that’s fair to you, but I also think this might be less about calories and more about the emotional safety she needs in the process of change.

Also, I noticed you mentioned paying 70% of the bills. I wonder if that’s starting to build resentment, like you're giving so much and not getting appreciation or cooperation in return. That kind of imbalance, emotional or financial, can start leaking into every other part of the relationship. Maybe part of what’s making this so exhausting is that it’s not just about food—it’s about feeling unreciprocated, unseen.
# They're thinking & feeling 
She’s probably feeling incredibly vulnerable and raw, even if she’s not saying it outright. She knows she’s gained weight. She knows you’re fit and healthy, and that comparison is probably eating away at her whether she admits it or not. Your presence, even when you're being kind, might trigger her insecurities—not because you’re doing anything wrong in essence, but because she’s projecting her self-judgment onto you. So when you start talking about calories and maintenance and logic, it might feel to her like you’re confirming her deepest fear: that she’s failing, that she’s not good enough, that even the person who loves her is disappointed.

She probably wants to change, but she might not have the self-trust or emotional resilience right now to actually take the steps. That creates a cycle: she says she wants to lose weight, you offer support, she feels judged, she shuts down, and then nothing changes. It’s safer, emotionally, to blame you than to sit in her own discomfort. She might also feel like your support is conditional—like, even if you say you love her no matter what, she may interpret your help as a sign that you’re low-key waiting for her to become someone else.

Also, there’s a good chance she’s feeling shame—deep, corrosive shame—not just about her body, but about not following through. And shame doesn’t motivate; it paralyzes. She might be scared that if she really tries and fails, then it confirms everything she fears about herself. So instead, she argues or avoids. None of that means she doesn’t care about you or appreciate what you’re doing—but she’s probably emotionally overwhelmed and not really able to meet you where you are.
# My response 
Hey man, I hear you. You’re in a tough spot—trying to be loving and real, and it feels like no matter what you do, it gets misread. That’s exhausting. And honestly, I think part of your frustration is coming from feeling like you’re being punished for giving a damn. Like, if you didn’t care, you wouldn’t be in this mess—but because you do, it’s all landing on you.

But here’s the thing—and I’m saying this not to side with her, but to help you both—this might not be a problem that logic can solve. You’re giving her facts, but she’s fighting feelings. That’s a mismatch. She needs emotional safety before she can really digest any of the practical advice. Right now, even well-meant truth might feel like criticism to her, especially coming from someone she loves and admires and maybe even compares herself to.

What if you pulled back a little from trying to “fix” it and focused more on validating her experience? Like, instead of pointing out what she could do better, just sit with her frustration. Say, “I know this feels hard, and I want to support you in a way that feels good to you. What would that look like?” And I know that might feel like enabling or sugarcoating—but sometimes people need a little space to feel seen before they can get into action mode.

Also—check in with yourself. If you’re carrying resentment, especially around the imbalance of effort (financial, emotional, etc.), that stuff’s going to leak out whether you want it to or not. Maybe it’s time to talk about that openly, too—not just about her weight, but about how the whole dynamic is affecting you.

You’re not wrong to want honesty. But maybe what she needs first is connection. Then the honesty can land.
Deepseek-r1
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. # I'm thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>
