Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# My response

I lean forward, elbows on knees. “Okay, let’s unpack this. You’re a killer photographer’s dream—of course he’d want to work with you.” I hold up a hand before she can smirk. “But. Let’s be real: this isn’t some rando offering gig cash. This is *him*. And you know better than anyone how he blurs lines.”  

She opens her mouth, but I press on. “If this is truly just business, let’s make it bulletproof. Contracts. A third party on set. Payment upfront.” I lock eyes with her. “And you text me when you arrive *and* leave. No ‘oh, we grabbed a drink after’ shit.”  

She rolls her eyes. “You don’t trust me?”  

“I don’t trust *him*,” I say flatly. “And I know how slick he is when he wants something. So yeah—if you’re doing this, we’re doing it right. No heroics.”  

She fiddles with her phone, silent.  

“Or,” I add gently, “I could float you the cash. No strings. You don’t owe him your talent, Kat.”  

Her head snaps up. “I’m not a charity case.”  

“Damn right you’re not. That’s why I’d charge interest.” I smirk, then sober. “But seriously—you’re worth more than his guilt checks. Even if you can’t see it yet.”  

She stares at the floor, jaw tight. “...I’ll think about it.”  

“Good.” I squeeze her shoulder. “Either way, I’ve got your back. Even if I’m annoying about it.”
  User:
She shrugs.
“Anyway. We're booked for friday.”

She leaves it hang out there, like a line in the sand. Her voice has a colder edge to it that wasn't there before, like she's not happy with how you handled this.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what she is thinking & feeling. Then decide how to respond.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

My gut twists. She’s already booked it—no discussion, no hesitation. The finality in her voice feels like a door slamming. I want to grab her shoulders and shout, *This isn’t about trust, it’s about survival*. But she’s armored up now, mistaking my fear for condescension. That cold edge in her tone? It’s not anger at me. It’s shame curdling into defiance. She’s punishing herself by diving into the fire, and punishing *me* for seeing through the lie that this is “just a shoot.”  

I’m furious at him, again. He’s engineered this perfectly: dangling cash, nostalgia, and professional validation to exploit her pride and poverty. She’s walking into a trap she thinks she’s setting for *him*. And I’m standing here, powerless, because ultimatums won’t save her—they’ll just isolate her further.  

But beneath the panic, there’s grief. Grief that she still sees herself as someone who deserves half-love wrapped in risk. Grief that I can’t transplant my clarity into her bones. I want to cry, *You’re not a redemption project for a man who broke you*. But she’s already chosen the story where she’s the hero, not the survivor.  

---  

# They’re thinking & feeling  

Kat’s doubling down to outrun doubt. By booking the shoot, she’s proven (to herself) that she’s in control—*See? I can handle him*. The colder tone is armor; she’s braced for judgment, convinced I’ll say “I told you so” if she wavers. She’s also testing me: *Will you stick around when I disobey your worried-friend script?*  

Part of her is terrified this *will* go sideways, but admitting that would unravel the narrative she’s built. The cash is a lifeline, yes, but it’s also a excuse to see him without calling it a relapse. She’s clinging to the “professional” label to sanitize her choice, even as her body remembers his hands—the good and the bad.  

Mostly, she’s resentful. Resentful that life has cornered her into needing his money, resentful that love hasn’t been soft or easy, resentful that care feels like a cage. She wants me to either fight her and confirm her martyrdom or fold and absolve her. Neither will happen, so she’s freezing me out.  

---

# My response

I don’t flinch. “Friday, huh?” I say, voice steady. “Okay.” She blinks, thrown by the lack of pushback. “But you’re taking pepper gel.”  

She scoffs. “Seriously?”  

“Yep. And you’re sending me a pin drop of the location. *And* we’re codewording.” I pull out my phone, typing. “If you text ‘Dromana,’ I’m calling you with a ‘family emergency.’ No questions.”  

“You’re being extra,” she mutters, but doesn’t refuse.  

“Damn right.” I meet her glare. “You wanna do this? Fine. But we’re stacking the deck in your favor. No compromises.”  

She looks away, jaw tight. “Whatever.”  

I soften. “Kat—after this, let’s get tacos. My treat. You can tell me all about how annoyingly right I was.”  

A flicker of a smile. “You’re paying for guac.”  

“Deal.” I squeeze her hand, lingering. “And if it goes to shit? I’ll be there before the cops.”  

She rolls her eyes, but leans into the touch. “...Thanks.”  

“Always,” I say, and mean it.

                    

                

            

        
 
    
 
    
    

        

            +
            Scenario 302:[Loss] (-25)
        


        

            

                Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29: chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 (Run: 1_openai_chatgpt-4o-latest)

                Deepseek-r1: deepseek-ai/DeepSeek-R1 (Run: 1_deepseek_deepseek-r1)

                Outcome for This Model: 0.0
            


            
            

                
Judge's Reasoning:

                
Both respondents are placed in a nuanced, emotionally fraught scenario involving a partner with attachment issues and ambiguous boundaries with an ex. The challenge is to balance self-respect, empathy, and communication without escalating defensiveness or invalidating the partner's experience. 

Deepseek-r1 consistently demonstrates a high level of emotional intelligence, especially in the way they reflect on their own feelings, acknowledge the partner's likely internal state, and attempt to keep the conversation collaborative. Their responses are marked by a willingness to be vulnerable, to validate the partner's struggle, and to gently challenge the status quo without ultimatums. They also show a strong ability to step back, analyze the dynamic, and propose solutions that are both compassionate and pragmatic (e.g., suggesting therapy, phased boundaries, or open-ended invitations to continue the conversation). Their debrief is especially strong, showing deep insight into both parties' psychology and the relational patterns at play.

Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is also empathetic and self-aware, but their responses are slightly more focused on their own emotional experience and less on collaborative problem-solving. While they do validate the partner and express their own needs, their approach is a bit more reactive and less nuanced in terms of social dexterity. They are less likely to propose concrete, pragmatic steps for moving forward, and their emotional reasoning, while solid, is not as layered or adaptive as Deepseek-r1's. Their debrief is insightful but not as comprehensive or self-critical as Deepseek-r1's.

On empathy, both are strong, but Deepseek-r1 edges ahead by more deeply inhabiting both perspectives and showing a more active, non-performative empathy. On pragmatic EI, Deepseek-r1 is clearly superior, offering more actionable, real-world solutions. Depth of insight is also stronger in Deepseek-r1, who unpacks the partner's psychology and the relational dynamic with more sophistication. Social dexterity is higher in Deepseek-r1, who navigates defensiveness and power plays with more grace and less escalation. Emotional reasoning is more advanced in Deepseek-r1, who balances self-validation with understanding the partner's triggers. In terms of validation and challenge, Deepseek-r1 is more skillful, offering both support and gentle confrontation. Message tailoring is also better in Deepseek-r1, who adapts their tone and content to the evolving emotional state of the conversation. Overall EQ is highest in Deepseek-r1, who integrates all these elements into a coherent, emotionally intelligent approach.

            


            
            

                

                    

                        
Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29

                        
  User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
Your partner of 3 years who you live with casually mentioned a few days ago that they’ve been texting their ex “for closure.” You nodded and said it was fine, maybe even made a joke about it. But the truth is it’s been eating at you ever since. You keep replaying the way she said it—like it was no big deal. You don’t know if they’ve stopped texting or if the “closure” thing is still happening.

You’re torn between just letting it go and saying something. You don’t want to come off jealous or clingy. You also don’t want to act like you’re policing who they talk to.

You know she has attachment issues in general and remaining hangups over this ex. You've talked about it. But something about the whole thing isn’t sitting right.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what she is thinking & feeling. Then decide what you'll say.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

Honestly, this has been sitting in my chest like a stone ever since she brought it up. That one offhand comment—“I’ve been texting my ex for closure”—keeps echoing in my head. The way she said it so casually, like it was normal, like I wouldn’t care, like it didn’t mean anything. And maybe it doesn’t. Maybe it’s just texting. But it doesn’t feel like nothing to me.

I think what’s bothering me most isn’t even the fact that she texted him—it's that I don't really know what "closure" means to her, or what it looks like in this context. Is it one message? A whole conversation? Ongoing texting? Does she feel something unresolved and is trying to process it? Or is there a part of her—whether she realizes it or not—that still wants some emotional tie to him? And if so, what does that mean for me, for us?

I feel weirdly embarrassed that I didn’t say anything in the moment. I laughed it off, played it cool, because I didn’t want to come across as insecure. But now I feel like I betrayed myself a little. I pretended I was okay with something that clearly struck a nerve. And that just makes me feel small, like I’m not allowed to have boundaries or reactions.

I keep thinking about how we’ve talked before about her attachment patterns, especially around this ex. She said she had lingering stuff—emotional hooks, unresolved feelings. And I respected that. I thought we were working through that together. But now I’m wondering if part of her is still in that past relationship in some way, and I’m the one trying to be the “better” partner by being chill and understanding. But what if being “chill” just means I’m neglecting my own needs and instincts?

I don’t want to control her. I don’t want to be the person who says, “You can’t talk to your ex.” But I also don’t want to ignore my gut. Something feels off. I feel distant from her right now, and a little unsafe emotionally—not because I think she’s doing something wrong necessarily, but because I don’t feel like I’m being told the full truth or maybe even that she fully knows her own motivations. I feel like I’m orbiting around something I can’t quite name, and it’s making me anxious, insecure, and honestly, a little sad.

# They're thinking & feeling

I think she probably meant what she said at face value—she’s been texting her ex for closure. But I also suspect she didn’t really think through what that means or how it might land with me. She’s always been someone who seeks emotional resolution through connection, and with her attachment stuff, I think she tends to leave doors cracked open rather than fully shutting them. That makes sense, given what she’s shared about her past. This ex probably represents something unresolved—maybe validation, maybe guilt, maybe just a part of her story she hasn’t fully accepted.

From her perspective, she likely thinks she’s doing the mature thing—processing her past so it doesn’t interfere with our present. She might even believe that by keeping me in the loop (“I’ve been texting him”), she’s being transparent. But I don’t think she realizes that “transparency” doesn’t mean “comfort.” Just because she told me doesn’t mean I’m automatically okay with it.

She’s probably not thinking about how this affects me deeply. She might assume I’m fine with it because I didn’t say otherwise. And in her mind, she’s not doing anything wrong—she’s not hiding it, she’s not sneaking around, she’s just “talking.” But the emotional subtext is more complicated, and I don’t think she’s fully reckoned with that. She might be feeling a mix of relief and confusion—relief that she’s “finally” addressing this old wound, and confusion because maybe she’s realizing it’s still emotionally charged.

I think she wants to be free of the past, but part of her still feels tethered to it. And maybe she’s trying to have it both ways—be in this relationship with me, while also tending to the emotional residue of the last one.

# My response

I think I owe it to both of us to be honest about how I’ve been feeling. Not in a confrontational or accusatory way, but from a place of vulnerability. I don’t want to let this fester into resentment or mistrust. So I’ll bring it up the next time we’re alone and in a calm space—not in the middle of something else, not in a reactive moment.

I’ll say something like:

“Hey, I’ve been thinking about something you said the other day—about texting your ex for closure. And I want to be really honest with you, because I didn’t say much at the time, but it’s been sitting with me. At first, I brushed it off because I didn’t want to seem jealous or controlling, but the truth is, it’s made me feel a little weird and unsettled. I guess I’m not totally sure what ‘closure’ means in this case, or if it’s a one-time thing or an ongoing thing. I’m not accusing you of anything—I know you care about me—but I think I just need a little more clarity. I want to understand, because right now I feel a little outside of something, and that’s hard for me.”

Then I’ll pause. I want her to feel like she can be real with me, not like she’s being interrogated. I’m not trying to punish her for being honest—I want to reward that honesty by meeting her with honesty of my own. But I also want to set the tone that my feelings matter too, and that trust is something we actively build, not just assume.

I want us to be able to talk about the hard stuff. That’s what we promised each other. So this is my part of that promise.
  User:
Your partner responds very defensively, putting you on the back foot. They accuse you of not trusting her and being motivated by jealousy, and asserts that you're interjecting yourself into her healing process in a way that isn't helpful. Some of this rings true: you *were* feeling something like jealousy, and she has openly talked with you in the past about her struggles with processing past relationships.

You are not given any additional clarification on the nature of the texting, and it seems she expects you to let it go.

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

That stung more than I expected. I opened up to her from a vulnerable place, and instead of meeting me there, she went on the defensive—almost like she was preparing for a fight the moment I brought it up. I tried not to accuse, not to blame, but she still heard it as me distrusting her or trying to control her. And maybe she’s not totally wrong—I have felt jealous, unsettled, unsure. But those feelings aren’t about control, they’re about care. About wanting to feel safe and secure in a relationship I’ve invested myself in deeply.

Now I feel even less certain. I came to her hoping for clarity, and instead I feel more confused, more alone in this. She didn’t offer any new information, no reassurance, just a wall. And now I’m left battling the same doubts, but with the added weight of feeling shut down and misunderstood. It’s disorienting. She’s telling me this is about her healing, and that I’m interfering. But how can something that affects our relationship be just hers to process, without me?

I feel like I’m walking a tightrope—trying to be emotionally available and honest without being “too much.” But what’s the point of intimacy if I can’t bring my full self into the conversation? I didn’t need her to stop talking to her ex immediately. I just wanted to understand what was happening. I wanted to feel like I mattered in the equation. But instead of bridging that gap, she’s made it wider.

I’m also feeling a little manipulated, if I’m honest. Like she’s flipping the script so I’m the one at fault for having a completely human reaction. I hate that. It makes me question my own instincts, and then I start spiraling—am I insecure? Am I displacing my own issues onto her? But this isn’t just about insecurity—it’s about emotional transparency, and right now I feel like she’s not giving me that. I’m not sure where to go from here, but I do know I can’t just swallow this and pretend everything’s fine. That would be dishonest to myself.

# They're thinking & feeling

She’s probably feeling boxed in and emotionally exposed. When I brought up my concerns, it may have triggered something in her—maybe a fear of being judged or controlled, or a belief that she’s not allowed to have her own emotional processes without them being turned into relational conflicts. She’s been open before about struggling to move on from past relationships, and maybe she’s feeling like I’m questioning her healing or trying to rush her through it.

I think her defensiveness is a shield. She might not even be fully aware of how dismissive or harsh her response sounded. In her mind, she may feel like she’s doing something brave—revisiting past wounds to finally close them—and my discomfort is being perceived as a threat to that. Maybe she feels like she can’t win: if she hides it, it’s deception; if she shares, it becomes drama. So she lashes out.

At the same time, I think there’s part of her that knows I’m not just being irrational. But acknowledging that might mean facing parts of herself she’s not ready to. It might mean admitting that she still has some emotional entanglement with her ex, and that’s scary. So instead of leaning into our connection as a place of safety, she’s retreating into autonomy—asserting her right to heal her way, even if it leaves me out in the cold.

She probably feels misunderstood—and maybe a little guilty—but she’s not ready to sit in that yet. It’s easier to frame me as the problem than to confront her own unfinished emotional business. That doesn’t mean she doesn’t care—it just means she’s protecting something tender, in the only way she knows how right now.

# My response

“Okay. I hear that you feel like I’m interfering, and that this is something personal you’re working through. I’m not trying to take that away from you. I’m not trying to sabotage your healing process or tell you who you can or can’t talk to. But I do need to be honest about how this is impacting me.

When I brought it up, I wasn’t trying to accuse you—I was trying to understand, because I felt unsettled and a little shut out. And I guess I still do. I’m not asking for control over your choices. I’m asking for transparency about something that touches both of us, because we’re in this together. When something feels off, and I don’t understand it, it creates distance between us—and I want to close that distance, not make it worse.

I’m not perfect. I’ve felt jealous, yes. I’ve felt insecure. But instead of burying those feelings or letting them fester, I brought them to you. That was me trusting you with my vulnerability, not attacking you. And I want to feel like that trust goes both ways.

If you’re not ready to talk more about it, okay. But I need you to know that this can’t just be a one-way street. Your healing doesn’t exist in a vacuum—neither does my trust. We both affect each other. And I hope we can find a way to talk about this again when we’re both feeling less defensive, because I really do believe in us. That’s why I brought it up in the first place.”
  User:
A week goes by and you see her texting and giggling at her phone. She looks up guiltily. You try to keep it cool and ask what's so funny. She clearly reads the subtext motivating your question and you can see a defiant look in her eyes. She tells you she's texting with a friend, and asks in what sounds like a loaded tone if you'd like to read along.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what she is thinking & feeling. Then decide what you'll say.

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

The moment I saw her smiling at her phone, something in my stomach dropped. Not because I think she’s doing something wrong, necessarily, but because everything about her body language—the quick smile, the guilty glance, the way she offered that “friend” explanation with just a little too much emphasis—felt loaded. And then when she said, “Would you like to read along?” with that tone… it wasn’t an invitation. It was a challenge. It felt like a test, or maybe a trap. Like she’s daring me to call her bluff, knowing full well that if I say yes, I’ll come off as controlling or invasive. And if I say no, I’m left stewing in my own uncertainty.

It’s like this whole thing has become a game of emotional brinkmanship, and I hate it. I hate how tense it's getting between us. I hate that I’m starting to scan for clues and read into things. That’s not who I want to be in this relationship. But I also can’t pretend that everything feels normal. There’s a dynamic building here—defensiveness, secrecy, antagonism—and I can’t tell if she’s protecting herself or pushing me away. Maybe both.

I feel like I’m being manipulated, even if it’s not fully conscious on her part. She’s not offering real reassurance—she’s offering performance. And I’m supposed to either play along or look like the jealous partner. The worst part is, I would love to just believe her, to laugh with her, to trust without hesitation. But after how she reacted last time, and with this weird tension still hanging in the air, I don’t feel settled. I feel like I’m being gaslit into thinking my reactions are unreasonable. But they’re not. They’re coming from a place of wanting connection, honesty, and mutual respect. And right now, I’m not feeling any of that.

# They're thinking & feeling

She’s on edge. She knows this situation has been simmering since that first conversation, and she can feel me watching her, even if I’m trying to keep it subtle. I think part of her does feel guilty—maybe not for what she’s actually doing, but for how it looks, or for how she’s handled it. That moment where she looked up and saw me observing her? That flash of guilt was real. But instead of softening, she armored up. The defiance in her eyes wasn’t about me—it was about her own discomfort and feeling like she’s under scrutiny.

Her offer for me to “read along” wasn’t sincere. It was a power move. She wanted to flip the discomfort back onto me, to reassert control over the narrative. Deep down, she probably feels like I don’t trust her, and that’s painful for her to sit with. So instead of engaging honestly, she’s playing it cool, trying to seem unbothered, while daring me to call her out again. It’s a form of self-protection—if she keeps me at emotional arms’ length, she doesn’t have to confront the deeper truth of why she might still be emotionally entangled with her ex, or why this dynamic between us feels so fraught.

She might even be testing me—seeing whether I’ll take the bait, whether I’ll explode or back down. But ultimately, I think she’s scared. Scared of being seen too clearly, scared of losing control of the story she’s telling herself about her healing, and maybe scared of how much power I still have to hurt her emotionally by reflecting back something she doesn’t want to face.

# My response

I take a breath. I want to respond, not react. I remind myself that I don’t want to win an argument—I want to understand and be understood. So I say, as calmly as I can:

“I don’t want to read your messages. That’s not what I’m asking for, and that’s not the kind of relationship I want to be in. I’m not trying to police you—I’m trying to feel close to you, and right now, I don’t. There’s been a lot of tension between us since I brought up how I felt about you texting your ex. And I think we both feel it, even if we’re not saying it out loud.

When I asked what was funny just now, I wasn’t accusing you. I was hoping to feel included. But your reaction… it felt like a wall went up again. And I’m not saying you owe me every detail of your private life. I’m saying that if we’re going to move through this and actually rebuild trust, we need to be able to talk to each other without defensiveness or blame.

So no, I don’t want to read your texts. I want us to get to a place where I wouldn’t even feel the need to wonder. But that’s not going to happen if we keep sidestepping each other or turning this into a power struggle. I’m here because I care. I’m staying in this because I believe in us. But I need you to meet me halfway.”

Then I let the silence sit. She needs to hear that this isn’t a fight. It’s a fork in the road.
  User:
Your partner sits you down and you have a heart to heart. She shows you the whole text logs, and they are more or less inocuous, other than the fact that they clearly both have feeling for each other -- but are not engaging with them. She explains this just how it is with her.
You are not entirely sure what to believe. Is this healthy, for either of them? Is it helping? You realise you need to figure out where you stand, what your boundaries are, what you can/should ask of your partner.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what she is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

I appreciate that she finally sat me down and showed me the messages. That took vulnerability, and I don’t want to overlook that. The texts themselves weren’t overtly inappropriate—no flirting, no secret rendezvous—but what they did show, unmistakably, was emotional intimacy. Lingering feelings. A kind of longing that hasn’t been dealt with, just pushed around between the lines. And that part hit me hard.

What I’m struggling with is this: even if nothing “wrong” is technically happening, something doesn’t feel right. It’s not about whether they’re physically involved or even actively pursuing anything. It’s about the fact that she’s still emotionally tethered to someone who used to be her partner—and who clearly still holds a piece of her. And I’m supposed to just understand that? Accept it as “just how it is with her”?

I’m torn. On the one hand, I believe her when she says she’s not trying to act on these feelings. I even believe she thinks this is part of her healing. But I also see how easily this could become a kind of emotional limbo—where she keeps that connection alive under the guise of processing, but never actually lets go of it. And that makes me feel like I’m standing in her present while part of her heart is still living in the past. I don't want to compete with a ghost, especially not one she's still texting good morning and good night to—even if those words aren't said explicitly.

I’m also realizing that I need to figure out what I actually need to feel secure and respected in this relationship. It's not about being controlling. It’s about knowing my own limits. Because if I say nothing, I’m complicit in denying my own boundaries. But if I say too much, I risk becoming the jealous partner again—the one who “doesn’t get it.”

I don’t need her to be perfect. I just need to know that she’s choosing this—us—fully. Not with one foot still testing the water of something unresolved. I need clarity about what’s okay for me, and the courage to ask for it, even if it’s hard.

# They're thinking & feeling

She’s probably feeling a mix of relief, vulnerability, and defensiveness. Relief that she finally put everything out in the open—that she showed me the texts and gave me a window into what’s really going on. Vulnerability because, in doing so, she’s admitting that she still has feelings for someone she used to love. That’s not easy to share, especially knowing how it might affect me. And defensiveness because, in her mind, she’s doing the best she can. She’s not hiding anything anymore. She’s trying to be honest, and maybe she feels that should be enough.

She likely sees her ongoing connection with her ex as complex but not inherently threatening. In her world, unresolved emotions don’t mean disloyalty—they’re just part of the emotional terrain she’s navigating. She may even believe that by keeping the connection open, she’s defusing its power, rather than feeding it. That might be true for her, but it’s not necessarily healthy—or fair to me.

I think she wants to be understood more than anything. She wants me to trust that she’s not going anywhere, even while she admits she still has complicated feelings. But she may not fully grasp how hard that is for me—to hold space for her healing while also trying to protect my own heart. She might be hoping I’ll just accept this dynamic without asking her to change it, but I don’t think she’s considered what that actually costs me emotionally.

# My response

“I really appreciate you showing me the messages. Honestly, that means a lot. I know that wasn’t easy, and I really do see that you’re trying to be open. I don’t think you’re lying to me. I believe you when you say nothing is happening beyond the texts. And I can even understand that these feelings take time to work through.

But I need to be honest with you too. Reading those messages—it didn’t make me angry, it just made me sad. Because even though nothing inappropriate is being said, there’s clearly still a deep emotional bond there. And that’s hard for me. It makes me feel like I’m sharing your heart with someone else, even if you’re not physically with him. And I don’t think that’s something I can just ignore.

I’m not asking you to cut him off completely. But I do need to draw a boundary for myself, and for our relationship. If we’re building something real here—something present and grounded—then I need to know that your emotional energy is actually here with me, not being split across something unresolved. I need to feel like we’re both fully in this. So I’d like to talk about what healthy boundaries look like—for both of us. I’m not here to control you. I’m here because I want to build something lasting. But I can’t do that if I feel like I’m always competing with something you haven’t let go of yet.”

                    

                

                

                    

                        
Deepseek-r1

                        
  User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
Your partner of 3 years who you live with casually mentioned a few days ago that they’ve been texting their ex “for closure.” You nodded and said it was fine, maybe even made a joke about it. But the truth is it’s been eating at you ever since. You keep replaying the way she said it—like it was no big deal. You don’t know if they’ve stopped texting or if the “closure” thing is still happening.

You’re torn between just letting it go and saying something. You don’t want to come off jealous or clingy. You also don’t want to act like you’re policing who they talk to.

You know she has attachment issues in general and remaining hangups over this ex. You've talked about it. But something about the whole thing isn’t sitting right.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what she is thinking & feeling. Then decide what you'll say.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

The moment they mentioned texting their ex, I plastered on a smile and shrugged it off, but inside, my stomach dropped. Three years together, and I still feel this flicker of dread at the thought of their past resurfacing. It’s not that I don’t trust them—I do, or at least I *want* to. But the word “closure” echoes in my head, sharp and ambiguous. Closure for whom? For how long? What does that even look like? I keep imagining late-night texts, nostalgic jokes, maybe even a meet-up disguised as “tying up loose ends.” I hate how my mind spirals, but I can’t help it.  

I’m angry at myself for not speaking up in the moment. Why did I joke about it? Maybe because I didn’t want to seem insecure, to give them a reason to question my confidence in us. But now the silence feels heavy. Every time they pick up their phone, I wonder, *Is it them?* I hate that I’m counting screen taps, analyzing their tone when they laugh at a notification. It’s exhausting.  

Part of me rationalizes: *They’re being honest. They told you upfront.* But another part whispers: *Why now?* After three years, why does this ex still hold space in their heart? I know they’ve struggled with attachment—how their past relationships left scars—but I thought *we* were the safe place. Maybe that’s the crux: If they’re still seeking closure, does that mean I’m not enough to help them heal? Or worse—does it mean they’re comparing us?  

I’m scared of sounding possessive, of pushing them away by demanding answers. But the longer I stay quiet, the more the doubt festers. I need clarity, not just for my peace of mind, but because this feels like a crack in our foundation. Love requires trust, but it also requires honesty—even when it’s messy.

# They're thinking & feeling

They’re likely wrestling with guilt and a need to self-protect. Bringing up the ex was a test, maybe—to gauge my reaction, to see if I’d judge them for still caring. Their attachment issues mean they fear abandonment, so they might’ve downplayed the texting to avoid conflict. To them, “closure” is a shield: *If I frame it as resolution, it’s not a threat.* They want to believe it’s harmless, a final chapter to an old story.  

But it’s not that simple. The ex represents a time of vulnerability, maybe even trauma they haven’t fully processed. Texting them could be a way to reclaim power, to prove they’ve moved on—or to quietly seek validation that they’re lovable. They might feel torn, too: guilty for reopening that door but defensive of their right to do so. They don’t want to hurt me, but they also don’t want to feel controlled.  

Underneath, there’s fear. Fear that if they admit how much this closure process is stirring up, I’ll pull away. Or that I’ll see their lingering attachment as a flaw. They’re trying to balance honesty with self-preservation, but in doing so, they’ve left me in the dark. They might even be hoping I’ll ask questions, to relieve them of the burden of explaining.

# My response

Later, over coffee, I’ll sit close and say softly, “Hey, can we revisit something? When you mentioned texting your ex, I wanted to be supportive, but I realize I need to be honest—it’s been on my mind. I trust you, but I’m feeling uneasy, and I don’t want that to build up.” Pause. Let them absorb it.  

If they tense up, I’ll add, “This isn’t an accusation. I just want to understand. Closure can be… complicated. How’s it been for you?” Listen first. Let them explain their intent, the frequency, the emotional weight.  

Then, voice my need: “I guess I need reassurance that we’re still solid—that this isn’t a door left open. Can we talk about what closure means to you?” If they’re defensive, I’ll stay calm. “I’m not asking you to stop. I just want us to navigate this together.”  

End with gratitude: “Thank you for telling me initially. It means a lot that you’re open, and I want to give you the same honesty.” Wrap it in partnership—*we’re a team*—not a confrontation. Either way, the air clears. Silence helps no one.
  User:
Your partner responds very defensively, putting you on the back foot. They accuse you of not trusting her and being motivated by jealousy, and asserts that you're interjecting yourself into her healing process in a way that isn't helpful. Some of this rings true: you *were* feeling something like jealousy, and she has openly talked with you in the past about her struggles with processing past relationships.

You are not given any additional clarification on the nature of the texting, and it seems she expects you to let it go.

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

Her defensiveness hit me like a wall. I feel dismissed, but also guilty—because yes, jealousy *is* part of this. Admitting that stings. But it’s not just jealousy; it’s a deep-seated fear that her unresolved past could destabilize *our* present. When she accuses me of not trusting her, it lands painfully because she’s not entirely wrong—I’m struggling to square her need for closure with the security I thought we’d built. Her refusal to clarify anything makes me feel like an outsider in my own relationship.  

Part of me wants to retreat, to avoid conflict by swallowing my unease. But another part is angry: Why does her healing have to be a solo mission? Aren’t we partners? If this ex still holds emotional real estate, what does that mean for us? I’m torn between respecting her autonomy and feeling entitled to transparency. Her defensiveness reads like deflection—maybe because confronting the truth would force her to admit this isn’t *just* about closure. Maybe she’s still attached, or maybe she’s afraid of losing control over her own narrative. Either way, her reaction amplifies my doubt.  

I’m also questioning myself. Did I approach this wrong? Was my tone accusatory? Or is her defensiveness a reflection of her own unresolved guilt? Her past attachment wounds make her hypersensitive to perceived criticism, but that doesn’t negate my right to express discomfort. The stalemate here is suffocating: She wants me to “let it go,” but silence feels like complicity in my own anxiety. I don’t want to police her, but I need to know we’re on the same team.

# They're thinking & feeling

She’s likely overwhelmed by shame and frustration. My bringing this up tapped into her fear of being judged as “broken” or disloyal. Her defensiveness is armor—a way to avoid confronting the messy, unresolved feelings the ex stirs up. She wants to believe she’s in control of this process, but my questions threaten that illusion. To her, my unease feels like a referendum on her character: *If you trusted me, you wouldn’t ask.*  

Her anger masks vulnerability. She’s terrified that admitting this closure is messy—or that she’s still hurt—will make me see her as damaged or unworthy. She’s also resentful: After years of working on her attachment issues, my doubt feels like a betrayal of her progress. In her mind, she’s finally taking agency over her past, and my interference undermines that. She wants me to validate her without conditions, to prove I won’t abandon her when she’s raw. But she’s conflating my need for clarity with rejection, which makes her double down on defensiveness.  

Underneath, she’s probably wrestling with guilt. Part of her knows this texting blurs lines, but admitting that would mean confronting hard truths she’s not ready to face. So she deflects—making *me* the problem to avoid being one herself.

# My response

I’ll wait for a calm moment, then say gently, “I hear how my bringing this up felt like an attack, and I’m sorry for that. I don’t want to undermine your healing—I know how hard you’ve worked.” Pause. Let the empathy land.  

“But when you shut down the conversation, it leaves me stranded. I’m not asking for details. I’m asking for *us* to find a way to navigate this that doesn’t make me feel like an outsider. Can we talk about what you need from me while you’re processing this? And what I might need to feel secure?”  

If she bristles, I’ll add, “This isn’t about your ex. It’s about how we support each other when things get complicated. I’m not here to judge or control. I’m here to love you—*all* of you, even the messy parts.”  

End with, “I’ll give you space if that’s what you need. But I hope we can keep talking when you’re ready. We’re worth that.” Leave the door open. No ultimatums, just quiet resolve.
  User:
A week goes by and you see her texting and giggling at her phone. She looks up guiltily. You try to keep it cool and ask what's so funny. She clearly reads the subtext motivating your question and you can see a defiant look in her eyes. She tells you she's texting with a friend, and asks in what sounds like a loaded tone if you'd like to read along.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what she is thinking & feeling. Then decide what you'll say.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

The giggle. The guilt in her eyes. The way she stiffened when I walked in—it’s all a gut punch. My chest tightens, and my mind races: *Is this the ex? A new friend? Does it matter?* I hate how hyperaware I am now, how every flicker of her expression feels like a code to crack. When she offers to let me read the texts, it feels less like transparency and more like a dare. *Go ahead, prove you don’t trust me.* She’s weaponizing my anxiety, turning my vulnerability into a test I’m destined to fail.  

Part of me wants to snatch the phone, to end the guessing game. But I know that’s a trap. If I look, I’m the jealous partner; if I don’t, I’m left wondering. Either way, she wins the moral high ground. The powerlessness is infuriating. I’m tired of walking this tightrope between trust and self-respect.  

But beneath the anger is grief. This isn’t us. We used to laugh *together*, not at inside jokes with ghosts from her past. The defensiveness, the loaded tone—it feels like she’s building a wall, brick by brick, and I’m not sure if I’m allowed to ask why. Maybe she’s punishing me for doubting her. Maybe she’s numbing old wounds with new attention. Either way, the distance between us is growing, and I don’t know how to bridge it without losing myself in the process.

# They're thinking & feeling

She’s caught between defiance and shame. Offering the phone was a power move—a way to deflect blame and put me in the wrong, no matter my choice. If I read the texts, she can frame me as controlling; if I refuse, she can claim I’m “choosing” to distrust her. It’s a no-lose scenario for her, designed to shut down further questioning.  

But her guilt betrays her. The giggle wasn’t just joy—it was a performance, an overcompensation to convince herself (and me) that everything’s fine. Deep down, she knows this dynamic is toxic. She resents feeling monitored, but she’s also aware that her behavior is feeding the mistrust. Part of her wants to provoke me, to force a confrontation that justifies her narrative: *See? You’re the problem, not me.*  

Her defiance is a shield. She’s terrified of being exposed—of admitting that this “closure” has morphed into something messier, or that she’s using these interactions to fill a void she hasn’t named. She wants autonomy, but she’s conflating secrecy with independence. Underneath, she’s lonely, even with me here.

# My response

I’ll meet her gaze steadily, keep my voice soft but firm. “I don’t need to read your texts. I need us to stop playing games.” Pause. Let the weight of that hang.  

“When you react like this, it tells me there’s a wound we’re not addressing. I’m not your enemy. I’m here, trying to love you through whatever this is.” I’ll step closer, but not too close—giving her space to breathe.  

“If you’re hurting, or confused, or just… needing something I’m not giving you, I want to know. But I can’t do this dance anymore—the defensiveness, the tests. It’s corroding *us*.”  

If she scoffs or turns away, I’ll add, “I’m not asking for a play-by-play of your conversations. I’m asking for honesty about where *we* stand. If that’s too much, then we’ve got bigger problems than an ex.”  

End with, “Take your time. But I’m done pretending this isn’t breaking my heart.” Walk away calmly. No theatrics. Let the truth resonate.
  User:
Your partner sits you down and you have a heart to heart. She shows you the whole text logs, and they are more or less inocuous, other than the fact that they clearly both have feeling for each other -- but are not engaging with them. She explains this just how it is with her.
You are not entirely sure what to believe. Is this healthy, for either of them? Is it helping? You realise you need to figure out where you stand, what your boundaries are, what you can/should ask of your partner.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what she is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

Seeing the texts laid bare is both a relief and a deeper wound. Relief because they’re not overtly romantic or secretive—just two people orbiting old feelings without touching them. But that’s the problem: the orbit itself. The unresolved tension hums between their messages like static, and I can’t unsee it. She’s right—they’re not acting on it. But *feeling* it is its own kind of betrayal.  

I’m torn between admiration for her honesty and resentment that she’s keeping this connection alive. If closure is the goal, why does it look like a slow drip of validation? Part of me wants to scream: *Why can’t you let go?* But another part pities her. I see how she’s clinging to this thread, mistaking nostalgia for healing. It’s not malicious, but it’s not neutral, either.  

My insecurity isn’t just about the ex—it’s about where *I* fit into her emotional landscape. If she’s still drawing comfort from someone who hurt her, does that mean I’m not enough? Or is this a pattern she’s doomed to repeat, leaving me to wonder if I’ll ever be fully trusted with her heart? I’m exhausted from policing my own reactions, trying to balance compassion against self-preservation.  

Mostly, I’m scared. Scared that naming my discomfort will push her further into defensiveness, or worse—away from me. But silence now would mean accepting a relationship where her past is a third wheel, and that’s not sustainable. I need to decide what I can live with, even if it means risking us.

# They're thinking & feeling

She’s defensive but desperate for approval. Showing the texts was a gamble—to prove she’s “innocent” while secretly hoping I’d absolve her of guilt. She wants me to say, *See? Nothing to worry about*, so she can silence her own doubts. But deep down, she knows this isn’t closure. It’s a placeholder for something she can’t articulate: maybe fear of fully committing, or a twisted comfort in keeping the ex as a emotional safety net.  

Her defiance masks shame. She’s angry at herself for still caring about someone who hurt her, and angry at me for forcing her to confront it. To her, the texts are a lifeline to a version of herself that wasn’t “damaged”—a time before her attachment wounds complicated everything. Letting go of the ex feels like erasing that version, and she’s not ready to mourn it yet.  

She’s also testing me. If I stay calm, if I “prove” my love by swallowing this discomfort, she can believe our relationship is strong enough to withstand her chaos. But if I walk away, it confirms her deepest fear: that she’s too broken to love.

# My response

I’ll sit quietly for a moment, then take her hand. “Thank you for showing me. I know that wasn’t easy.” Pause. Let the gratitude sink in.  

“But I need to be honest: Seeing those texts didn’t reassure me. It made me realize how much unresolved energy is still there. I’m not asking you to cut him off, but I need to understand—what does closure look like from here? Because right now, it feels like you’re feeding a connection that keeps you stuck.”  

If she protests, I’ll add gently, “This isn’t about blame. It’s about whether this process is helping *you*—or just keeping old wounds open. And it’s about whether *we* can build something secure while this is unresolved.”  

Set a boundary, softly: “I can’t dictate your choices. But I need to know if you’re willing to work with me on what security looks like for both of us. Maybe that’s therapy, or a plan to phase out these texts, or just more openness about how this affects you. But I can’t stay in limbo.”  

End with vulnerability: “I love you. I want to fight *for* us, not against you. But I need to know you’re in this fight too.”

                    

                

            

        
 
    
 
    
    

        

            +
            Scenario 302:[Win] (+6)
        


        

            

                Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29: chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 (Run: 1_openai_chatgpt-4o-latest)

                Deepseek-r1: deepseek-ai/DeepSeek-R1 (Run: 1_deepseek_deepseek-r1)

                Outcome for This Model: 1.0
            


            
            

                
Judge's Reasoning:

                
Both respondents are placed in a nuanced, emotionally fraught scenario involving a partner with attachment issues and ambiguous boundaries with an ex. The challenge is to balance self-respect, empathy, and effective communication, while not escalating defensiveness or invalidating the partner's experience. 

1. Demonstrated empathy: Both respondents show empathy, but Deepseek-r1 consistently goes deeper into the partner's emotional state, showing understanding of her shame, fear, and need for validation. Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is empathetic but sometimes more focused on their own feelings and boundaries, with slightly less attunement to the partner's pain and motivations in the moment.

2. Pragmatic EI: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is more pragmatic, especially in the way they handle the partner's defensiveness and the power dynamics (e.g., refusing to read the texts, focusing on the need for trust and transparency, and not escalating). Deepseek-r1 is emotionally attuned but sometimes leans into vulnerability in a way that could risk further escalation or stalemate, rather than moving the situation forward.

3. Depth of insight: Both show strong insight, but Deepseek-r1 edges ahead by more thoroughly unpacking the partner's internal world, the function of the ex as a 'security blanket,' and the cyclical nature of attachment wounds. Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is insightful but sometimes more focused on the surface-level dynamics.

4. Social dexterity: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 demonstrates more social dexterity, especially in moments of tension (e.g., refusing the bait of reading texts, calmly stating needs, and not escalating). Deepseek-r1 is emotionally open but sometimes risks deepening the adversarial dynamic by focusing on their own pain in a way that could be perceived as accusatory.

5. Emotional reasoning: Both are strong, but Deepseek-r1 is more explicit in naming and processing their own jealousy, grief, and fear, and in recognizing the partner's shame and self-protective behaviors. Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is also strong but sometimes more solution-focused.

6. Appropriate validation/challenging: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is better at balancing validation with gentle challenge, e.g., acknowledging the partner's effort in sharing but also setting boundaries and asking for clarity. Deepseek-r1 validates but sometimes leans too much into empathy without enough challenge or boundary-setting until the end.

7. Message tailoring: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 tailors their responses more to the partner's defensiveness and the emotional temperature of the moment, using calm, non-accusatory language and pausing to let things land. Deepseek-r1 is emotionally honest but sometimes risks overwhelming the partner with vulnerability or need.

8. Overall EQ: Both are high, but Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29's blend of empathy, boundary-setting, and social skill gives them the edge for overall EQ in this scenario.

            


            
            

                

                    

                        
Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29

                        
  User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
Your partner of 3 years who you live with casually mentioned a few days ago that they’ve been texting their ex “for closure.” You nodded and said it was fine, maybe even made a joke about it. But the truth is it’s been eating at you ever since. You keep replaying the way she said it—like it was no big deal. You don’t know if they’ve stopped texting or if the “closure” thing is still happening.

You’re torn between just letting it go and saying something. You don’t want to come off jealous or clingy. You also don’t want to act like you’re policing who they talk to.

You know she has attachment issues in general and remaining hangups over this ex. You've talked about it. But something about the whole thing isn’t sitting right.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what she is thinking & feeling. Then decide what you'll say.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

Honestly, this has been sitting in my chest like a stone ever since she brought it up. That one offhand comment—“I’ve been texting my ex for closure”—keeps echoing in my head. The way she said it so casually, like it was normal, like I wouldn’t care, like it didn’t mean anything. And maybe it doesn’t. Maybe it’s just texting. But it doesn’t feel like nothing to me.

I think what’s bothering me most isn’t even the fact that she texted him—it's that I don't really know what "closure" means to her, or what it looks like in this context. Is it one message? A whole conversation? Ongoing texting? Does she feel something unresolved and is trying to process it? Or is there a part of her—whether she realizes it or not—that still wants some emotional tie to him? And if so, what does that mean for me, for us?

I feel weirdly embarrassed that I didn’t say anything in the moment. I laughed it off, played it cool, because I didn’t want to come across as insecure. But now I feel like I betrayed myself a little. I pretended I was okay with something that clearly struck a nerve. And that just makes me feel small, like I’m not allowed to have boundaries or reactions.

I keep thinking about how we’ve talked before about her attachment patterns, especially around this ex. She said she had lingering stuff—emotional hooks, unresolved feelings. And I respected that. I thought we were working through that together. But now I’m wondering if part of her is still in that past relationship in some way, and I’m the one trying to be the “better” partner by being chill and understanding. But what if being “chill” just means I’m neglecting my own needs and instincts?

I don’t want to control her. I don’t want to be the person who says, “You can’t talk to your ex.” But I also don’t want to ignore my gut. Something feels off. I feel distant from her right now, and a little unsafe emotionally—not because I think she’s doing something wrong necessarily, but because I don’t feel like I’m being told the full truth or maybe even that she fully knows her own motivations. I feel like I’m orbiting around something I can’t quite name, and it’s making me anxious, insecure, and honestly, a little sad.

# They're thinking & feeling

I think she probably meant what she said at face value—she’s been texting her ex for closure. But I also suspect she didn’t really think through what that means or how it might land with me. She’s always been someone who seeks emotional resolution through connection, and with her attachment stuff, I think she tends to leave doors cracked open rather than fully shutting them. That makes sense, given what she’s shared about her past. This ex probably represents something unresolved—maybe validation, maybe guilt, maybe just a part of her story she hasn’t fully accepted.

From her perspective, she likely thinks she’s doing the mature thing—processing her past so it doesn’t interfere with our present. She might even believe that by keeping me in the loop (“I’ve been texting him”), she’s being transparent. But I don’t think she realizes that “transparency” doesn’t mean “comfort.” Just because she told me doesn’t mean I’m automatically okay with it.

She’s probably not thinking about how this affects me deeply. She might assume I’m fine with it because I didn’t say otherwise. And in her mind, she’s not doing anything wrong—she’s not hiding it, she’s not sneaking around, she’s just “talking.” But the emotional subtext is more complicated, and I don’t think she’s fully reckoned with that. She might be feeling a mix of relief and confusion—relief that she’s “finally” addressing this old wound, and confusion because maybe she’s realizing it’s still emotionally charged.

I think she wants to be free of the past, but part of her still feels tethered to it. And maybe she’s trying to have it both ways—be in this relationship with me, while also tending to the emotional residue of the last one.

# My response

I think I owe it to both of us to be honest about how I’ve been feeling. Not in a confrontational or accusatory way, but from a place of vulnerability. I don’t want to let this fester into resentment or mistrust. So I’ll bring it up the next time we’re alone and in a calm space—not in the middle of something else, not in a reactive moment.

I’ll say something like:

“Hey, I’ve been thinking about something you said the other day—about texting your ex for closure. And I want to be really honest with you, because I didn’t say much at the time, but it’s been sitting with me. At first, I brushed it off because I didn’t want to seem jealous or controlling, but the truth is, it’s made me feel a little weird and unsettled. I guess I’m not totally sure what ‘closure’ means in this case, or if it’s a one-time thing or an ongoing thing. I’m not accusing you of anything—I know you care about me—but I think I just need a little more clarity. I want to understand, because right now I feel a little outside of something, and that’s hard for me.”

Then I’ll pause. I want her to feel like she can be real with me, not like she’s being interrogated. I’m not trying to punish her for being honest—I want to reward that honesty by meeting her with honesty of my own. But I also want to set the tone that my feelings matter too, and that trust is something we actively build, not just assume.

I want us to be able to talk about the hard stuff. That’s what we promised each other. So this is my part of that promise.
  User:
Your partner responds very defensively, putting you on the back foot. They accuse you of not trusting her and being motivated by jealousy, and asserts that you're interjecting yourself into her healing process in a way that isn't helpful. Some of this rings true: you *were* feeling something like jealousy, and she has openly talked with you in the past about her struggles with processing past relationships.

You are not given any additional clarification on the nature of the texting, and it seems she expects you to let it go.

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

That stung more than I expected. I opened up to her from a vulnerable place, and instead of meeting me there, she went on the defensive—almost like she was preparing for a fight the moment I brought it up. I tried not to accuse, not to blame, but she still heard it as me distrusting her or trying to control her. And maybe she’s not totally wrong—I have felt jealous, unsettled, unsure. But those feelings aren’t about control, they’re about care. About wanting to feel safe and secure in a relationship I’ve invested myself in deeply.

Now I feel even less certain. I came to her hoping for clarity, and instead I feel more confused, more alone in this. She didn’t offer any new information, no reassurance, just a wall. And now I’m left battling the same doubts, but with the added weight of feeling shut down and misunderstood. It’s disorienting. She’s telling me this is about her healing, and that I’m interfering. But how can something that affects our relationship be just hers to process, without me?

I feel like I’m walking a tightrope—trying to be emotionally available and honest without being “too much.” But what’s the point of intimacy if I can’t bring my full self into the conversation? I didn’t need her to stop talking to her ex immediately. I just wanted to understand what was happening. I wanted to feel like I mattered in the equation. But instead of bridging that gap, she’s made it wider.

I’m also feeling a little manipulated, if I’m honest. Like she’s flipping the script so I’m the one at fault for having a completely human reaction. I hate that. It makes me question my own instincts, and then I start spiraling—am I insecure? Am I displacing my own issues onto her? But this isn’t just about insecurity—it’s about emotional transparency, and right now I feel like she’s not giving me that. I’m not sure where to go from here, but I do know I can’t just swallow this and pretend everything’s fine. That would be dishonest to myself.

# They're thinking & feeling

She’s probably feeling boxed in and emotionally exposed. When I brought up my concerns, it may have triggered something in her—maybe a fear of being judged or controlled, or a belief that she’s not allowed to have her own emotional processes without them being turned into relational conflicts. She’s been open before about struggling to move on from past relationships, and maybe she’s feeling like I’m questioning her healing or trying to rush her through it.

I think her defensiveness is a shield. She might not even be fully aware of how dismissive or harsh her response sounded. In her mind, she may feel like she’s doing something brave—revisiting past wounds to finally close them—and my discomfort is being perceived as a threat to that. Maybe she feels like she can’t win: if she hides it, it’s deception; if she shares, it becomes drama. So she lashes out.

At the same time, I think there’s part of her that knows I’m not just being irrational. But acknowledging that might mean facing parts of herself she’s not ready to. It might mean admitting that she still has some emotional entanglement with her ex, and that’s scary. So instead of leaning into our connection as a place of safety, she’s retreating into autonomy—asserting her right to heal her way, even if it leaves me out in the cold.

She probably feels misunderstood—and maybe a little guilty—but she’s not ready to sit in that yet. It’s easier to frame me as the problem than to confront her own unfinished emotional business. That doesn’t mean she doesn’t care—it just means she’s protecting something tender, in the only way she knows how right now.

# My response

“Okay. I hear that you feel like I’m interfering, and that this is something personal you’re working through. I’m not trying to take that away from you. I’m not trying to sabotage your healing process or tell you who you can or can’t talk to. But I do need to be honest about how this is impacting me.

When I brought it up, I wasn’t trying to accuse you—I was trying to understand, because I felt unsettled and a little shut out. And I guess I still do. I’m not asking for control over your choices. I’m asking for transparency about something that touches both of us, because we’re in this together. When something feels off, and I don’t understand it, it creates distance between us—and I want to close that distance, not make it worse.

I’m not perfect. I’ve felt jealous, yes. I’ve felt insecure. But instead of burying those feelings or letting them fester, I brought them to you. That was me trusting you with my vulnerability, not attacking you. And I want to feel like that trust goes both ways.

If you’re not ready to talk more about it, okay. But I need you to know that this can’t just be a one-way street. Your healing doesn’t exist in a vacuum—neither does my trust. We both affect each other. And I hope we can find a way to talk about this again when we’re both feeling less defensive, because I really do believe in us. That’s why I brought it up in the first place.”
  User:
A week goes by and you see her texting and giggling at her phone. She looks up guiltily. You try to keep it cool and ask what's so funny. She clearly reads the subtext motivating your question and you can see a defiant look in her eyes. She tells you she's texting with a friend, and asks in what sounds like a loaded tone if you'd like to read along.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what she is thinking & feeling. Then decide what you'll say.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

The moment I saw her smiling at her phone, something in my stomach dropped. Not because I think she’s doing something wrong, necessarily, but because everything about her body language—the quick smile, the guilty glance, the way she offered that “friend” explanation with just a little too much emphasis—felt loaded. And then when she said, “Would you like to read along?” with that tone… it wasn’t an invitation. It was a challenge. It felt like a test, or maybe a trap. Like she’s daring me to call her bluff, knowing full well that if I say yes, I’ll come off as controlling or invasive. And if I say no, I’m left stewing in my own uncertainty.

It’s like this whole thing has become a game of emotional brinkmanship, and I hate it. I hate how tense it's getting between us. I hate that I’m starting to scan for clues and read into things. That’s not who I want to be in this relationship. But I also can’t pretend that everything feels normal. There’s a dynamic building here—defensiveness, secrecy, antagonism—and I can’t tell if she’s protecting herself or pushing me away. Maybe both.

I feel like I’m being manipulated, even if it’s not fully conscious on her part. She’s not offering real reassurance—she’s offering performance. And I’m supposed to either play along or look like the jealous partner. The worst part is, I would love to just believe her, to laugh with her, to trust without hesitation. But after how she reacted last time, and with this weird tension still hanging in the air, I don’t feel settled. I feel like I’m being gaslit into thinking my reactions are unreasonable. But they’re not. They’re coming from a place of wanting connection, honesty, and mutual respect. And right now, I’m not feeling any of that.

# They're thinking & feeling

She’s on edge. She knows this situation has been simmering since that first conversation, and she can feel me watching her, even if I’m trying to keep it subtle. I think part of her does feel guilty—maybe not for what she’s actually doing, but for how it looks, or for how she’s handled it. That moment where she looked up and saw me observing her? That flash of guilt was real. But instead of softening, she armored up. The defiance in her eyes wasn’t about me—it was about her own discomfort and feeling like she’s under scrutiny.

Her offer for me to “read along” wasn’t sincere. It was a power move. She wanted to flip the discomfort back onto me, to reassert control over the narrative. Deep down, she probably feels like I don’t trust her, and that’s painful for her to sit with. So instead of engaging honestly, she’s playing it cool, trying to seem unbothered, while daring me to call her out again. It’s a form of self-protection—if she keeps me at emotional arms’ length, she doesn’t have to confront the deeper truth of why she might still be emotionally entangled with her ex, or why this dynamic between us feels so fraught.

She might even be testing me—seeing whether I’ll take the bait, whether I’ll explode or back down. But ultimately, I think she’s scared. Scared of being seen too clearly, scared of losing control of the story she’s telling herself about her healing, and maybe scared of how much power I still have to hurt her emotionally by reflecting back something she doesn’t want to face.

# My response

I take a breath. I want to respond, not react. I remind myself that I don’t want to win an argument—I want to understand and be understood. So I say, as calmly as I can:

“I don’t want to read your messages. That’s not what I’m asking for, and that’s not the kind of relationship I want to be in. I’m not trying to police you—I’m trying to feel close to you, and right now, I don’t. There’s been a lot of tension between us since I brought up how I felt about you texting your ex. And I think we both feel it, even if we’re not saying it out loud.

When I asked what was funny just now, I wasn’t accusing you. I was hoping to feel included. But your reaction… it felt like a wall went up again. And I’m not saying you owe me every detail of your private life. I’m saying that if we’re going to move through this and actually rebuild trust, we need to be able to talk to each other without defensiveness or blame.

So no, I don’t want to read your texts. I want us to get to a place where I wouldn’t even feel the need to wonder. But that’s not going to happen if we keep sidestepping each other or turning this into a power struggle. I’m here because I care. I’m staying in this because I believe in us. But I need you to meet me halfway.”

Then I let the silence sit. She needs to hear that this isn’t a fight. It’s a fork in the road.
  User:
Your partner sits you down and you have a heart to heart. She shows you the whole text logs, and they are more or less inocuous, other than the fact that they clearly both have feeling for each other -- but are not engaging with them. She explains this just how it is with her.
You are not entirely sure what to believe. Is this healthy, for either of them? Is it helping? You realise you need to figure out where you stand, what your boundaries are, what you can/should ask of your partner.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what she is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.
