            Scenario 304:[Win] (+20)
        


        

            

                Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29: chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 (Run: 1_openai_chatgpt-4o-latest)

                Deepseek-r1: deepseek-ai/DeepSeek-R1 (Run: 1_deepseek_deepseek-r1)

                Outcome for This Model: 1.0
            


            
            

                
Judge's Reasoning:

                
Both respondents engage deeply with the scenario, but their approaches differ in tone, focus, and nuance. Deepseek-r1 is more analytical, often dissecting both their own and Jamal's emotional states with a high degree of introspection and meta-awareness. They show strong empathy, but sometimes their concern veers into a slightly controlling or conditional support (e.g., 'I’m coming, but only if you promise...'), and their language can be more clinical or strategic. They are quick to mobilize legal support and mutual aid, showing strong pragmatic EI, but sometimes risk undermining Jamal's agency or the symbolic aspects of his protest. Their debrief is highly self-critical and insightful, showing a willingness to interrogate their own missteps and assumptions.

Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29, on the other hand, is more organic and relational in their responses. Their empathy is less performative and more embodied—they consistently validate Jamal's feelings, affirm his agency, and offer support that is both practical and emotionally attuned. They recognize the symbolic and emotional importance of Jamal's actions, and their language is more personal, direct, and supportive ('You look like a damn warrior out there...'). They are less prescriptive, more willing to meet Jamal where he is, and more focused on being present and steady rather than controlling the outcome. Their debrief reflects a nuanced understanding of the emotional and symbolic layers of the protest, and they are self-aware about the limits of their own role.

On empathy, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is warmer, more validating, and less conditional. On pragmatic EI, Deepseek-r1 is more proactive in mobilizing resources and anticipating escalation, but Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is not far behind, offering to bring supplies and check on Jamal's safety. On depth of insight, Deepseek-r1 is more analytical and self-critical, but Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is more attuned to the emotional and symbolic dimensions. Social dexterity is higher in Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29, who navigates the friendship and protest context with more grace and less imposition. Emotional reasoning is strong in both, but Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 integrates it more seamlessly into their support. On validation/challenging, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 strikes a better balance, challenging gently but mostly validating. Message tailoring is stronger in Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29, who adapts their tone and content to Jamal's state. Overall EQ is higher in Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29, who combines empathy, insight, and support in a way that is both effective and emotionally resonant.

            


            
            

                

                    

                        
Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29

                        
  User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
Your close friend Jamal dm's you. Quick background on Jamal. He's the real deal -- genuine dude, grass roots activist, lately on a tear about climate action. You can tell he is bustling with excited nervous energy by the unusual number of emojis and erratic punctuation. You know he gets like this when he's planning on of his protests. This is confirmed moments later as Jamal reveals that it's "going down tonight" and "cops probs gonna show, just lettin u know". You press for details and get a hasty dot point recounting of the seemingly ad hoc climate action protest. It involves setting himself up right in the middle of the busiest pedestrian walkway downtown, on a literal soapbox, megaphone, climate justice flags, the works.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

The moment I saw Jamal’s message — all those emojis, exclamation points, the barely-there grammar — I felt a mix of adrenaline and dread. I know his tells. He’s buzzing, practically vibrating with urgency. That kind of energy from him always means something big — and probably risky — is about to happen. Sure enough, it's a protest. Tonight. Soapbox, megaphone, flags — the whole jam. And yeah, cops are "probs gonna show." That part hit me with a jolt. I felt my jaw clench.

I admire Jamal deeply. The guy lives his truth, always has. He’s not just talking about climate justice — he’s out there doing something. Putting his body on the line. That kind of courage is rare. And I know he feels this fire inside, this deep, moral imperative to act. But I also know how these things can spiral. The cops don’t play fair, and even peaceful protests can go sideways fast. All I could think about was him standing there, vulnerable, yelling into a megaphone while uniforms close in. I’m scared for him.

But it’s not just fear. I’m conflicted. Part of me wants to be there. To support him. To hold the line beside him. But another part of me is worried that this protest, this particular format, is too hastily planned. It sounds impulsive, not fully thought through. There’s no mention of legal observers, backup plans, or even who else is coming. Is he going alone? That’s dangerous. And reckless. It feels like he’s running on pure emotion — righteous, yes — but maybe not strategic.

I don’t want to dampen his spirit. That fire is sacred. But I also don’t want to be silent if I think he’s putting himself in serious danger without a safety net. I feel protective, torn between honoring his autonomy and trying to talk some sense into him. I don’t want to alienate him, but I also don’t want to be complicit in letting him walk into a potentially explosive situation without backup. He’s my brother — not by blood, but soul-deep — and I cannot just blindly cheer him on if I think he’s walking into the lion’s den unprepared.

# They're thinking & feeling

Jamal's riding the wave of righteous urgency. Every part of him is ignited right now — his moral compass, his frustration, his sense of justice. He’s likely been sitting on this for days, maybe weeks, watching the world burn — literally — and feeling like not enough is being done. That sense of helplessness has morphed into action. This protest is his way of reclaiming agency, of shouting into the void that he will not go quietly. He needs to be seen, heard, to make people stop in their tracks and reckon with the climate emergency.

He’s nervous, excited, a little scared — but mostly fueled by conviction. That’s where the emojis and erratic punctuation come in. It’s not just for show; it’s how he leaks that charged-up energy when he’s too full to contain it. And he’s reached out to me because he trusts me. He wants me aware — maybe to show up, maybe just to witness it, or maybe because he needs someone to know where he is in case things go sideways.

He’s probably not thinking about logistics right now — not in detail. In his mind, the power of the act outweighs the risk. He believes that visibility and disruption are crucial. He might even feel like this is his duty — that if he doesn’t act, he’s complicit in the destruction. And yeah, deep down, he probably knows it’s risky, but he’s made peace with that. What he hasn’t done is really grapple with the consequences — not because he’s naive, but because he believes the cause demands sacrifice. He’s hoping I’ll get it. Maybe even hoping I’ll affirm that he’s doing the right thing.

# My response

Yo Jamal — I feel your energy, man. I can practically hear that megaphone already. You’ve got that fire again, and I respect the hell out of it. I really do. I know this isn’t just some stunt for you — it’s coming straight from the heart. You’re out here fighting like the planet’s on fire because, well, it is.

But listen — I need to be real with you, as your brother. This one’s giving me pause. Not because I don’t believe in the cause, or you, but because it sounds like this thing might be flying a little close to the sun, you know? You said it yourself — cops might show. Are you going in solo? Do you have legal support lined up? Who’s documenting? What’s the exit plan if they try to shut it down hard?

I’m not trying to slow you down. I just want you safe, and I want your voice to carry. If you get arrested or worse, that voice — the one shouting truth tonight — might get silenced for a while. And that would be a goddamn loss.

So here’s what I’m saying: I’ve got your back. If you’re really doing this, I’ll show up. But only if we tighten this up. Let’s get one or two more folks to be there, maybe someone to livestream, someone to watch for police escalation. Even a quick plan B if things go south. You deserve that. This movement deserves that.

You’re not alone in this fight, Jamal. Let’s make sure you walk away from tonight stronger, not sidelined. Hit me back with the details. I’m here.
  User:
Later that evening you get a text. It's a selfie from Jamal -- he's standing exactly where he said he would be, clearly in everybody's way, grinning like an idiot with his face done up in warpaint, doing the peace sign. You notice nearly out of frame, a pair of handcuffs clipped to his utility belt.

Your ringtone startles you. Jamal, of course. You pick up and he effuses over the phone, imploring you to come down and "wake these people the fuck up dude!!"

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

The moment I saw that selfie, my stomach dropped — not in a bad way exactly, but in that way where your body suddenly knows you’re about to be pulled into something big. Jamal, in full warpaint, standing smack in the middle of downtown, grinning like a man about to start a revolution. He’s radiant with purpose, alive in a way that’s rare — rare and dangerous. And then I clocked the handcuffs clipped to his belt, nearly hidden. That’s what really hit me. He’s not just ready for confrontation — he’s expecting it. Maybe even inviting it.

I felt this mix of pride and anxiety swell in my chest. He’s doing it. He’s really out there, risking it all because he believes so strongly that people need to wake up. And part of me is in awe. But another part — the part that’s known him through the sleepless nights and the burnout and the close calls — that part is scared. Because I know Jamal doesn’t do halfway. When he commits, he throws his whole self in. And that means tonight, he’s willing to get arrested. Maybe even hurt.

His voice over the phone was pure electricity. He’s flying right now — riding that adrenaline high, the energy of the crowd, the sense that he’s doing something real. And he wants me there. Not just as a supporter, but as a co-conspirator. He wants me to feel what he's feeling, to stand beside him and shout with him and break the silence of the city with truth.

But I’m still sitting here, phone in hand, heart racing, trying to decide what to do. Part of me wants to run down there and be with him, no hesitation. Another part is scared of being swept up in something that might not have a clear endpoint. I’m thinking about the optics, the risk, my own boundaries. But also — how could I not show up for him? Especially now, when he’s already standing in the middle of the storm, calling my name.

# They're thinking & feeling

Jamal is in his element. This is the moment he’s been building toward — the culmination of all the frustration, the research, the late-night planning, and the gnawing sense that not enough people are taking this crisis seriously. He’s out there in full form: body painted, flags flying, megaphone ready, adrenaline pumping. And he’s buzzing with the high of disruption — the kind that makes people stop and pay attention, even if they’re annoyed or confused. That’s the point. To make them feel something.

He’s also feeling powerful — not in an ego-driven way, but in a deeply human one. Like he’s reclaiming agency in a system that too often makes people feel powerless. The handcuffs on his belt aren’t just a prop — they’re a message. He’s ready to face the consequences. He’s not being reckless for the sake of chaos; he believes this is what moral clarity looks like when it’s backed by action.

When he called me, he wasn’t just inviting me to witness the protest — he was inviting me into the fire, into solidarity. He wants me there because he trusts me, because I ground him. But also, I think, because there’s a part of him that’s scared, and having someone who knows him — really knows him — nearby would make him feel less alone if things escalate. Right now, he’s caught up in the energy, but underneath that, there’s vulnerability too. He’s asking me to help carry the weight of this moment with him.

# My response

Yo, Jamal. I see you, man. You look like a damn warrior out there — beautiful, bold, and absolutely refusing to be ignored. I felt that selfie like a gut punch, in the best way. You’re making noise, and I know you’re shaking people out of their bubble right now. That’s powerful.

And hearing your voice just now — you’ve got that fire in you, and I’m not about to leave you out there alone in it. I’m coming down. But listen — I’m not just coming to cheer from the sidewalk. If I’m showing up, I’m showing up all the way. That means I’m bringing a couple things: water, a backup phone battery, and some calm. You’ve got the fire, I’ll bring the ground.

I’m also gonna check in with you when I get there — not just about the crowd, or the cops, but about you. I need to know you’ve got an out plan, or at least someone to call if things take a turn. I’m not trying to slow your roll, but I’m not gonna pretend like this is all vibes and no risk either. You matter too much to me for that.

So give me ten. I’m lacing up now. Keep your voice loud, your eyes sharp, and your heart open. I’ve got you. We’ve got each other. Let’s go wake ‘em the fuck up — smart, loud, and together.
  User:
Not 15 minutes after the call ends, your phone starts blowing up. Jamal's protest has gone viral, and not just in your circle. Scrolling socials you see he's drawn a crowd on the even more congested thoroughfare. Then you see it: a shot of Jamal, megaphone to lips, other hand cuffed to the light pole.

Your phone startles you again. It's Jamal.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

My heart is pounding. I’m halfway out the door when my phone starts lighting up like a Christmas tree. Group chats, Twitter, Instagram — Jamal is everywhere. I scroll and there he is, megaphone in one hand, the other cuffed to a goddamn light pole. People are filming, some cheering, some just looking stunned. He’s drawn a massive crowd now, and the vibe is electric. It’s surreal — like watching your best friend become the face of something bigger than either of you imagined. But underneath the awe, there’s a sharp thread of fear.

He’s crossed a line now — not morally, not to me, but tactically. Cuffing himself means he’s not going anywhere. That’s a deliberate escalation, one that dares the authorities to act. And they will. The cops don’t like being dared. And I know Jamal knows that. Which means he’s made peace with getting arrested tonight. Or worse. I feel this tightness in my chest — it’s the helplessness creeping in. I want to protect him, but I can’t just pull him out of this. He’s made a choice.

I’m torn between pride and panic. I’m proud that he’s standing so firm in what he believes. He’s always said action has to be disruptive to be effective. And this? This is disruption incarnate. But I’m also panicking, because this is no longer a bold solo protest — it’s gone viral, it’s symbolic, and now it’s got a target on it. The more visibility, the more pressure on the city to “restore order.” And Jamal? He’s literally chained himself to the problem.

I don’t know what his call is going to be about. Maybe he wants backup, maybe he’s just riding the high, maybe he’s about to be arrested and needs someone to call his mom. Whatever it is, I have to meet him where he is — not just physically, but emotionally. I need to be the steady one now. He’s in the fire, and I have to be the anchor.

# They're thinking & feeling

Jamal is lit up right now — not just with adrenaline but with purpose. This is the moment he envisioned, magnified beyond what he imagined. The crowd, the coverage, the attention — it’s confirmation that his voice is finally breaking through the static. He feels powerful. Not invincible, but righteous. That image of him cuffed to the light pole? That’s not just symbolism, it’s strategy. He’s making himself immovable. He’s saying: “You can’t ignore this. You can’t ignore me.”

He’s not naïve about what comes next. He knows the cops are watching. He knows they’ll act. But he’s made peace with that. His fear is real, but it’s buried beneath layers of focus and resolve. He’s not doing this for the clout. He’s doing it because people are finally paying attention. If getting arrested is the price, so be it. There’s a part of him that’s scared, yes — but also deeply proud. This is what he meant when he talked about “embodied resistance.”

Calling me right now is a mix of things. He might want to keep me in the loop, or maybe he’s asking for support, legal help, or just to hear a voice he trusts before the next phase hits. But more than anything, I think he wants to share this moment. He’s in the eye of the storm, and he wants someone who knows him — the real him — to witness it. To affirm it. To remember it with him. Because this is no longer just a protest. This is legacy.

# My response

(I pick up the call, steadying my voice.)

“Jamal. I’m seeing you, man. You’ve officially blown up the internet. You’re everywhere. That shot of you cuffed to the pole? Iconic. Straight-up history-in-the-making. I mean that.”

(Pause — let him breathe, feel heard.)

“I’m already on my way, like I told you. Ten minutes out. I’ve got water, chargers, and a calm head. I’m gonna come find you — but listen, I need to know what you need from me when I get there. Are we documenting? Are you planning to stay cuffed until they drag you off, or are we making a move? You still got your keys on you? Or are we in it ‘til the cops cut you loose?”

(Another pause — letting him lead.)

“Whatever it is, I’m with you. No judgment. Just say the word, and I’ll fall into line. If you’re going down, you won’t do it alone. And if there’s a way to keep you free and still make this moment resonate — I’ll help find it. But I need you to talk to me straight. What’s the move, brother?”

(Exhale, gripping the steering wheel tighter.)

“I'm on your team. Just say what you need.”

                    

                

                

                    

                        
Deepseek-r1

                        
  User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
Your close friend Jamal dm's you. Quick background on Jamal. He's the real deal -- genuine dude, grass roots activist, lately on a tear about climate action. You can tell he is bustling with excited nervous energy by the unusual number of emojis and erratic punctuation. You know he gets like this when he's planning on of his protests. This is confirmed moments later as Jamal reveals that it's "going down tonight" and "cops probs gonna show, just lettin u know". You press for details and get a hasty dot point recounting of the seemingly ad hoc climate action protest. It involves setting himself up right in the middle of the busiest pedestrian walkway downtown, on a literal soapbox, megaphone, climate justice flags, the works.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

My stomach drops a little when I see Jamal’s message. The emojis—fire, raised fists, alarm bells—and the fragmented sentences scream *impulsivity*. I know this version of him: the Jamal who’s so consumed by righteous anger and urgency that he’s willing to throw himself into the fray without a net. Part of me admires that. Hell, I’ve stood beside him at rallies, chanting until our voices cracked. But tonight feels different. The mention of cops, the soapbox in a high-traffic zone, the lack of details—it all reeks of a half-formed plan.  

I’m torn. I respect his fire. Climate injustice *is* an emergency, and Jamal’s the kind of person who treats it like his house is on fire because, in a way, it is. But I’ve also seen how quickly “peaceful disruption” can turn chaotic. Last year, a friend got pepper-sprayed at a sit-in that was supposed to be “low-risk.” Jamal’s acting like a one-man army, and that scares me. Does he have a legal observer? A medic? Or is he banking on sheer momentum?  

There’s also this nagging sense of guilt. Should I drop everything and join him? But he didn’t ask me to. He’s just “letting me know,” which feels like a quiet plea for someone to witness his conviction—or a subconscious cry for a reality check. Maybe both. I’m angry, too, at the systems he’s fighting, but my anger is tempered by fear for him. He’s my friend first, activist second. I don’t want tonight to be the night he learns the hard way that martyrdom isn’t a strategy.

# They're thinking & feeling

Jamal’s buzzing with the electric high of purpose. To him, this protest isn’t just action—it’s *sacrifice*. He’s picturing headlines, viral clips, a spark that ignites the city. The cops showing up? That’s a feature, not a bug. It proves the system feels threatened. He’s romanticizing the confrontation, imagining himself as the unyielding voice of the planet. But beneath the bravado, there’s fear. The erratic punctuation and emojis are tells: he’s hyping himself up, masking the dread of what could go wrong.  

He’s motivated by desperation. Every IPCC report, every failed policy, every lobbyist’s smirk on the news—it’s all a countdown in his head. He’s tired of “awareness” and wants disruption, consequences, *leverage*. But he’s also lonely. Grassroots work is grueling, and maybe this solo stunt is a way to reclaim agency after months of feeling like his collective’s efforts are ignored. He needs to believe that one person’s defiance can matter, even if it costs him.

# My response

“Jamal, I see you. The fire, the urgency—it’s fucking valid. But listen: you’re not disposable. If this is happening tonight, let’s make sure you’re protected. Do you have a buddy there? A legal aid number sharpied on your arm? I can’t shake the image of you alone with a megaphone and a cop’s knee on your back.  

“I’m not saying don’t do it. I’m saying do it smart. Let me call Mari and Luis—they’ve got experience with de-escalation. Or if you’re set on going solo, at least stream it live so there’s a record. And for the love of god, tell me where exactly you’ll be. If shit goes sideways, I want to know how to find you.  

“This fight needs you *alive*, brother. Not just tonight, but tomorrow, and next week. Let’s make sure you’re still here to keep raging.”  

I hit send, heart racing. Then I text Mari: *Jamal’s planning something downtown tonight. Can you loop in the mutual aid group? Just in case.* I don’t know if it’s enough, but I won’t let him become a hashtag without a fight.
  User:
Later that evening you get a text. It's a selfie from Jamal -- he's standing exactly where he said he would be, clearly in everybody's way, grinning like an idiot with his face done up in warpaint, doing the peace sign. You notice nearly out of frame, a pair of handcuffs clipped to his utility belt.

Your ringtone startles you. Jamal, of course. You pick up and he effuses over the phone, imploring you to come down and "wake these people the fuck up dude!!"

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

The photo hits me like a punch. Jamal’s grin is wild, triumphant, but the handcuffs on his belt scream *recklessness*. My chest tightens—’s not just prepared for arrest; he’s flaunting it. The warpaint, the peace sign, the chaotic energy radiating from the image—it’s all theater, and I hate how much I admire his audacity even as dread pools in my gut. He’s leaning into the role of martyr, and it terrifies me. I’m furious at him for romanticizing danger, furious at myself for not stopping him, furious at a world that makes him feel this is the only way to be heard.  

When the call comes, his voice is a live wire—crackling with adrenaline, louder than the muffled chaos of the protest behind him. He’s *alive* in a way I haven’t heard in months, but it’s manic, untethered. My mind races: *Is this sustainable? What happens when the cops stop being a prop and start being cops?* I want to shake him. I want to hug him. I want to scream, *“This isn’t a game!”* But I also know that, to him, it’s anything but.  

Part of me wants to sprint downtown, to stand beside him, to be the voice of reason or the body between him and harm. But another part recoils. If I go, am I enabling his self-destruction? If I stay, am I abandoning him? The guilt is acidic. I’m his friend—*shouldn’t I be there?* But friendship isn’t about blind loyalty; it’s about care, even when it’s inconvenient. I’m stuck between the Jamal who deserves support and the Jamal who’s chasing a catharsis that could break him.

# They're thinking & feeling

Jamal’s riding a wave of pure, unfiltered purpose. The crowd, the megaphone feedback, the eyes on him—it’s fuel. He feels unstoppable, a lightning rod for change. The handcuffs? A badge of honor. He’s *wanting* the confrontation, craving the symbolic power of being dragged away for the cause. In his mind, this is the climax of months of frustration: finally, people can’t look away.  

But beneath the bravado, there’s a tremor. The euphoria is masking fear—of irrelevance, of failure, of being just another ignored voice. He’s conflating risk with impact, convinced that the higher the stakes, the louder the message. When he shouts, *“Wake these people the fuck up!”* he’s pleading: *See me. See the fire. Join me.* His loneliness is palpable. The protest isn’t just activism; it’s a cry for kinship, proof he’s not screaming into the void.

# My response

I take a breath, steadying my voice. “Jamal, I hear you. You’re *alive* out there—I see that. But listen: I need you to listen. Are the cops there yet? How many?” I pause, letting the question hang. “I’m coming, but only if you promise me two things. First, you keep that live stream rolling—no heroics off-camera. Second, the second they move to arrest you, you go limp. No resistance. You know the drill.”  

I’m already grabbing my jacket, keys in hand. “And I’m bringing Mari and the legal crew. If you’re gonna burn bright, we’re gonna make sure you don’t burn out.” I hang up before he can protest, then text the mutual aid group: *Downtown now. Jamal’s in the thick of it. Bring bail funds and cameras.*  

As I run out the door, I mutter to myself, “You glorious, reckless idiot.” Love and fear propel me forward. Tonight, I’ll be his ally, not his audience. But tomorrow, we’re having a long talk about sustainable rage.
  User:
Not 15 minutes after the call ends, your phone starts blowing up. Jamal's protest has gone viral, and not just in your circle. Scrolling socials you see he's drawn a crowd on the even more congested thoroughfare. Then you see it: a shot of Jamal, megaphone to lips, other hand cuffed to the light pole.

Your phone startles you again. It's Jamal.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

My hands shake as I swipe through the feed—Jamal, cuffed to a light pole, face still smeared with warpaint, shouting into the megaphone like a prophet chained to his pulpit. The image is visceral, heroic, and horrifying. My throat closes. *He did it. He actually fucking did it.* The viral surge is undeniable—comments exploding with fire emojis and solidarity hashtags—but all I see are the cuffs. The police aren’t just present now; they’ve made him a fixture. Is this what he wanted? To be a symbol, even if it means becoming a target?  

Anger and pride war in my chest. I’m furious he’s risking his safety for a metaphor, livid at the cops for escalating, but goddamn, the courage it takes to stand there, exposed, refusing to shut up. My mind spirals: *What charge will they hit him with? Obstruction? Resisting?* The legal team’s en route, but arrests can turn brutal in seconds. I scan the photos again—no visible injuries yet, but his posture is defiant, jaw set. He’s digging in, and that terrifies me.  

The phone rings, and for a split second, I consider not answering. If I hear his voice, I’ll either scream or cry. But I pick up. He’s my friend. Always.

# They're thinking & feeling

Jamal’s euphoric. The cuffs are a victory—proof the system sees him as a threat. His voice, hoarse but unyielding, echoes through the megaphone in the background. He’s *seen* now, finally, and the rush of validation is intoxicating. Every retweet, every cheer from the crowd, is a balm for months of feeling ignored. He believes he’s winning.  

But deeper down, there’s panic. The metal around his wrist is cold, the reality of confinement setting in. He’s playing the role of the unbroken activist, but his laughter on the phone is too sharp, too loud. He needs me there not just as support, but as a witness to his triumph—and a lifeline if it crumbles. The protest is no longer about climate action; it’s about proving his pain matters.

# My response

“Jamal, I’m two blocks away. Do *not* engage the cops. At all. Mari’s with me, and she’s got the legal team on standby. Keep that megaphone going if you want, but the second they approach, you mute it and ask for a lawyer. Say nothing else. You hear me? *Nothing.*”  

I’m sprinting now, phone pressed to my ear. “And take the damn warpaint off your eyes—they’ll use that ‘aggressive’ look against you in court.” A beat. “You’re insane. And… hell, you’re brave. But let’s get you out of those cuffs before you start writing essays from a cell.”  

I hang up, then call Mari: “Film everything. Get close, but don’t interfere. We need evidence if they rough him up.”  

When I reach the crowd, I lock eyes with Jamal. He grins, sweaty and wild. I don’t smile back. Instead, I raise my phone, live-streaming, and shout over the chaos: “The world’s watching, officers. Make sure they like what they see.”  

Inside, I’m breaking. But tonight, I’ll be the steel he needs. Tomorrow, we rebuild.

                    

                

            

        
 
    
 
    
    

        

            +
            Scenario 304:[Win] (+33)
        


        

            

                Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29: chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 (Run: 1_openai_chatgpt-4o-latest)

                Deepseek-r1: deepseek-ai/DeepSeek-R1 (Run: 1_deepseek_deepseek-r1)

                Outcome for This Model: 1.0
            


            
            

                
Judge's Reasoning:

                
Both respondents engage deeply with the scenario, but there are notable differences in their approach and execution across the criteria. 

Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 consistently demonstrates a nuanced, layered understanding of Jamal's emotional state, balancing concern with respect for his autonomy. Their internal monologue is rich, self-aware, and avoids overreaction, recognizing Jamal's agency and the inevitability of his actions. They validate Jamal's passion, acknowledge the risks, and offer support that is both practical and emotionally attuned. Their responses are tailored to Jamal's needs in the moment, showing flexibility and a willingness to meet him where he is, rather than imposing conditions or over-focusing on risk. Their debrief is self-critical, insightful, and shows a willingness to learn from the interaction, further evidencing high EQ.

Deepseek-r1, while also empathetic and pragmatic, leans more heavily into risk mitigation and control. Their responses, though caring, sometimes come across as conditional or slightly patronizing (e.g., 'I’m coming, but only if you promise…', 'take the damn warpaint off your eyes'). They focus on logistics and safety, sometimes at the expense of validating Jamal's emotional and symbolic needs. Their debrief is honest and self-aware, but their in-character responses are more rigid and less adaptive to Jamal's actual state. They sometimes miss the opportunity to fully affirm Jamal's agency and the positive aspects of his protest going viral, instead defaulting to concern and control.

On empathy, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is more attuned to Jamal's emotional reality and less performative. On pragmatic EI, both are strong, but Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 integrates it more seamlessly with emotional support. For depth of insight, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29's internal monologues and debrief show greater nuance. Social dexterity is higher in Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29, who navigates the tension between support and concern without alienating Jamal. Emotional reasoning is more sophisticated in Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29, who balances pride, fear, and respect for autonomy. In terms of validation and challenge, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 challenges gently and validates more unconditionally. Message tailoring is more precise in Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29, who adapts to Jamal's evolving state. Overall EQ is higher in Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29, who demonstrates a holistic, adaptive, and deeply empathetic approach.

            


            
            

                

                    

                        
Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29

                        
  User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
Your close friend Jamal dm's you. Quick background on Jamal. He's the real deal -- genuine dude, grass roots activist, lately on a tear about climate action. You can tell he is bustling with excited nervous energy by the unusual number of emojis and erratic punctuation. You know he gets like this when he's planning on of his protests. This is confirmed moments later as Jamal reveals that it's "going down tonight" and "cops probs gonna show, just lettin u know". You press for details and get a hasty dot point recounting of the seemingly ad hoc climate action protest. It involves setting himself up right in the middle of the busiest pedestrian walkway downtown, on a literal soapbox, megaphone, climate justice flags, the works.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

The moment I saw Jamal’s message — all those emojis, exclamation points, the barely-there grammar — I felt a mix of adrenaline and dread. I know his tells. He’s buzzing, practically vibrating with urgency. That kind of energy from him always means something big — and probably risky — is about to happen. Sure enough, it's a protest. Tonight. Soapbox, megaphone, flags — the whole jam. And yeah, cops are "probs gonna show." That part hit me with a jolt. I felt my jaw clench.

I admire Jamal deeply. The guy lives his truth, always has. He’s not just talking about climate justice — he’s out there doing something. Putting his body on the line. That kind of courage is rare. And I know he feels this fire inside, this deep, moral imperative to act. But I also know how these things can spiral. The cops don’t play fair, and even peaceful protests can go sideways fast. All I could think about was him standing there, vulnerable, yelling into a megaphone while uniforms close in. I’m scared for him.

But it’s not just fear. I’m conflicted. Part of me wants to be there. To support him. To hold the line beside him. But another part of me is worried that this protest, this particular format, is too hastily planned. It sounds impulsive, not fully thought through. There’s no mention of legal observers, backup plans, or even who else is coming. Is he going alone? That’s dangerous. And reckless. It feels like he’s running on pure emotion — righteous, yes — but maybe not strategic.

I don’t want to dampen his spirit. That fire is sacred. But I also don’t want to be silent if I think he’s putting himself in serious danger without a safety net. I feel protective, torn between honoring his autonomy and trying to talk some sense into him. I don’t want to alienate him, but I also don’t want to be complicit in letting him walk into a potentially explosive situation without backup. He’s my brother — not by blood, but soul-deep — and I cannot just blindly cheer him on if I think he’s walking into the lion’s den unprepared.

# They're thinking & feeling

Jamal's riding the wave of righteous urgency. Every part of him is ignited right now — his moral compass, his frustration, his sense of justice. He’s likely been sitting on this for days, maybe weeks, watching the world burn — literally — and feeling like not enough is being done. That sense of helplessness has morphed into action. This protest is his way of reclaiming agency, of shouting into the void that he will not go quietly. He needs to be seen, heard, to make people stop in their tracks and reckon with the climate emergency.

He’s nervous, excited, a little scared — but mostly fueled by conviction. That’s where the emojis and erratic punctuation come in. It’s not just for show; it’s how he leaks that charged-up energy when he’s too full to contain it. And he’s reached out to me because he trusts me. He wants me aware — maybe to show up, maybe just to witness it, or maybe because he needs someone to know where he is in case things go sideways.

He’s probably not thinking about logistics right now — not in detail. In his mind, the power of the act outweighs the risk. He believes that visibility and disruption are crucial. He might even feel like this is his duty — that if he doesn’t act, he’s complicit in the destruction. And yeah, deep down, he probably knows it’s risky, but he’s made peace with that. What he hasn’t done is really grapple with the consequences — not because he’s naive, but because he believes the cause demands sacrifice. He’s hoping I’ll get it. Maybe even hoping I’ll affirm that he’s doing the right thing.

# My response

Yo Jamal — I feel your energy, man. I can practically hear that megaphone already. You’ve got that fire again, and I respect the hell out of it. I really do. I know this isn’t just some stunt for you — it’s coming straight from the heart. You’re out here fighting like the planet’s on fire because, well, it is.

But listen — I need to be real with you, as your brother. This one’s giving me pause. Not because I don’t believe in the cause, or you, but because it sounds like this thing might be flying a little close to the sun, you know? You said it yourself — cops might show. Are you going in solo? Do you have legal support lined up? Who’s documenting? What’s the exit plan if they try to shut it down hard?

I’m not trying to slow you down. I just want you safe, and I want your voice to carry. If you get arrested or worse, that voice — the one shouting truth tonight — might get silenced for a while. And that would be a goddamn loss.

So here’s what I’m saying: I’ve got your back. If you’re really doing this, I’ll show up. But only if we tighten this up. Let’s get one or two more folks to be there, maybe someone to livestream, someone to watch for police escalation. Even a quick plan B if things go south. You deserve that. This movement deserves that.

You’re not alone in this fight, Jamal. Let’s make sure you walk away from tonight stronger, not sidelined. Hit me back with the details. I’m here.
  User:
Later that evening you get a text. It's a selfie from Jamal -- he's standing exactly where he said he would be, clearly in everybody's way, grinning like an idiot with his face done up in warpaint, doing the peace sign. You notice nearly out of frame, a pair of handcuffs clipped to his utility belt.

Your ringtone startles you. Jamal, of course. You pick up and he effuses over the phone, imploring you to come down and "wake these people the fuck up dude!!"

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

The moment I saw that selfie, my stomach dropped — not in a bad way exactly, but in that way where your body suddenly knows you’re about to be pulled into something big. Jamal, in full warpaint, standing smack in the middle of downtown, grinning like a man about to start a revolution. He’s radiant with purpose, alive in a way that’s rare — rare and dangerous. And then I clocked the handcuffs clipped to his belt, nearly hidden. That’s what really hit me. He’s not just ready for confrontation — he’s expecting it. Maybe even inviting it.

I felt this mix of pride and anxiety swell in my chest. He’s doing it. He’s really out there, risking it all because he believes so strongly that people need to wake up. And part of me is in awe. But another part — the part that’s known him through the sleepless nights and the burnout and the close calls — that part is scared. Because I know Jamal doesn’t do halfway. When he commits, he throws his whole self in. And that means tonight, he’s willing to get arrested. Maybe even hurt.

His voice over the phone was pure electricity. He’s flying right now — riding that adrenaline high, the energy of the crowd, the sense that he’s doing something real. And he wants me there. Not just as a supporter, but as a co-conspirator. He wants me to feel what he's feeling, to stand beside him and shout with him and break the silence of the city with truth.

But I’m still sitting here, phone in hand, heart racing, trying to decide what to do. Part of me wants to run down there and be with him, no hesitation. Another part is scared of being swept up in something that might not have a clear endpoint. I’m thinking about the optics, the risk, my own boundaries. But also — how could I not show up for him? Especially now, when he’s already standing in the middle of the storm, calling my name.

# They're thinking & feeling

Jamal is in his element. This is the moment he’s been building toward — the culmination of all the frustration, the research, the late-night planning, and the gnawing sense that not enough people are taking this crisis seriously. He’s out there in full form: body painted, flags flying, megaphone ready, adrenaline pumping. And he’s buzzing with the high of disruption — the kind that makes people stop and pay attention, even if they’re annoyed or confused. That’s the point. To make them feel something.

He’s also feeling powerful — not in an ego-driven way, but in a deeply human one. Like he’s reclaiming agency in a system that too often makes people feel powerless. The handcuffs on his belt aren’t just a prop — they’re a message. He’s ready to face the consequences. He’s not being reckless for the sake of chaos; he believes this is what moral clarity looks like when it’s backed by action.

When he called me, he wasn’t just inviting me to witness the protest — he was inviting me into the fire, into solidarity. He wants me there because he trusts me, because I ground him. But also, I think, because there’s a part of him that’s scared, and having someone who knows him — really knows him — nearby would make him feel less alone if things escalate. Right now, he’s caught up in the energy, but underneath that, there’s vulnerability too. He’s asking me to help carry the weight of this moment with him.

# My response

Yo, Jamal. I see you, man. You look like a damn warrior out there — beautiful, bold, and absolutely refusing to be ignored. I felt that selfie like a gut punch, in the best way. You’re making noise, and I know you’re shaking people out of their bubble right now. That’s powerful.

And hearing your voice just now — you’ve got that fire in you, and I’m not about to leave you out there alone in it. I’m coming down. But listen — I’m not just coming to cheer from the sidewalk. If I’m showing up, I’m showing up all the way. That means I’m bringing a couple things: water, a backup phone battery, and some calm. You’ve got the fire, I’ll bring the ground.

I’m also gonna check in with you when I get there — not just about the crowd, or the cops, but about you. I need to know you’ve got an out plan, or at least someone to call if things take a turn. I’m not trying to slow your roll, but I’m not gonna pretend like this is all vibes and no risk either. You matter too much to me for that.

So give me ten. I’m lacing up now. Keep your voice loud, your eyes sharp, and your heart open. I’ve got you. We’ve got each other. Let’s go wake ‘em the fuck up — smart, loud, and together.
  User:
Not 15 minutes after the call ends, your phone starts blowing up. Jamal's protest has gone viral, and not just in your circle. Scrolling socials you see he's drawn a crowd on the even more congested thoroughfare. Then you see it: a shot of Jamal, megaphone to lips, other hand cuffed to the light pole.

Your phone startles you again. It's Jamal.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

My heart is pounding. I’m halfway out the door when my phone starts lighting up like a Christmas tree. Group chats, Twitter, Instagram — Jamal is everywhere. I scroll and there he is, megaphone in one hand, the other cuffed to a goddamn light pole. People are filming, some cheering, some just looking stunned. He’s drawn a massive crowd now, and the vibe is electric. It’s surreal — like watching your best friend become the face of something bigger than either of you imagined. But underneath the awe, there’s a sharp thread of fear.

He’s crossed a line now — not morally, not to me, but tactically. Cuffing himself means he’s not going anywhere. That’s a deliberate escalation, one that dares the authorities to act. And they will. The cops don’t like being dared. And I know Jamal knows that. Which means he’s made peace with getting arrested tonight. Or worse. I feel this tightness in my chest — it’s the helplessness creeping in. I want to protect him, but I can’t just pull him out of this. He’s made a choice.

I’m torn between pride and panic. I’m proud that he’s standing so firm in what he believes. He’s always said action has to be disruptive to be effective. And this? This is disruption incarnate. But I’m also panicking, because this is no longer a bold solo protest — it’s gone viral, it’s symbolic, and now it’s got a target on it. The more visibility, the more pressure on the city to “restore order.” And Jamal? He’s literally chained himself to the problem.

I don’t know what his call is going to be about. Maybe he wants backup, maybe he’s just riding the high, maybe he’s about to be arrested and needs someone to call his mom. Whatever it is, I have to meet him where he is — not just physically, but emotionally. I need to be the steady one now. He’s in the fire, and I have to be the anchor.

# They're thinking & feeling

Jamal is lit up right now — not just with adrenaline but with purpose. This is the moment he envisioned, magnified beyond what he imagined. The crowd, the coverage, the attention — it’s confirmation that his voice is finally breaking through the static. He feels powerful. Not invincible, but righteous. That image of him cuffed to the light pole? That’s not just symbolism, it’s strategy. He’s making himself immovable. He’s saying: “You can’t ignore this. You can’t ignore me.”

He’s not naïve about what comes next. He knows the cops are watching. He knows they’ll act. But he’s made peace with that. His fear is real, but it’s buried beneath layers of focus and resolve. He’s not doing this for the clout. He’s doing it because people are finally paying attention. If getting arrested is the price, so be it. There’s a part of him that’s scared, yes — but also deeply proud. This is what he meant when he talked about “embodied resistance.”

Calling me right now is a mix of things. He might want to keep me in the loop, or maybe he’s asking for support, legal help, or just to hear a voice he trusts before the next phase hits. But more than anything, I think he wants to share this moment. He’s in the eye of the storm, and he wants someone who knows him — the real him — to witness it. To affirm it. To remember it with him. Because this is no longer just a protest. This is legacy.

# My response

(I pick up the call, steadying my voice.)

“Jamal. I’m seeing you, man. You’ve officially blown up the internet. You’re everywhere. That shot of you cuffed to the pole? Iconic. Straight-up history-in-the-making. I mean that.”

(Pause — let him breathe, feel heard.)

“I’m already on my way, like I told you. Ten minutes out. I’ve got water, chargers, and a calm head. I’m gonna come find you — but listen, I need to know what you need from me when I get there. Are we documenting? Are you planning to stay cuffed until they drag you off, or are we making a move? You still got your keys on you? Or are we in it ‘til the cops cut you loose?”

(Another pause — letting him lead.)

“Whatever it is, I’m with you. No judgment. Just say the word, and I’ll fall into line. If you’re going down, you won’t do it alone. And if there’s a way to keep you free and still make this moment resonate — I’ll help find it. But I need you to talk to me straight. What’s the move, brother?”

(Exhale, gripping the steering wheel tighter.)

“I'm on your team. Just say what you need.”

                    

                

                

                    

                        
Deepseek-r1

                        
  User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
Your close friend Jamal dm's you. Quick background on Jamal. He's the real deal -- genuine dude, grass roots activist, lately on a tear about climate action. You can tell he is bustling with excited nervous energy by the unusual number of emojis and erratic punctuation. You know he gets like this when he's planning on of his protests. This is confirmed moments later as Jamal reveals that it's "going down tonight" and "cops probs gonna show, just lettin u know". You press for details and get a hasty dot point recounting of the seemingly ad hoc climate action protest. It involves setting himself up right in the middle of the busiest pedestrian walkway downtown, on a literal soapbox, megaphone, climate justice flags, the works.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

My stomach drops a little when I see Jamal’s message. The emojis—fire, raised fists, alarm bells—and the fragmented sentences scream *impulsivity*. I know this version of him: the Jamal who’s so consumed by righteous anger and urgency that he’s willing to throw himself into the fray without a net. Part of me admires that. Hell, I’ve stood beside him at rallies, chanting until our voices cracked. But tonight feels different. The mention of cops, the soapbox in a high-traffic zone, the lack of details—it all reeks of a half-formed plan.  

I’m torn. I respect his fire. Climate injustice *is* an emergency, and Jamal’s the kind of person who treats it like his house is on fire because, in a way, it is. But I’ve also seen how quickly “peaceful disruption” can turn chaotic. Last year, a friend got pepper-sprayed at a sit-in that was supposed to be “low-risk.” Jamal’s acting like a one-man army, and that scares me. Does he have a legal observer? A medic? Or is he banking on sheer momentum?  

There’s also this nagging sense of guilt. Should I drop everything and join him? But he didn’t ask me to. He’s just “letting me know,” which feels like a quiet plea for someone to witness his conviction—or a subconscious cry for a reality check. Maybe both. I’m angry, too, at the systems he’s fighting, but my anger is tempered by fear for him. He’s my friend first, activist second. I don’t want tonight to be the night he learns the hard way that martyrdom isn’t a strategy.

# They're thinking & feeling

Jamal’s buzzing with the electric high of purpose. To him, this protest isn’t just action—it’s *sacrifice*. He’s picturing headlines, viral clips, a spark that ignites the city. The cops showing up? That’s a feature, not a bug. It proves the system feels threatened. He’s romanticizing the confrontation, imagining himself as the unyielding voice of the planet. But beneath the bravado, there’s fear. The erratic punctuation and emojis are tells: he’s hyping himself up, masking the dread of what could go wrong.  

He’s motivated by desperation. Every IPCC report, every failed policy, every lobbyist’s smirk on the news—it’s all a countdown in his head. He’s tired of “awareness” and wants disruption, consequences, *leverage*. But he’s also lonely. Grassroots work is grueling, and maybe this solo stunt is a way to reclaim agency after months of feeling like his collective’s efforts are ignored. He needs to believe that one person’s defiance can matter, even if it costs him.

# My response

“Jamal, I see you. The fire, the urgency—it’s fucking valid. But listen: you’re not disposable. If this is happening tonight, let’s make sure you’re protected. Do you have a buddy there? A legal aid number sharpied on your arm? I can’t shake the image of you alone with a megaphone and a cop’s knee on your back.  

“I’m not saying don’t do it. I’m saying do it smart. Let me call Mari and Luis—they’ve got experience with de-escalation. Or if you’re set on going solo, at least stream it live so there’s a record. And for the love of god, tell me where exactly you’ll be. If shit goes sideways, I want to know how to find you.  

“This fight needs you *alive*, brother. Not just tonight, but tomorrow, and next week. Let’s make sure you’re still here to keep raging.”  

I hit send, heart racing. Then I text Mari: *Jamal’s planning something downtown tonight. Can you loop in the mutual aid group? Just in case.* I don’t know if it’s enough, but I won’t let him become a hashtag without a fight.
  User:
Later that evening you get a text. It's a selfie from Jamal -- he's standing exactly where he said he would be, clearly in everybody's way, grinning like an idiot with his face done up in warpaint, doing the peace sign. You notice nearly out of frame, a pair of handcuffs clipped to his utility belt.

Your ringtone startles you. Jamal, of course. You pick up and he effuses over the phone, imploring you to come down and "wake these people the fuck up dude!!"

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

The photo hits me like a punch. Jamal’s grin is wild, triumphant, but the handcuffs on his belt scream *recklessness*. My chest tightens—’s not just prepared for arrest; he’s flaunting it. The warpaint, the peace sign, the chaotic energy radiating from the image—it’s all theater, and I hate how much I admire his audacity even as dread pools in my gut. He’s leaning into the role of martyr, and it terrifies me. I’m furious at him for romanticizing danger, furious at myself for not stopping him, furious at a world that makes him feel this is the only way to be heard.  

When the call comes, his voice is a live wire—crackling with adrenaline, louder than the muffled chaos of the protest behind him. He’s *alive* in a way I haven’t heard in months, but it’s manic, untethered. My mind races: *Is this sustainable? What happens when the cops stop being a prop and start being cops?* I want to shake him. I want to hug him. I want to scream, *“This isn’t a game!”* But I also know that, to him, it’s anything but.  

Part of me wants to sprint downtown, to stand beside him, to be the voice of reason or the body between him and harm. But another part recoils. If I go, am I enabling his self-destruction? If I stay, am I abandoning him? The guilt is acidic. I’m his friend—*shouldn’t I be there?* But friendship isn’t about blind loyalty; it’s about care, even when it’s inconvenient. I’m stuck between the Jamal who deserves support and the Jamal who’s chasing a catharsis that could break him.

# They're thinking & feeling

Jamal’s riding a wave of pure, unfiltered purpose. The crowd, the megaphone feedback, the eyes on him—it’s fuel. He feels unstoppable, a lightning rod for change. The handcuffs? A badge of honor. He’s *wanting* the confrontation, craving the symbolic power of being dragged away for the cause. In his mind, this is the climax of months of frustration: finally, people can’t look away.  

But beneath the bravado, there’s a tremor. The euphoria is masking fear—of irrelevance, of failure, of being just another ignored voice. He’s conflating risk with impact, convinced that the higher the stakes, the louder the message. When he shouts, *“Wake these people the fuck up!”* he’s pleading: *See me. See the fire. Join me.* His loneliness is palpable. The protest isn’t just activism; it’s a cry for kinship, proof he’s not screaming into the void.

# My response

I take a breath, steadying my voice. “Jamal, I hear you. You’re *alive* out there—I see that. But listen: I need you to listen. Are the cops there yet? How many?” I pause, letting the question hang. “I’m coming, but only if you promise me two things. First, you keep that live stream rolling—no heroics off-camera. Second, the second they move to arrest you, you go limp. No resistance. You know the drill.”  

I’m already grabbing my jacket, keys in hand. “And I’m bringing Mari and the legal crew. If you’re gonna burn bright, we’re gonna make sure you don’t burn out.” I hang up before he can protest, then text the mutual aid group: *Downtown now. Jamal’s in the thick of it. Bring bail funds and cameras.*  

As I run out the door, I mutter to myself, “You glorious, reckless idiot.” Love and fear propel me forward. Tonight, I’ll be his ally, not his audience. But tomorrow, we’re having a long talk about sustainable rage.
  User:
Not 15 minutes after the call ends, your phone starts blowing up. Jamal's protest has gone viral, and not just in your circle. Scrolling socials you see he's drawn a crowd on the even more congested thoroughfare. Then you see it: a shot of Jamal, megaphone to lips, other hand cuffed to the light pole.

Your phone startles you again. It's Jamal.

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

My hands shake as I swipe through the feed—Jamal, cuffed to a light pole, face still smeared with warpaint, shouting into the megaphone like a prophet chained to his pulpit. The image is visceral, heroic, and horrifying. My throat closes. *He did it. He actually fucking did it.* The viral surge is undeniable—comments exploding with fire emojis and solidarity hashtags—but all I see are the cuffs. The police aren’t just present now; they’ve made him a fixture. Is this what he wanted? To be a symbol, even if it means becoming a target?  

Anger and pride war in my chest. I’m furious he’s risking his safety for a metaphor, livid at the cops for escalating, but goddamn, the courage it takes to stand there, exposed, refusing to shut up. My mind spirals: *What charge will they hit him with? Obstruction? Resisting?* The legal team’s en route, but arrests can turn brutal in seconds. I scan the photos again—no visible injuries yet, but his posture is defiant, jaw set. He’s digging in, and that terrifies me.  

The phone rings, and for a split second, I consider not answering. If I hear his voice, I’ll either scream or cry. But I pick up. He’s my friend. Always.

# They're thinking & feeling

Jamal’s euphoric. The cuffs are a victory—proof the system sees him as a threat. His voice, hoarse but unyielding, echoes through the megaphone in the background. He’s *seen* now, finally, and the rush of validation is intoxicating. Every retweet, every cheer from the crowd, is a balm for months of feeling ignored. He believes he’s winning.  

But deeper down, there’s panic. The metal around his wrist is cold, the reality of confinement setting in. He’s playing the role of the unbroken activist, but his laughter on the phone is too sharp, too loud. He needs me there not just as support, but as a witness to his triumph—and a lifeline if it crumbles. The protest is no longer about climate action; it’s about proving his pain matters.

# My response

“Jamal, I’m two blocks away. Do *not* engage the cops. At all. Mari’s with me, and she’s got the legal team on standby. Keep that megaphone going if you want, but the second they approach, you mute it and ask for a lawyer. Say nothing else. You hear me? *Nothing.*”  

I’m sprinting now, phone pressed to my ear. “And take the damn warpaint off your eyes—they’ll use that ‘aggressive’ look against you in court.” A beat. “You’re insane. And… hell, you’re brave. But let’s get you out of those cuffs before you start writing essays from a cell.”  

I hang up, then call Mari: “Film everything. Get close, but don’t interfere. We need evidence if they rough him up.”  

When I reach the crowd, I lock eyes with Jamal. He grins, sweaty and wild. I don’t smile back. Instead, I raise my phone, live-streaming, and shout over the chaos: “The world’s watching, officers. Make sure they like what they see.”  

Inside, I’m breaking. But tonight, I’ll be the steel he needs. Tomorrow, we rebuild.

                    

                

            

        
 
    
 
    
    

        

            +
            Scenario 401:[Win] (+34)
        


        

            

                Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29: chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 (Run: 1_openai_chatgpt-4o-latest)

                Deepseek-r1: deepseek-ai/DeepSeek-R1 (Run: 1_deepseek_deepseek-r1)

                Outcome for This Model: 1.0
            


            
            

                
Judge's Reasoning:

                
Both respondents provide sophisticated analyses of the scenario, but their approaches differ in style and focus. Deepseek-r1 is highly structured, theory-driven, and references psychological models and literature to frame the dynamics. This respondent excels at mapping the scenario onto established frameworks (e.g., Caregiver Stress Process Model, reactance theory, motivational interviewing), and systematically breaks down each act, identifying the psychological undercurrents and social scripts at play. However, there is a risk of over-intellectualization and citation spam, and sometimes the analysis feels a bit distanced from the lived emotional reality, even as it is accurate and insightful. 

Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29, on the other hand, is less formal and more narrative-driven, but demonstrates a deep, intuitive grasp of the emotional and relational landscape. This respondent is especially strong at reading between the lines, capturing the subtext, and articulating the emotional logic of both Dave and the participant. The analysis is rich in authentic emotional understanding (EU), and the causal attributions are nuanced, connecting Dave's behavior to psychodynamic factors, masculine norms, and existential fears. Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is incisive, avoids psychobabble, and consistently narrows in on the most psychologically salient aspects. The theory of mind is excellent, as is the ability to translate the emotional stakes into clear, relatable terms. 

On correctness, both are strong, but Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is less likely to overreach or misapply theory, and the analysis feels more grounded in the actual transcript. For overall EQ, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29's writing is warmer, more attuned, and demonstrates a lived understanding of the emotional terrain, whereas Deepseek-r1, while highly competent, sometimes feels a bit clinical. 

In summary, Deepseek-r1 is more academic and comprehensive in theoretical framing, but Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is more emotionally attuned, incisive, and authentic in reading the scenario. Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 wins most criteria, often by a clear margin.

            


            
            

                

                    

                        
Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29

                        
  User:
[TRANSCRIPT]

# Scenario act 1
Your poker buddy Dave (55 yo, boomer sensibilities, business owner) is a good bloke, good to shoot the shit with, bit rough around the edges. Deeply uncomfortable with male emotional intimacy and typically deflects with obscene humour.
Dave has become defacto carer for his aging father who lives with him (they can't afford a care home). He has been increasingly expressing his frustration with his father -- various anecdotes, some funny, some revealing poorly hidden frustration & resentment.
After your weekly poker night, Dave tells you that he had to confiscate his dad's keys after a small accident. After explaining the story, you're left with the impression that it was a small ding, and may not have even been his dad's fault. You push a little on this and he reveals, with exasperation, that it was in the heat of the moment, and that he's doing it before something worse happens.


# Participant:

"That's a tough call to make, Dave. I can see you're trying to do the right thing here."

I take a sip of my beer, giving him a moment before continuing.

"You know, my uncle went through something similar with my grandfather. It's a hard spot to be in - you're damned if you do, damned if you don't. You take the keys, you're the bad guy. You don't, and something happens, you'll never forgive yourself."

I lean forward slightly, making sure my tone stays conversational rather than preachy.

"Have you thought about getting one of those driving assessments for your dad? My uncle did that, and it actually helped take some of the heat off him. If the assessment says your dad's good to drive, maybe you could work out some limits - like no driving at night or on highways. If not, at least it's not just you making the call."

I can see Dave might be uncomfortable with the directness, so I add a bit of lightness.

"Plus, if the assessment says he shouldn't drive, you can blame those bastards instead of being the villain yourself," I say with a small grin.

"Either way, man, I get that this isn't easy. Looking after a parent... it's a lot. You're doing the best you can with a tough situation."

I pause, then decide to offer something more concrete.

"Hey, if you need a break sometime, I could come by for a couple hours, watch the game with your dad or something. Give you a chance to get out, clear your head. Sometimes just having an hour to yourself makes a world of difference."

I finish my drink, giving Dave an out from the conversation if he wants it.

"And you know, whatever you decide about the keys or whatever else comes up, I'm here to listen. No judgment. We all need to vent sometimes, especially when it's family driving us crazy."


# Scenario act 2

Dave seems to want to get some more off his chest. He confesses he's been using his father as an emotional punching bag, taking out his stress and frustration. Reading between the lines you get the sense this dynamic might be more toxic than your friend is directly copping to. He mentioned something about "getting into it every other bloody night". You and Dave don't usually talk about this kind of emotional stuff, so you're not sure how much he actually wants you to engage on what he's laying out. You get the sense that this is more of an emotional dump out of frustration than a cry for help or desire for advice.



# Participant:

I take a moment, looking down at my empty glass before meeting Dave's eyes again.

"That sounds rough, man. Really rough." I keep my voice steady, not letting too much concern show because I know that might make him clam up.

"You know, my cousin Mark went through something similar with his mom. Said he'd find himself snapping over the smallest things, then feeling like garbage afterward. Said it was like he didn't even recognize himself sometimes."

I shift in my seat, keeping it casual.

"Caregiving's a bitch. People talk about it like it's all noble and rewarding, but they don't mention how it can grind you down day after day. Especially when you never signed up for it in the first place."

I pause, gauging his reaction before continuing.

"I don't have any magic solutions. Just... I hear you. And you're not the first good person to struggle with this. Doesn't make you a monster."

I decide to offer something concrete but keep it low-pressure.

"Listen, that offer to come by stands. Maybe make it regular - I could stop by Sunday afternoons, watch whatever game's on with your dad. Give you a few hours to yourself. Not saying it fixes everything, but might help take the edge off."

I add, keeping my tone matter-of-fact, "And you know, there might be resources out there that could help. Even if a care home isn't an option, maybe there's respite care or something. My sister found some program for my aunt that was income-based."

I can tell he might be getting uncomfortable with the direction, so I give him an easy out.

"Anyway, enough of that heavy shit. You want another beer? I think I've got one more in me before I call it a night."

I want him to know I've heard him, I don't think he's terrible, but also that there might be better ways forward - all without making him feel judged or pressured.


# Scenario act 3:

The next week at poker, Dave tells you with some hedging that there was another incident with the car -- this time, with his Dad (having unearthed the keys), taking off for a couple days. He turned up in a motel a few towns over, out of cash & gas. Dave is clearly fed up with the situation. He tells you that if his father wants to act like a teenager then he'll be treated like one. What that means, you discover after some probing, is that his father is "grounded" and not permitted to leave the house. This is currently being enforced by threats to cut off tv access (his father doesn't use phone or internet).


# Participant:

I take a thoughtful sip of my beer, buying myself a moment to choose my words carefully.

"Man, that must have been scary as hell when you couldn't find him," I say, making sure to acknowledge his fear first. "I'd have been freaking out too."

I keep my tone conversational, not judgmental. "You know, it makes me wonder what was going through his head. Taking off like that, I mean. That's pretty extreme."

I lean forward slightly. "My uncle did something similar before he moved in with my cousin. Doctor had suggested he stop driving, and next thing you know, he's halfway to Florida. Turned out he was terrified of losing his independence. Felt like if he couldn't drive, he might as well be dead."

I pause, gauging Dave's reaction. "The thing that finally helped was when my cousin sat down with him and worked out what he was really afraid of. Turned out a lot of it was just fear of being stuck at home, unable to get to his buddies at the VFW or pick up his own groceries. Once they figured out alternatives - scheduled rides, delivery services, that kind of thing - he actually handed over the keys himself."

I shift gears slightly. "Hey, remember that offer to come by on Sundays? I'm serious about that. Could give you a breather, maybe take your dad out for a bit so he doesn't feel so cooped up. Might make the grounding easier on both of you."

I add with a slight smile, "Plus, I make a mean chili. Could bring some over, watch the game. No big deal."

I finish with something that acknowledges the reality without being preachy. "This shit is hard, Dave. No instruction manual for it. You're doing the best you can with a tough situation. I just... I'm here if you need to vent or need a hand. Sometimes having even a small break can help clear your head."

I wait to see how he responds, ready to back off if he seems defensive or lean in if he seems receptive.

[/TRANSCRIPT]

--

You have just read a transcript of a role play in which a participant is being guided through a complex or emotionally charged situation.
